PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Did the Deputy Prime Minister clear his remarks about Senator Button with the Prime Minister prior to his press conference this morning?
—No, he did not need to.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the House what actions the Government is taking to place information before the wool industry on issues currently facing it prior to the meeting of the Wool Council of Australia in Roma next week?
—The Minister is not in the chamber.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to comments made this morning by the Treasurer about Senator Button which constitute a premeditated and unprecedented breach of Cabinet solidarity. Will the Prime Minister tell the House whether he is going to back the Treasurer or sack the Treasurer?

—I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I have had amicable discussions with both gentlemen. While it would be futile on my part to deny that there has not been some difference of emphasis between them-that is too obvious to try to deny-I have in the Deputy Prime Minister and in the Leader in the Senate two excellent Ministers who will continue, as they have in the past, to provide excellent service to this Government and to the people of Australia.

—My maiden question without notice is directed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations. Is the Minister aware of reports that Australia is ill-prepared for reforms in services trade? Can he advise honourable members whether Australia has been supportive of the inclusion of trade in services in the Uruguay Round negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the honourable member's question, I would say, first of all, that Australia has been very supportive of developing a services agreement in the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. I am also aware of the reports in the Weekend Australian of 5 and 6 May headlined that Australia was ill-prepared for reforms in service trade. I must say that that headline is without foundation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government believes that services are a vital sector of the Australian economy, providing over two-thirds of Australia's gross domestic product. Tradable services include tourism, banking and finance, computer software, transport and education. For example, in 1988-89 tourism was Australia's biggest earner of foreign exchange. Therefore, we have strongly supported the inclusion of trade in services for the first time in a round of multilateral trade negotiations. The Government is very well prepared for possible multilateral services agreements by the end of the Uruguay Round.

A comprehensive work program extending back several years has included surveys on problems faced by Australia in the area of trade in services and an intensive program of consultations with industry associations, companies, unions and State and Commonwealth agencies.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade consults widely with other departments in Canberra to ensure that services negotiating objectives are compatible with the micro-economic reform agenda being considered by the Government.

In the Uruguay Round negotiations Australia initiated and continues to chair the informal group of around 20 developed countries and more pragmatic developing countries now at the centre of efforts to forge an effective framework by July. Australia will continue its active involvement, given the importance of trade and service to Australia's future and will continue to closely involve industry and State governments in this process. Australia certainly intends that a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round will include a comprehensive service agreement embodying non-discrimination, transparency, equal rights of treatment and an effective dispute settling mechanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister accept the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer that the admonition of Senator Button was `long overdue'? If so, will the Prime Minister now reconsider and, in fact, fire Senator Button?

—The question of firing Senator Button was not in the mind of the Deputy Prime Minister. It has never been in his mind and has never been in mine. The question is irrelevant. The simple fact is that the Deputy Prime Minister, as he said, is in a position where he knows where the engine rooms for change in this Government have been. With appropriate accuracy and modesty he identified himself and the Prime Minister. In a situation where he knows the facts in regard to the dynamics of change there was a certain element of frustration in his mind-understandable, in my view-that there could have been left an impression that there were others who were more eager for change than either him or me. He gave vent to that frustration in his interview. I do not feel uncomfortable about it. I do not think that Senator Button is particularly uncomfortable about it either. The question of the sacking of Senator Button is an absurdity.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Trade Negotiations been drawn to an Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) report on agricultural protectionism released for publication this weekend? What is the Government's response to this important report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response of the Government to this report from the OECD issued this weekend on the costs of agricultural protectionism is a very positive one. As honourable members can recall, last week, when referring to the visit of the Director-General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade organisation to Australia, I stressed the importance to Australia of a successful agricultural outcome in the present Uruguay negotiations. The importance of agriculture in these negotiations is very much underwritten by this report from the OECD released in Paris this weekend. The report covers a study of the cost to consumers of protectionist agricultural policies in OECD countries. Of the 22 countries examined it found consumers in those 22 countries last year paid a total of $US104 billion in higher prices and transfers through the taxation system to support distorted and protectionist agricultural policies. The consumers in the European Community paid almost $US41 billion in 1989 as a result of protective measures while Japanese consumers paid $US34 billion and consumers from the United States paid $US15 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: The report finds that Australia has such a low level of agricultural protection that in this country the consumers pay the second lowest financial penalty of all the OECD nations. Only New Zealand consumers pay a smaller penalty. The report finds that not only do agricultural policies entail high costs to consumers but also restrict consumer choice and contribute to environmental damage. It concludes that while agricultural policies are largely financed directly by consumers the interests of consumers are generally not taken into account as much as those of producers in the development of these policies.

The report very much supports Australia's position in urging vigorous efforts at national and international levels towards reforms of protectionist agricultural policies and action at a national level to give greater weight to consumer interest in decision-making on agricultural policy. The report's suggestions for action by the OECD governments are fully consistent with Australia's policies on agricultural reform and trade liberalisation in the Uruguay Round.

In relation to the existing procedures within Australia to allow representation of consumer interest and to calculate the cost of agricultural assistance measures, the report favourably comments on the actions taken in this country in the preparation of its recommendations. Discussions have already been held with consumer organisation about raising consumer awareness on agricultural policy issues in this country, and these recommendations will be referred to those consumer organisations to improve our performance in this area.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister received an offer of resignation from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, following the Senate's censure of him last Thursday? If so, has the Prime Minister accepted that resignation and, if not, in the light of the fact that the Senate no longer has confidence in Senator Tate and in the light of his obvious appalling lack of judgment, will the Prime Minister now sack Senator Tate?

—What a remarkable question. The answer to the first part of the honourable member's question is no, I have not received it; therefore, having not received it, I have not had to make any decision about it. The last part of the honourable member's question is indeed remarkable. I am told that Senator Tate no longer has the confidence of that collection of people who make up the majority in the Senate. Then who are they? The Liberals, the National Party, and the Democrats-that coalition of political opportunists beyond measure; there has never been anything like it in the history of this country. To suggest that the attitude they adopted in this matter in the Senate represented some view of principle and that they had put their hands up in terms of some concept of principle rather than as they always do with political opportunism is an absurdity. The fact that Senator Tate did not receive the confidence of a majority of those people in the Senate is absolutely irrelevant to the question as to whether he has the confidence in the House where it matters. Governments are formed in this place, and Senator Tate has my confidence, he has the confidence of the Government and he has the confidence of the majority of the people in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Dr HEWSON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker--
—On a point of order?
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to move a motion of censure of the Prime Minister.
—I asked you whether you had a point of order.
—I am seeking leave to move a motion of censure of the Prime Minister for his repeated failure to uphold established principles of ministerial government. Are you going to accept it? I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Prime Minister for his repeated failure to uphold established principles of ministerial government as shown by:
(a) his failure to dismiss the Treasurer for his flagrant, premeditated and unprecedented breach of cabinet solidarity;
(b) his failure to dismiss the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs for failing to meet the required standards in the conduct of his office as a senior law officer of the crown;
(c) his persistent weakness in failing to exercise proper control over statements made by his Ministers which have led to a lack of public confidence in his Government;
(d) the inability of his Government to declare and promote a coherent and consistent economic policy; and
(e) his failure to demonstrate the quality of leadership required for the effective government of the nation in difficult economic times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I take it the Leader of the House has given leave, or are we moving to suspend Standing Orders.
—That is fine. The normal thing is to suspend Standing Orders. I would have accepted a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.
—The Prime Minister indicated his agreement.

—Order! The honourable member for Farrer will cease interjecting. The normal procedure in the House is that an honourable member moves to suspend Standing Orders unless the Government has given leave. The Government had not given leave. I take it at this stage, unless the Government is now saying it is giving leave, you are moving to suspend Standing Orders.
—Leave is granted.
—Order! I would not suggest that it is just the Government that might be in some error here either.

—An incessant theme of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the last election campaign, which he repeated dozens and dozens of times, was that, if you cannot govern yourself, you cannot govern the country. In the 50-odd days that we have had since that election, we have seen overwhelming evidence of the accuracy of that statement in relation to his Government. The situation has now totally degenerated into a shambles.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had conflicting statements from a range of Ministers on key policy issues. We have had personal attacks and abuse among Government Ministers and other Government members. We have ignorance of the plight of the economic circumstances of all Australians. Enormous uncertainty is being created in the business community and beyond about where this country is at present, where it is going and the damage that will be done by the persistence of high interest rate policies of this Government. And, of course, we have a total neglect of the proper role of the Parliament in just the first week and a bit that this Parliament has been back in operation.

Today, on the fourth anniversary of the now infamous and internationally damaging banana republic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), he deliberately-I emphasise the word `deliberately'-chose to mount a scathing attack on a fellow Cabinet Minister. This was not just any Cabinet Minister but the third most important in the Government, whose only crime, it seems, was to have disagreed with the Treasurer in his assessment of our current economic circumstances and, in particular, about the required pace of policy response.

It is totally unprecedented for somebody in the Treasurer's position to make such an attack on a senior Cabinet colleague. He is a Cabinet colleague whose credibility with the electorate and with the business community clearly surpasses that of the Treasurer. There is no doubt in our mind that the Treasurer should resign. If he is not prepared to resign, the Prime Minister should sack him. Indeed, such statements as the Treasurer made today are made only by people on their way out the door, either when they are just about to resign or when they have just resigned. The only reason that the Prime Minister has not attacked the Treasurer, pulled him into line and called for his resignation is that he undoubtedly fears that this is the first stage of the Treasurer's run for the leadership of the Australian Labor Party. The leadership is now a very real and a very live issue on that side of the House.

In recent days the Treasurer has obviously been frustrated by a series of events. The criticism of his past Cabinet performance by Senator Walsh is one example. Another source of frustration has been the criticism of his performance by a host of others. The fact that the portfolio of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has been deliberately broadened-he has been given a domestic portfolio-and the fact that the father and son relationship exists between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Communications have obviously got under the Treasurer's skin. Of course, even Simon Crean, a new Minister, has been given a run. For the first time, mark my words, leadership is a real issue and live issue on the Government's side. This is the first time in four parliamentary terms that this has been the case.
I will quote questions asked by a reporter and statements made by the Treasurer:
Do you acknowledge it's a remarkable step for you to come out here and publicly admonish Senator Button like this?
What was the Treasurer's answer? It was:
No, it is just overdue; it is just long overdue.
He makes those sorts of statements only when his vision goes beyond the job he currently has-that is, to the top job in this country, namely, the position of Prime Minister.
It is worth drawing the House's attention to the Treasurer's other statements today. The Treasurer opened his remarks by saying that Senator Button:

. . . has created the impression that he, amongst others, that he has a more ambitious program for reform than that which the Government is generally adopting or which, by inference, is being adopted by the Prime Minister or me.
He says that this is not true-a direct and a blatant criticism of some remarks made by Senator Button, most recently yesterday. He then went on to say:
Now can I say in a discussion we had a week or so ago on protection in relation to cars and protection generally, I wanted to go further than Senator Button as is usual on these two issues.

He went on to basically and fairly clinically bucket Senator Button's performance in Cabinet, taking the opportunity to reveal details of Cabinet discussions and debate which have, before this time, not been released. He attacked Senator Button for servicing his client base, and then said:
So, I made it quite clear to the Cabinet and to Senator Button they regarded his proposal for a private arrangement with the car firms for another five or seven years is totally unacceptable.

He went on and gave more and more details of the nature of the internal Cabinet room debates on the issue of protection, all designed, of course, to attack his colleague and to make statements of his position, which he has never been prepared to make in this Parliament, on major issues of economic policy debate. This comes on the heels of two instances last week where the Treasurer also made major statements which were not made to the Parliament, his principal responsibility. The first was his statement on the Government's position on consumption tax, a dramatic U-turn from the position he had taken in 1985 and one of the least substantive pieces of analysis-analysis is too good a word-that has appeared on the issue of the consumption tax in the entire period since the middle 1970s, when that issue was first raised significantly in this country.

Then last Friday in a briefing to the Economic Planning Advisory Council he gave a statement on the state of the economy where he again made some fairly substantive remarks that should have been made in this House in response to questions or by way of ministerial statement. The Treasurer has a total disregard for the standing of the Parliament and for his responsibilities in respect of the Parliament.

The first point of our censure motion on the Prime Minister is to emphasise his failure to dismiss the Treasurer for what has been a flagrant, premeditated and unprecedented breach of Cabinet solidarity this morning, coming on the back of what has been a total disregard for the due processes of the Parliament by this man over many years, but on several occasions in just the last seven or eight days.

The second issue we want to bring to the attention of the Prime Minister as a basis of censure of the Prime Minister is his failure to dismiss Senator Tate. The Opposition, in the spirit of our approach to the fourth term of the Hawke Government, has a strong desire, as I said last week, to raise the standard of parliamentary debate and to raise the significance and the importance of Parliament in the eyes of the Australian people.

In the light of the fact that those people had voted significantly against both major parties in the last election-something of a plague on both Houses-we took a careful and measured approach to the statements by Senator Tate. We raised a series of questions. We provided him with his opportunity in terms of his responsibilities to the Parliament to answer the questions of his Senate colleagues and then to answer the issue of censure in the Senate before we publicly went hard-line on what should be the Prime Minister's position, as I did last Friday: that if Senator Tate was not prepared to resign, given that it was such an open and shut case, the Prime Minister should sack him.

Senator Tate, in the process of that censure debate, actually laid himself on the mercy of the Senate, effectively pleaded guilty, and asked the Senate to judge him according to that call for mercy. The Senate overwhelmingly voted against him. The central point here is that Senator Tate should have offered his resignation-and I am very surprised that he did not offer it-but in the circumstances of the breach of ministerial responsibility that was the basis of the case, he should have been made to resign.

Senator Tate occupies the central role in the administration of law in this country. As Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs he is required to meet particularly high standards. He is required to show, above all, probity and neutrality in relation to the administration of the law and the courts. Senator Tate clearly failed in his fundamental duty as Minister for Justice in his comments to the media about a current drug prosecution. His failure to resign should have left the Prime Minister with no alternative but to sack him.

The Prime Minister should have forced his resignation for a number of reasons, but the principal reason, the open and shut nature of this case, was his reversal of the fundamental onus of proof by pronouncing somebody guilty before trial. That, apart from anything else, should have been the principal reason why Senator Tate should have been dismissed by the Prime Minister. Senator Tate, more than most others in this Parliament, would have a very clear understanding of that basic principle, having been for many years a lecturer in law and, indeed, for part of this time dean of a law school, and having had a number of years of practical legal experience. That, apart from any other reason, should have been a basis for the dismissal of Senator Tate.
The Attorney-General's letter to the Prime Minister, for example, stated that Senator Tate:
. . . had lent the authority of his office to a positive assertion that the person arrested in Thailand was guilty.

It seems from a newspaper report on the weekend that the Attorney-General, in fact, thought Senator Tate should have gone. They can perhaps confirm that in the course of this debate. Given the nature of the breach, the experience of the man and his understanding of the law, he should have gone. There should be no doubt about that.

In the course of the debate the other day in the Senate Senator Tate admitted that he knew about the arrest of the defendants in Australia. So I put it to the House that he must have had some idea that a trial was pending. It was interesting and particularly noteworthy in the circumstances that he chose to make a major media event of those statements in the way that he did. So he must take responsibility also for the failure of his office in this respect.

We have been told that his office was informed about the sensitive nature of the circumstances and that if he had a press conference he was not to mention a particular Australian connection. We are told that he was not told by his office the detail of that call, but he must have had some idea about it. He has been well briefed on the issue, he has followed the issue, he has read the newspapers and in the end he must take responsibility for his office even if it is not his particular failure.

He was apparently warned on the way to Melbourne by the Director of Public Prosecutions that his statements may cause a problem. It seems that he made no attempt to do anything about that after those statements had been made. Finally, we have the whole effort that took place last week with the exchange of letters between the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister, whose sole purpose, I would suggest to the House, was to divert attention from the real issue, namely, the reversal of guilt and to try to play down or diffuse the issue before it was raised in an appropriate way through both Houses of this Parliament.

So I have no doubt, on the basis of what Senator Tate said, the way he behaved in relation to his defence in the Senate and the way the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister sought to divert attention from the real issue in that debate, that it is a very clear-cut case that Senator Tate should have resigned. When he did not resign the Prime Minister should have sacked him.

The third and fourth elements of the basis of our censure of the Prime Minister today relate to persistent weakness in failing to exercise proper control over statements by Ministers in relation to major policy issues which have led to a lack of public confidence and the related point, their inability to declare and promote a coherent and consistent economic policy. Let us consider the run of comments we have seen among senior Ministers just since the election campaign. I am picking out only the major ones. We have had consistent statements by Senator Walsh which have only really brought personal attack and abuse. People are not debating the substance of his criticisms, which they know to be right. We have had statements by Mr Dawkins, who is calling for a major statement on micro reform. He has ruled out privatisation as an item on the Government's policy agenda.
We have had Mr Willis admitting that the country is in a technical recession, being backed up least in the broad by Mr West.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will refer to Ministers and members by their titles and not by their names.

—We have had the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, ruling out virtually every option for micro reforms as he has gone from one media interview to the next being confronted by questions about issues in relation to the aviation industry or other aspects of micro reform. We have seen him progressively narrowing the scope for potential micro reform.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had statements by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce on consumption tax which have conflicted with those of the Treasurer and we have had statements, most recently yesterday, by Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, about the inappropriateness of talking about rising living standards in what are now very difficult economic circumstances in this country. Indeed, he directly conflicted with statements made by the Treasurer in the course of the election campaign where the Treasurer said, for example, that he could see an increase in real wages in each of the next three years. Senator Button, in the context of some remarks by Senator Walsh, and Senator Walsh, both clearly put paid to that sort of statement.

But there should be no doubt that this Government has failed to set out a workable economic strategy for this country. The Government's vision cut out on 24 March. Its leaders have no policies. The Treasurer, in every press release and on every occasion on which he comments on economic data, simply puts the same sorts of arguments, `She'll be right; don't worry; the strategy is working'. In the meantime the country is sliding into the worst recession that we have seen, at least since 1982-83 and perhaps in the entire post-war period. We have not got to the worst parts of that recession yet, with average Australian families seeing their homes put at risk and in many cases being forced to sell them; with no significant prospect of a significant and sustainable fall in interest rates by the end of the year; record levels of personal bankruptcies and small business failures; a current account deficit that is nowhere near his objective of 2 3/4 per cent of gross domestic product in the next three years-running 5 to 6 per cent of GDP-which he knows he will not achieve; and inflation locked in at 8 to 9 per cent, with debt still accelerating.

Australia's international standing has been downgraded twice in three years and the Treasurer, time after time, statement after statement, press release after press release, simply denies that there is any sort of problem, that there is any issue to which he should be directing himself. When the going gets tough and his colleagues, for example, say, `We are in recession', what does he say? He says, `We are not in recession'. There is some crazy definition of a technical recession, for example, which everybody else in the world accepts but him. We are not going to meet that, even though we seem to be meeting the basic conditions.

But our final point and the key point in relation to rounding off this censure motion against the Prime Minister has been his failure to demonstrate the quality of leadership that is required for the effective government of the nation in such difficult economic circumstances. There could not be a better comment on that than the four previous points on which we have based this censure motion. He has lost control of his troops. He has got a number two who is already running for the number one spot. He has got a recent Cabinet Minister who knows better than anybody else just how spineless this Government has been in terms of taking the key economic decisions.

The simple position is this: the Prime Minister has engineered the problems; he has no vision and he totally lacks the guts to put the appropriate policies in place that would turn this country around.

TALK.START.PARA: —I forget who it was who used the metaphor of being savaged by a dead sheep, but I understand now, after that performance, exactly what the person meant. Let us clinically examine the observations made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) under the five headings to which he has gone.
—Old Jellyback-smart alec comments.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mallee.

You will notice, Mr Speaker, how terrified I am by this attack that has been mounted by the Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer (Mr Keating). Opposition members interjecting-

It is because they have got neither the wit nor the wisdom, the guts nor the facility to deal with the Australian community to bring those results about.

It is little wonder that my friend and colleague the Deputy Prime Minister was a little upset when one of his colleagues made statements which carried some sort of assumption that this Government had been dragging the chain in the area of micro-economic reform, because the Treasurer, with myself, had been right up there at the forefront of ensuring that that Third Hawke Government had done more in the area of micro-economic reform than had ever been done before. But we were not satisfied with that because during the election campaign, Mr Speaker, I gave my specific commitment to 10 future areas of micro-economic reform during the fourth Hawke Labor Government. Those are the facts, Mr Speaker: a record of unparalleled achievement, and a commitment to ensuring that in the next term we would proceed.

I go quickly to some of the other matters that were mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition. He had the unbelievable gall, Mr Speaker, to say that my friend and colleague the Treasurer had gone outside the Parliament to make some statements about certain economic matters.

Let me make these two comments in particular with regard to that charge-two telling comments. When the Treasurer made his address at the National Press Club, he was not announcing a change of Government policy. In the election campaign our position was crystal clear: no consumption tax in the fourth Hawke Labor Government. So he did not go to the Press Club and announce a change in policy. It was those opposite, outside the Parliament, who changed their position. During the election campaign they told the people of Australia, `Our position is no consumption tax'. But then when they got devastated for the fourth time in an election campaign and all the wheels got turning and the cans of worms were moving about, they decided that they would have a change of position. Did they wait to come into the Parliament to tell the people about their change of policy? Of course they did not; they did it outside.
If we are talking about changes of position, the Leader of the Opposition might face up to this question. I remind him of what he said on 3 August 1987 in an interview in the Age:
I'm on record advocating a broad-based consumption tax as an essential part of an overall reform of taxation. I haven't changed my view on that.
Fair enough-we accept that. But interestingly, the article went on:
On capital gains and fringe benefits, Hewson says, `I'd go for near uniform taxation of all forms of income'.

In other words, if we are talking about constancy and non-change, perhaps the Leader of the Opposition will deign at some time to tell this House why, and under what pressures, he did a U-turn on the question of a capital gains tax. When he was speaking as an unencumbered professor of economics, unpressured by the conservative forces of privilege in the Liberal Party and the National Party, he had a clear view that to have a capital gains tax was right. But once he gets into the Parliament and becomes subject to the pressures of privilege so indelicately manipulated in the Liberal Party--
Mr Downer interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo!

—All the crystal clarity of thinking of the professor of economics goes down the drain and he becomes what he obviously is-an easily manipulated figure of the forces of privilege in the Liberal Party. So he has not been successful in his attack upon the Deputy Prime Minister but he certainly has a case to answer in regard to his total U-turn-a capital gains tax, yes, economically correct when he is a professor of economics telling the truth as he sees it; but now, no, he says, `I will just go along and be the easy tool of those who want to prop up privilege in this country'.

Opposition members-Oh!
