TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding this motion, I want to continue with this matter concerning Senator Tate. I must say that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has introduced a particularly new element into this. Even for him, this must be absolutely rock bottom. Desperate as he is, he now calls upon private associations or connections that some of us might have with Senator Tate through the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship. Let me tell the Prime Minister one thing about the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship which he might like to pay attention to: one of the things that it subscribes to is putting into practice in one's daily life some basic principles. I would suggest to the Prime Minister that it is about time that he learned what some of the basic principles are so far as his office of Prime Minister is concerned, and I will elaborate on that as we go along.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition censures the Prime Minister today in respect of Senator Tate for three reasons. The first is because of Senator Tate's appalling failure to live up to the standards expected of a Minister, both generally and, in the particular case, the standards expected of a Minister for Justice. The second reason is because Senator Tate expressly asked the Senate-and we know that the Prime Minister does not think much of the Senate but it happens under the Constitution of this country to be one of the two Houses of this Parliament-after having pleaded guilty, to expiate him, to forgive him. He asked the Senate for a vote of confidence and the Senate gave him a resounding no. We now have, whether the Prime Minister likes it or not, a Minister in his Government who does not have the confidence of the Senate and, hence, does not have the confidence of the Parliament of this country.

The third reason is because, faced with this quite overwhelming case-it is the only way to describe it-the Prime Minister, instead of acting as a Prime Minister should and demanding the resignation of Senator Tate when his Minister is clearly incompetent and does not have the confidence of the Parliament, acted in the most spineless and unprincipled way and let the Minister stay on. By that means we say that this Prime Minister has demeaned his own office and the principles of ministerial government.

I mention the word principles. It is just as well that we get the principles straight in this matter before we go any further. Frankly, our system of government cannot function properly or with public confidence unless Ministers can pass some basic tests. The first test is that they have to be competent and know what they are doing. Senator Tate has failed that test. Secondly, Ministers must have, and they must show that they have, some basic understanding of the rules that govern their own portfolio. Senator Tate showed that he has no such understanding. Thirdly, they must have the confidence of the Parliament because under our system of government if a Minister does not have the confidence of the Parliament then that Minister has nothing.

We have these principles straight. If we have them straight then we can look at the three reasons why the Opposition maintains that the Prime Minister should have sacked Senator Tate. Not having done it so far he should do it now. We maintain further that not having done so to this moment the Prime Minister is certainly deserving of being censured by this House.

I come to the first reason again. It must surely now be obvious to anyone that Senator Tate acted with the grossest incompetence imaginable when he announced to the world at large that a Thai man who had been arrested in Thailand was the No. 1 importer of heroin to Australia. Not only did he announce that to the world but he did so without qualification. At the same time there were three people on trial in Sydney for those exact activities. Not only were they on trial in Sydney for those exact activities but they were on trial in a case where the principal contention of the Crown was that they had dealt with heroin which had been supplied to them from Thailand by this same man whom Senator Tate had branded in public as being guilty. The Minister committed two absolutely vital and fundamental blunders. It must surely be as plain as a pikestaff that he has done that. Senator Tate's first blunder was to make the announcement to the world at large that this man arrested in Thailand was, in fact, guilty. The second blunder he committed was that he aborted a trial in Sydney because, as I have said, the three people in Sydney who were on trial were alleged by the Crown to have been dealing in heroin which that same man had been responsible for shipping from Thailand to Australia. Commonsense would tell one that this is plain incompetence.

We do not need to go any further than to remind ourselves of the Prime Minister's own categorisation of this conduct of Senator Tate as an appalling lapse of judgment. This means that if Senator Tate stays in the Ministry the Australian people should understand that the Hawke Government tolerates a tenth-rate standard of performance from its Ministers. It is worse than that. This comes to the very nub of what our case is about. Senator Tate is not just a Minister; he is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. He is sworn in to administer the Attorney-General's Department. If anyone should have any understanding of the principles of justice it must surely be a Minister for Justice. That is the primary qualification which this Minister should have. It is the prime defect that Senator Tate obviously does have and he has no justification for remaining in the Ministry.

I think that Senator Tate has done for justice what General Jaruzelski did for sunglasses. I cannot see any justification for his remaining and holding out this false claim that he has some basic understanding of the principles of justice, when clearly he does not. Of course, honourable members know that he has had a good teacher, because another Minister in this Government likes to brand people as guilty in public, and that is the Prime Minister. Only one example of that is needed. When the War Crimes Amendment Bill was introduced into this Parliament, the Prime Minister, believe it or not, said in public that people who were to be charged under the War Crimes Amendment Bill, which had not even been passed by the Parliament, would appear to have been guilty. The standard the Prime Minister has set himself is to say in public, of people who are about to be charged with crimes, or who might be charged with crimes, that they are in fact guilty. So, on any test, Senator Tate had a good teacher in this particular matter, and he has learned his lesson well.

The second reason for this censure motion with respect to Senator Tate is that he made what he claims is a clean breast of the whole matter. He threw himself on the mercy of the Senate; he virtually pleaded guilty and said to the Senate, `I ask the Senate to indicate by its vote that it wishes me to continue in that particular task.' He said, `Well, I know what I have done; we all know it. We all know the reality. We know all the facts. I ask the Senate to give me a vote of confidence.' The Senate rejected him and gave him a resounding `No'. The Senate was saying, `We have no confidence in you' and, whatever the standing of the Senate may be in the eyes of the Prime Minister, the reality is that one House of this Parliament has censured a Minister in the Hawke Government, and he therefore has no confidence vested in him by the Senate and, for that reason, by the Parliament. It would be bad enough without that censure motion, but it is doubly bad with the censure motion having been passed. Senator Tate's credibility in his State must be the same, and is probably as extinct, as the Tasmanian tiger. He has no basis on which he can hold up his head, or stand or speak with any authority as a Minister of the Government.

We come to the third reason-and this brings us to the Prime Minister, which is what this motion of censure is all about. The Prime Minister has a special responsibility. He has a responsibility to maintain public confidence in all his Ministers; he has a responsibility to uphold the principles of ministerial government; and he has a responsibility to act when it is necessary for him to act. This Prime Minister has been here long enough to know that he is a trustee of what has gone before which has been handed down to him and with which he is expected to comply. It is about time that the Prime Minister was reminded of this and that he put these principles into practice. But, of course, we do not have that sort of Prime Minister. We have a Prime Minister who can say in this case, `Well I looked at this and, on balance, I decided not to sack Senator Tate.' This is the flexible Prime Minister with flexible principles. He applies the principles when it suits his convenience and ignores them when it does not.

The second thing he should have learned by now is, as Gladstone said, `If you are going to be a good Prime Minister, you have to learn to be a good butcher'. A Prime Minister is expected to take firm and resolute decisions when it is necessary for him to do so. There is only way that the Prime Minister can now redeem his position in this particular scandal, and that is for him at last to do the right thing. I do not know what sort of example would influence the Prime Minister. Over the weekend I looked at this question and the closest example I came up with was something that happened during Mr Attlee's Prime Ministership in Britain. This is the way he did it and the way that this Prime Minister should do it if he had enough backbone and gumption to do so, which clearly he does not. Attlee called one of his junior Ministers to 10 Downing Street-a Minister who thought he would be praised for his performance-and Attlee opened up by saying, `I want your job'. The Minister said, `Why, Prime Minister; why?'. Attlee's answer was, `Afraid you are not up to it'. When the facts are presented to a Prime Minister that one of his Ministers is not up to it, it is as simple and straightforward as that. There has been plenty of evidence that Senator Tate is not up to this and, frankly, there is now a lot of evidence accumulating that the Prime Minister himself is not up to it.

This is all perfectly clear. We have a case of a Minister who has failed dismally to perform his proper ministerial functions; a Minister who clearly is grossly incompetent; and a Minister who-and it is doubly worse for this reason-holds himself out as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs but obviously does not have an inkling of what his responsibilities are or what basic principles of justice he should be applying.

There is a clear open and shut case against Senator Tate. He should have been brought to heel from the very time that these facts became known. There is only one clear responsibility on the Prime Minister-one thing for him to do-and that is to dismiss Senator Tate. If he does not do that, he diminishes his own office and the standing of the principles of ministerial government which this country is run along.

As at this time in this debate the Minister has not been dismissed, our position is very clear-and the position should be very clear to the Prime Minister and to this House: the Prime Minister himself should be censured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a time not so long ago when the censure motion was regarded as an instrument whereby matters of great import could be discussed by the Parliament when the Opposition felt indignant about certain circumstances in public issues or their management. But the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson)-again for this Opposition, but for the first time for him-debased this traditional, serious mode of censure which the Parliament's Standing Orders offer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader's speech was very weak. In politics and in this Parliament, if one is going to make a speech with nothing to say, often one is better off saying nothing. This was very much the case with the Leader of the Opposition: he would have been better off not making the speech. Instead, he felt he had to get up and make it. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made an analogy of being mauled by a dead sheep. I could have added another-being hit with a warm lettuce. The fact is that it added up to nothing.

The truth is that, now in the second week of sitting, not one substantive motion about economic issues or the issues which matter to the Parliament has been moved. In fact, today the Opposition cynically listed on the Notice Paper a matter of public importance regarding the flooding and callously used it as a shield to move a censure motion against the Government, knowing that it was intending to move the censure and that, if a censure motion is moved, there is no matter of public importance. That is known to be the case. Those opposite decided to use the flood victims to suit their own political purposes. They will be judged on them accordingly.

The fact is that there are differences of opinion in a government of change. There are differences of emphasis as well as differences of view. But the healthy foment of discussion which has taken place in the Cabinet of this Government over seven years has been the only effective dialogue of change in this country in the last quarter of a century. Why would such a dialogue not go on? When it becomes a public matter, obviously the press and the Opposition are interested. It was my view today that the inferences drawn from the comments of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) could not be left unanswered, and I answered them.

In saying that, I do not have the slightest doubt that the positive approach and contribution that Senator Button has employed in his ministerial duties and career in the last seven years he has been industry Minister will continue during the deliberations of this Government. But because those opposite know that the discussion within this Government is the only dialogue of real change-even the bits that fall from the table-they scrummage around trying to lift for their own political purposes and, dare I say, even learn something.

I have not been asked a question by the Leader of the Opposition in one week and one day because mostly he does not like the answers. I was asked one question by the shadow Treasurer on the second day, I think, and even with that he had to make a bit of an effort. The Leader of the Opposition said that the Government did not have the guts to put the policies into place. In last Friday's Australian Financial Review, in a story backgrounded by the Leader of the Opposition obviously, under the heading `Hewson's priority: cut tax rates on middle incomes', we find this:
But Dr Hewson wants to go much further.
He wants to reduce the whole middle and top structure of personal income tax. He believes that under Paul Keating, the progressivity of the tax system has been greatly increased-
that is, its fairness has been greatly improved-
and that it is time to turn back the tide to increase incentive and encourage initiative . . .

As if the highest profit share in our history is not enough, as if a 39c corporate rate is not enough, as if the rate of tax on distributed income cut in half from 78c to 47c is not enough: no, we have to flatten the tax rate to give tax cuts to people on the top end of the system and at the middle, as the Leader of the Opposition puts it, because the system has become too progressive.

Too right, it has become progressive, with things such as the fringe benefits tax, which collects $250m; the capital gains tax, which is now collecting half a billion dollars a year and growing; the tax file number, which is there to deal with fraud and abuse in the system and which Opposition members supported but only after we dragged them to it; and the more rigorous company tax audit system, over which they have constantly attacked the Tax Commissioner. These are the things which have made the tax system more progressive and more fair. At least we can be thankful for the fact that the Opposition has given us credit by saying our tax system is now much more progressive, even if it does not like it. At least the Opposition has acknowledged the fact that Labor has presided over fairer tax systems.

In the same newspaper, three pages on under the heading: `Hewson promises visionary rule', it picks up the Leader of the Opposition's reply to the Governor-General's Speech. According to the article, the Leader of the Opposition promised `a revitalised coalition under his leadership which was willing to tackle the tough decisions necessary to overcome Australia's economic problems. He said Australia had become too soft and complacent'. Yet on page 1 he wants to give middle and higher income earners a tax cut.

That is where he stands. It is back to Box Hill in week one of this leadership. In other words, he is saying, `Look, we have suffered four defeats at the hands of this Government. We do not have a policy structure, we do not have a structure on wages, we do not have a structure on health, we do not have a policy for constraining demand and producing investment and we have a phoney fiscal policy'. Instead of going back to do the solid work, which the Opposition has never done, here it is with reverberations of Box Hill and the Economic Action Plan in week one-the $8 billion of unfunded tax cuts offered by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), and now the Economic Action Plan with big cuts to the two-rate tax system. The Leader of the Opposition is back to the electoral bribe in the first week of office.

At the same time the Leader of the Opposition says on page 4 that he is willing to tackle the tough decisions. It is a very tough decision to give somebody a tax cut. It is a really tough one. One really has to get one's pecker up, one's guts up, to give someone a tax cut. That is really giving it to them, is it not? But that is what the new leadership is going to offer. It is going to offer these changes; it is going to offer a system which provides more to the rich.

In the same newspaper the day before the cat was really let out of the bag by the former senator and former Secretary to the Treasury, John Stone, who at least honestly had this to say about a consumption tax:

Indeed, it is precisely because the consumption tax-cum-income tax cutting proposals are recognised as inegalitarian that all of them include various associated measures for `compensating' those . . . affected by them.
But listen to this:

The problem then is that the more perfectly you `compensate' those adversely affected . . . the more egalitarian you render the overall outcome-and, hence, the less you succeed in enhancing national savings.
In other words, the more one makes it fair, the less practical and effective it is in lifting savings because one cannot give the biggest tax cuts to the rich.
He goes on to say:

But if we are to raise our national savings by making after tax incomes more unequal we do not need a consumption tax to do so. We could just take, for example, merely take away the tax-free threshold and cut the top rates.

In other words, here is former Senator Stone saying that one does not even need a consumption tax: do not go through the humbug and cant of setting up a badly compensated consumption tax. Just rip the money off low income earners with the tax-free threshold and give it to the rich. He said, `That is basically what you want to do. If you want to compensate everyone you will end up with an egalitarian outcome and it won't work anyway'. In other words, he has blown the gaff on honourable members opposite in what they are really about with their consumption tax proposal-a non-compensated consumption tax to let the poor have it right in the neck and to give the money up the top to flatten the tax system with a two-rate structure.

The Leader of the Opposition says that it is too progressive. That is what the Opposition means by selling out and representing the people of Vaucluse, as if the profit share in gross domestic product is not high enough at an Australian record, as if the corporate rate is not low enough at 39 with full dividend imputation. No, belt the poor and give them an even bigger tax cut by having a two-rate or flat rate system which is paid for and then masquerade that as being tough, as addressing the real issues-giving the rich a tax cut. That is what it is really all about.

Then we have the changed agenda. We now have in the House two former advisers to the former Government, the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), who is sitting here as a frontbencher. Where were they when quota protection went up in the middle 1970s, when quotas were introduced and protection actually rose from the tariff cut of the Labor Government of 1974? Where were they when the two-airline agreement was re-entered before this Government was elected to office? Where were they when all of the work practices on the waterfront were being wound into an extricable set of complementary arrangements? Where were they when the structure of fiscal policy-the current Leader of the Opposition was the principal economic adviser-gave us the largest fiscal imbalance of any country of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development or, as Senator Stone then said in his former capacity as Secretary to the Treasury, the greatest change in fiscal policy, the greatest unwinding of fiscal policy, that had been witnessed?

Where were they when the former Government gave the States unlimited power to borrow and blow the public sector borrowing requirement out of the water? Are they back there shifting their policy ground? No, they are in to try to give a tax cut to the rich. If Senator Button and I or the Prime Minister exchange some words about degrees of difference over tariffs they are in here with a censure motion, when they presided over the sclerosis of Australian manufacturing with McEwenism, when the Liberal Party sunk under the criminal, craven pressure of the Country Party to provide for this industrial swamp, this sewage, this sink they left Australian manufacturing in-this spittoon they produced in Australian manufacturing. Now, when we talk about reducing protection they are up here on a censure.

The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition is like all the ones before him. He has no new ideas and not much to say and cannot say it very well anyway. That is what today's censure means. What it means is that the Opposition is not going back to do its fundamental work. What this tactic today implies is that Opposition members will sit there doing what they have always done-wait until it falls into their laps. They will wait for a damned long time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a shallow defence we have seen from the Government here this afternoon; what a mocking defence, what an arrogant defence the Government has put up. Let me highlight just two of the very cheap shots lodged by the Government in this debate. I remind the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) invoked no less a body than the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship in his defence of Senator Tate. I point out to the Prime Minister that we are not doubting the truth of some of Senator Tate's comments. I am going to read them into the lower House Hansard. I quote from the Senate Hansard. At 4 o'clock on the last sitting Thursday after our Question Time had expired, Senator Tate said:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to my knowledge of the arrest, I have conceded that I knew of the arrest of certain persons back in January 1989. I find it difficult to give only a partial indication of what was in the brief about the arrest, but I will tell the Senate-
honourable members should listen to this-
that I was informed of the names of the two Australians and was informed that two Thais were also arrested.

There it is on the record that the Minister knew over a year and a quarter before he made his appalling mistake, and to use the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship in this context does the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) no good. It does damage to that organisation from which I hope it will recover, and I point out that the Prime Minister would have been better served addressing the fundamentals of that debate.

Let us turn to what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did. He went one worse. He decided, as a cheap debating point, to invoke the flood victims in the course of this censure debate. May I remind the House that the very first question I asked on behalf of the coalition in my new role as Federal Leader of the National Party of Australia was a question about the floods. It was addressed to the Treasurer. May I remind the House that that was over five days ago and I am still waiting for an answer from the Treasurer. We gave the matter our absolute priority. May I also remind the House that there is no one worse than this man in answering questions or answering his ministerial correspondence submitted on behalf of electors. It is about time the Treasurer became less arrogant and more answerable to this Parliament.

I want to say that we will push on with the matter of public importance on floods, because we accept the importance of it and that was a very cheap point for which the Treasurer should apologise. I could go on to mention something about his personal persona following his extraordinary visit to the floods-I am pleased he went; let me be quite clear-but I choose not to, because we are about lifting the standards of this debate and addressing the fundamentals. That is why this censure is vital in terms of its taking priority over business at this time and because of that undoubtedly the Government has a case to answer which so far it has failed to answer both in respect of Senator Tate and in respect of Senator Button.

Indeed, in one sense there can be no more important issue than Cabinet solidarity and what has been torn up here today is the question of Cabinet solidarity. In one sense, there comes a time at which every government reaches a turning point. That time for this Government is today. This is a time the Prime Minister has fundamentally walked away from the need to honour Cabinet solidarity and he will pay a price for it. In some ways the genesis of this goes back to another time. Honourable members will remember the day the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) crept round to the office of the Prime Minister, and what did he say to the Prime Minister, in his third term? He said, `Bob, it is about time you resigned; it is about time you retired'.

What happened after that? None other than the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) was around there saying, `Bob, it is about time you named the date'. There was the headline in the Sydney Morning Herald and elsewhere, `Button says, ``Hawke, name the date'' '-not at the next election-`name the date of your retirement, Prime Minister, during the next parliamentary term'.

What did the Prime Minister do in those circumstances arising? Nothing. He allowed two senior Ministers to come and ask for his resignation, and then he let them off the hook. I think we all know what a Margaret Thatcher would do in that situation. We all know what happened to Heseltine. We all know what a Lange would do in that situation. We all know what happened to Douglas, for example. Let me say very clearly in the House that in fact the Prime Minister failed the test at the time of Senator Button's and Mr Dawkins's intervention, when they asked for his resignation, and the Prime Minister has failed the test on this occasion by failing to take proper action with regard to Senator Button, with regard to the Treasurer and with regard to Senator Tate.
Indeed, it is interesting to examine some of the quotes from no less a person than the Treasurer. He said in 1980, reported again on 18 October 1985, the following:
The first Labor leader I tear down will be the one I replace.

Is that the agenda of the Treasurer today? Is that what he is about? Is that the secret agenda? Did he hold a press conference at 10 o'clock this morning to commence this process of tearing down the Prime Minister? Because there it is-that is his statement. It is an exact quote. On 24 May 1988, the Treasurer said:
I would probably run the place in a different way than Bob runs it. I would run it differently from the way he does.

Another quote, more dynamic to the Caucus, relates to 1981 when he said that if the Caucus dared to pass him over in terms of the Prime Ministership `they will pass me over at their own political folly'. I can see the Left smiling at that. I thank the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and others for these contributions.
The best of the lot comes from 1986 when the Treasurer said:
I could do a lot more outside politics.
I say to the Treasurer, `Away you go. We give you the invitation', because the Deputy Prime Minister has outlasted his distance in politics. It is time that he departed and went outside politics.

The Government is also guilty of another smokescreen with regard to these matters before the House this day. This matter came up during the election campaign. The Left got all excited for a moment and thought it was going to get a deal out of the Right. Do honourable members recall the time when the Minister for Community Services and Health, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), was suddenly elevated in the media, in the middle of the campaign, to the position of being the likely Deputy Prime Minister candidate after the election if the Government won? Faces lit up on the Left. It thought the Right had finally seen a way to be magnanimous, to be fair once and for all and give the Left a fair dinkum go for once. What happened? Within 24 hours of the election that deal had been torn up. The Treasurer came back into the stakes for Deputy Prime Minister and, of course, the poor old Minister for Community Services and Health was sent packing into the sunset.

The Treasurer has a lot to answer for in terms of the economic agony he has created all over Australia. He has a lot to answer for in terms of his conduct in the parliamentary building this morning when he broke every rule of Cabinet solidarity and attacked his most senior colleague, Senator Button. The Prime Minister has even more to answer for in not standing up to the Deputy Prime Minister sitting on his left wing and dismissing him, and, in sorting it out, dismissing Senator Button and, for that matter, Senator Tate.

Let us look at Senator Button and his record over the years. This is not the first time that he has been involved in a series of altercations and spates with the Treasurer. It is not the first time that he has stated his own agenda. Indeed, it is very clear that this is a Cabinet running around in a candy shop in all directions-babes in a candy shop trying to pick up sweets here and there, and heading off in every direction while the country's economy goes down the drain.

Senator Button has breached solidarity on occasions as well. He has certainly got a reputation for speaking honestly about the economy, as did his former ministerial colleague Senator Walsh. Clearly the Prime Minister, in accordance with the censure motion so ably moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), has consistently failed to exercise leadership to avoid these conflicting statements and ensure that he has a united Cabinet-one which adheres to the important Westminster doctrine of Cabinet solidarity. The Prime Minister's failure to do that is a charge before the House at this time. That is what the House is addressing-the failure to discipline Keating, Button and Senator Tate and, indeed, move for their dismissal. That is the case the Prime Minister must now answer.

Let us come back to that third case, the case of Senator Tate. Let me tell the House that my colleagues have adequately shown that Senator Tate is no legal babe in the woods. He is a former dean of law at the University of Tasmania. How can he have the hide to stand up and say that, despite the error, he should be allowed to continue as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs in Australia? How can he honestly do that, when the person was charged and the Minister for Justice decided to assign guilt?

Going one step further, I submit to the House that Senator Tate also has a very deep knowledge of the drug trade between Australia and Thailand, quite legitimately in his role as Minister with responsibilities for the work of the Australian Federal Police, and with the visit that he made in March 1988, at which time he had a series of briefings which I, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), and others had the privilege of having also. The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs met the Secretary-General of the Office of the Narcotics Control Board (ONCB), Major-General Chauvolit Yodmani.

He met a number of other officials. He looked at the ONCB computer project, which Australia is part-funding. It is an important project and a good one. It tracks the movements of people between Australia and Thailand, and elsewhere, and has helped greatly in apprehending the drug traffickers in this part of the world. Every one of those briefings always emphasises the point that the linkage between various drug traffickers is complex; that there is a lot of networking, that there are a number of Mr Bigs and many of the cases are interrelated, and that in those circumstances one should always exercise a great deal of caution.

I put it to the House that Senator Tate has failed on two counts. The first is, as Minister for Justice, assuming guilt when someone is charged. That is unacceptable. Secondly, he knows the whole background of the drug trafficking industry between Australia and Thailand and should therefore have been cautious in his comments. But no, he got so exited that he boiled over. The result is a mistrial in New South Wales resulting in a great deal of additional cost and difficulty, and the failure of the Prime Minister to act in relation to this matter.

There is one other area which is relevant to this whole situation. I could give examples of Minister after Minister having failed to adhere to Cabinet solidarity. The Prime Minister has failed to make them adhere to solidarity. Following today's efforts in being prepared to tolerate a much lower standard of acceptable behaviour, things will get worse and will continue to do so. If Treasurer Keating gets away with this today one can bet that he will be back again saying more things about ministerial colleagues in an unacceptable way. That is why the Prime Minister needed to act today, but in not doing so he has failed the House and the nation.

We also have the prospect of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) not even knowing about the confidentiality of his own departmental files, as they were scattered all over the Canberra Press Gallery by the ex-Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who got busy with a photocopier and copied all the files and then took off into the sunset. Is that the basis on which the Prime Minister allows government to be conducted in this country? The Prime Minister should re-read the censure motion and accept the thrust of it. He has failed his Government and his country in his failure to act against these Ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —We saw the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) in action last week and we have now seen the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer)-and nothing is clearer than that, during this Parliament, changes will be made. Those of us who have sat in this Parliament for a while can imagine what the conduct of this debate would have been like had former leaders, such as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), been presenting the Opposition case. We would not have been savaged by a sort of wet lettuce; we would have been savaged by someone who had at least some understanding of parliamentary processes. None of that has come through at all on the part of those speaking here today.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of aside, let me make something clear about one thing-because I think the Opposition's tactics stand condemned in this regard. What the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said about the normal course of events with matters of public importance is absolutely right. When a censure motion is moved in this place-and this is not simply the tradition of this Government but has been the tradition of previous governments-the matter of public importance goes out the window. That has been the normal course of events, in order to ensure that Government business and other business of the day gets done.

So, putting forward that motion as a blind was done in full knowledge of that. Nothing could be more cynical than trying to exploit in that way the position of those who have been involved in the task of clearing up those floods and the flood victims.

On this occasion we will depart from normal practice and permit the matter of public importance to take place. Because of that we will not compound the chicanery of the other side of the House and use such matters in this way. No doubt, any of those people who bother to follow this debate will know the motives of the Opposition as far as these matters are concerned.

The Opposition has made no case here today. The reason why the motion is before us is that the Leader of the Opposition suffered a buffeting from his colleagues during the course of last week as to how he was handling at that stage the situation of Senator Tate. It is quite evident from the comments that the Leader of the Opposition made on Friday to members of the Press Gallery, or which he allowed his office to make, that he intended not to pursue the Senator Tate matter any further. He accepted that, on balance, as far as the Prime Minister was concerned, the public interest was served more effectively by Senator Tate remaining in his office, this imbroglio being taken out of the newspapers so that trials could proceed without interference by public comment. That was the statesmanlike position he adopted then.

That, of course, was not the position that his colleagues wished him to adopt. What his colleagues wanted him to do was to go for blood. They said to him, `If you fail to do that, you fail a test as Leader of the Opposition'. When this was finally pointed out to the honourable member, after having maintained his silence through a couple of days of potential parliamentary consideration of it, having allowed that to go forward, he said, `Oh, no, I am not in fact a weak Leader of the Opposition. I will in fact say something about this when the time comes. Unlike the sensible position that I adopted in relation to the media, I will turn that on its head and I will ensure, by my comments in this place or those that I permit my colleagues to make, that whatever trial is about to take place would be delayed further'.

That is the position of the Opposition Leader-a position of falling between two stools. There are pressures to make him, in the minds of some of his colleagues, an effective Opposition Leader as opposed to the commonsense that he has when he moves outside the economic area and starts making the judgment of a plain man as to what is a sensible course of action. The commonsense that caused him to decide to do nothing further has been set aside. That is a very great shame for this country but, nevertheless, it is worth noting on this side of the House when we consider how these things are going to be dealt with in the future.

All that needs to be said about Senator Tate is this: Obviously there was an on balance judgment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as to whether or not Senator Tate should remain in office. Two important things had to be weighed in the balance in respect of Senator Tate remaining in office. The first was that Senator Tate's contribution to law enforcement in this country has been substantial since he has held his post. The essence of that, in fact, was ironically outlined by the Leader of the National Party of Australia when he spoke here about the sincerity of Senator Tate's commitment in the drug war and the effectiveness of his administration's efforts, in so far as Federal government can be effective in that regard, to pursue this objective. That was one thing that weighed in the balance and ought to weigh in the balance. Indeed, that matter was not in doubt in respect of those senators who censured him. I am sure that Senator Hill and Senator Macklin, who have worked with the Minister, have absolutely no doubt as to his contribution to the fight against crime.

That weighed in the balance in the favour of Senator Tate. What also weighed in the balance in favour of Senator Tate is that everybody has accepted the veracity of his account, and that is that he was not aware that a trial was proceeding in this country when he made the comments that he did.

The long established practice of ministerial responsibility is that when Ministers are sacked and held accountable for their actions it is because they have knowingly adopted a position in regard to the administration of their portfolio where they have caused the objectives of that portfolio to be seriously upset or where they have corrupted the objectives of that portfolio. That is why Ministers are sacked. They are not sacked for mistakes. They are sacked for intentional actions aimed at destroying an important aspect of government policy with regard to their portfolio or, for that matter, any other, or behaving in regard to their portfolio or any other aspect of government activity in a corrupt fashion.

None of those issues has been raised in the case of Senator Tate. There is an on balance question of trading off whether or not he had seriously harmed his effectiveness as a Minister for Justice so seriously that he could no longer continue in office with whether or not his very substantial contribution and the inadvertence of the comments he made were reason enough to leave him in his position. In that on balance decision, the decision of the Prime Minister fell on the side of maintaining Senator Tate in office. That is all there is to it; it is not a terribly complex matter.

And there the matter ought to be let rest, as Hewson mark 1 on Thursday morning would have it rest. Hewson mark 2, stiffened up by less cool heads on the Opposition front bench, took a totally different view the next day. But we in this House are fortunately not in a position where we have to accommodate this sort of nonsense. We can accept Hewson mark 1 and leave the matter at that as far as this aspect of the censure motion is concerned.

The censure motion goes on to discuss questions related to the Government's handling of economic policy. I ask: With a record like the Opposition's during the course of the last election campaign and with a record like the Opposition's since that campaign, what any right thinking person making a judgment about what this Parliament ought to be considering now is whether or not the Opposition's views on economic matters stack up against those of the Government.

What we have had from the Opposition since the election is total confusion. We have had the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders, who is the Opposition's policy bungee jumper. What the Opposition does with the Deputy Opposition Leader is tie a rope around his ankles. Then it throws him off a cliff. The screaming noise that he makes when he goes down is called `floating a policy'. And the `boing' which is heard when he reaches the bottom and starts bouncing up again is the policy being reconsidered. The snap that we ultimately hear is when the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) or someone else whacks an axe into that rope and he goes all the way down. He will be no loss when he goes down all that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Me or Tuckey?

—If he jumps over after the honourable member, it will be all that much to the better. But I do not think he will. He is not totally suicidal, where the honourable member may be. Indeed, the honourable member's situation is such that if his Party does not adopt a consumption tax as an aspect of policy and people leave their positions, I think he may well be first out the door.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell the honourable member that at the rate the Liberal Party makes policy changes, it will finally arrive at a conclusion on the consumption tax probably at that time honoured point when the general spills of Liberal leadership take place-about 18 months from now. About 18 months from now the Liberal Party will bell the cat on Liberal Party leadership change as the honourable member for O'Connor or somebody else snaps that rope.

The Leader of the Opposition repeated here again today-otherwise I would not have bothered raising it in the course of this debate-the suggestion that somehow or other the action last week of the Treasurer in choosing to use the National Press Club instead of this place to continue to maintain an argument for well established Government policy was somehow reprehensible. I would not have bothered bringing that up again because I thought the Opposition had got off it. But I see that has to be, or evidently is, one of the Opposition's arguments that suggests somehow the inability of this Government to declare and promote a coherent and consistent economic policy.

Sometimes this chamber takes on an Alice in Wonderland atmosphere and no more Alice in Wonderland atmosphere can be conjured up by this. Here we have the Government doing what? It is declaring and promoting a coherent and consistent economic policy. We have announced that policy to the electorate. We announced to the electorate that there would be no consumption tax because we have broadened the tax base. We did so because of the essential inequities in it, because of its impact on inflation and because of all the other things that the Treasurer talked about in the course of his remarks which, while elaborate in detail, were essentially no different from arguments that the Treasurer was presenting before the election-arguments which had sound economic reasons behind them.

Because the Treasurer did that last Wednesday, we are now to be censured here today for not being coherent and consistent. On the other hand, these fellows who wrap themselves in unctuous statements about how they are now giving serious thought to the nature of the economy are capable of marching out to the electorate and saying things about three or four weeks before the election.
On an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program on 12 March 1990 the then Opposition Treasury spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth, said:

And we decided not to have a new broad-based consumption tax in our first term for two main reasons. One, we want to cut Government expenditure and we want the focus to be on cutting Government expenditure. And you don't, you know, to be crude, want to give a new Government a new tax, as was the case in New Zealand where a significant percentage of the revenue from the tax was actually spent by the Government or in the case of the United Kingdom even, Thatcher doubled the VAT in the early eighties and spent a substantial amount of the gain on boosting social security and health expenditure. We want to focus our attention on expenditure restraint. Secondly, there is already a very wide range of consumption taxes.

That does not actually sound to me like an ill-considered statement. It sounds like a statement of a thought out political position that he was attempting to establish in order to give the Liberal Party's policy something it had not had before; that is, coherence and consistency. He made that statement only two months ago. Yet he comes in here and says that we are incoherent and inconsistent because we still agree with that.

What we have presented to us is an Opposition which wants to have a sea change as far as that consumption tax is concerned. It then comes to us and says, `Look, what we want you to do is to break your promises in order to establish your credibility with the electorate'. I thank the Opposition very much for that advice. We are not going to be taking that advice because as far as we can see that is not a sensible way of going about business.

In suggesting that we have to be censured for an inability to declare and promote a coherent and consistent economic policy instead of the Opposition is simply humbug. This whole censure motion is humbug from beginning to end. It is conceived in failure, failure from the point of view of an opposition to handle the issues related to Senator Tate sensibly last week, having chosen to go the high road instead of the low road, to try to backtrack on that and scramble down the incline to find the low road again. That is the first error of judgment as far as the Opposition is concerned about this matter. The second is that it made some sort of broad based attack on the Government about its economic policy when it has no coherent alternative to offer and when it cannot sustain any case against the Government at all of the type that it has indicated in that regard.

The censure motion is a motion that has become much abused in this place over the years. It was once a motion that was treated seriously by governments. It is treated seriously no longer by government, either here or in the Senate. Every one of us on the front bench has had the experience of being censured in the Senate, including me. I found out about it when Senator Hamer told me two weeks after the event. Censure motions are a dime a dozen in the Senate. They are not treated seriously there and if they are going to have a similar background here they will not be treated seriously here either. It is time for us to vote on this motion. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement on the tabling of the Inter-State Commission (ISC) report on road use charges and vehicle registration, which is a national scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased today to release the Inter-State Commission report on road user charging and vehicle registration. As this was its final report, the Commission took the opportunity to broaden its investigation and finalise its work on an earlier efficiency reference. It is therefore a comprehensive analysis of most of the key roads and road transport issues confronting governments today. The Commission's work on transport is highly regarded and I would like to thank the Commissioners and staff for their commitment since 1984 on behalf of the Government. They have made a substantial contribution to improving Australia's transport system. On a personal note I have found their objective assessments of transport issues of great assistance in developing land transport policy.

Its proposals on vehicle registration, cost recovery and road funding are far-reaching and worthy of careful study and thoughtful discussion. I propose therefore, that there be an eight week public comment period to allow for a wide range of contributions, after which the Government will formulate its proposals in consultation with the States and industry. The report raises issues central to the Government's approach to land transport reform in its fourth term of office. This approach focuses on Australia's transport needs:
* a more balanced and integrated system with stronger links between road, rail and sea and a more efficient interface, particularly at the waterfront
* a rail system capable of competing effectively in the freight and passenger markets

* urban public transport systems which meet the legitimate requirements of users, at a time when the road systems in our major cities are becoming increasingly congested and the effects of transport activity on the environment more serious

* reduction of the additional taxation burden imposed by inefficient public enterprises: rail deficits on commercial services have no place in an efficient economy and transport system. Services provided for social reasons should be clearly identified as community service obligations with more stringent controls on operating subsidies

* reduction of the high cost of road trauma by a range of measures including a model shift to more commercial rail systems, improved road networks and vehicles, and a more socially responsible approach from all road users to safety
* a better return on the community's major investments in land transport infrastructure-we cannot afford a second rate return on this investment, or be wasteful in using it.

A number of major studies in recent years have highlighted the deficiencies in our transport systems and the enormous potential benefits from significant reform. The Industry Commission (IC) in its last annual report conservatively estimated a 3 per cent increase in Australian gross domestic product from transport reform. This is roughly equivalent to the annual growth from all sectors of the economy at present. Land transport accounts for most of these benefits, with the Industries Assistance Commission's estimates based on improved road pricing and rail reform alone.

The Business Council of Australia has estimated savings in excess of $500m from more rational road transport arrangements such as higher mass limits, B-Doubles operating nationally, deregulation of commodity transport and improved road transport administration. While there is room for debate about some of the claims made in these studies there is little doubt that many of their criticisms are justified. Australia is not in a position to ignore this potential for economic growth, particularly when the means of achieving it will also have environmental benefits and significantly reduce pressure on public budgets.

Since 1983 the Hawke Government has changed our land transport system significantly: we have undertaken a comprehensive examination of the road transport industry, and in 1987 became directly involved through the Federal interstate registration scheme. This has provided a means for increasing uniformity of regulations, increasing productivity and addressing the most serious charging anomalies; our new road funding arrangements have made progress in requiring greater efficiency in the management of our road networks and in targeting our limited investment to roads of economic significance; and the federally owned railway, Australian National, has vastly improved its performance on commercial traffics and now records a surplus on mainland commercial freight operations. We have also increased pressure on the States to follow this lead with their own systems through the Grants Commission. More change is now required to meet the increasing demands on our transport system. Greater and continuing commitment to change is required from all levels of government and the transport industry.

The guiding objectives for the Federal Government can be simply described as promoting development of an integrated, efficient and coordinated land transport system which reflects national economic and social priorities; pursues safe and efficient operations and practices responsive to user requirements, with each mode undertaking the transport tasks to which it is best suited; and is equipped to meet the rapid growth envisaged for the 1990s and beyond.

In continuing to pursue these objectives we will be observing the following principles: national funds will be targeted to projects with a high economic and social benefit; increased competition within and between transport modes-the primary role for governments is to provide the environment in which this competition can take place; freight and passenger transport regulation should be limited to that required to meet legitimate community expectations, particularly in relation to safety; more economic pricing arrangements for publicly provided road and rail infrastructure are required, with greater involvement by the private sector in the provision of that infrastructure, and in the operations of our rail systems; the States need to be more responsive to economic, market and commercial imperatives in their investment decisions; and our initial approach will be to seek a cooperative basis for reform with the States, but we will make strategic use of Federal powers, which are considerable, where this process does not yield a satisfactory rate or level of change.

The Federal Government recognises that land transport reform is a process which needs to be accelerated. The opportunities presented by rapid growth will be grasped only if fundamental changes are made over the next few years. On this basis we are planning a series of reforms in 1990-91 as part of a comprehensive package for land transport.

The Commission's report will be of great assistance in this regard. It has identified the key areas to be addressed in road transport and in the provision and management of our road system. The ISC report suggests that roads and road transport are important areas for micro-economic reform and the existing mechanisms for achieving these reforms have not succeeded in producing the necessary changes fast enough; greater efficiency and public accountability is required from our road authorities; there is an urgent need for a more national approach to road transport; existing road user charging arrangements are neither efficient nor equitable; there are large differences between individual State road user charges, encouraging operators to `shop around', penalising those States attempting to develop responsible road user charges; and there are many opportunities for increased productivity through more innovative use of our road system.

Over the next two months I will be consulting with my State colleagues, road users and the road transport industry on the ISC proposals for resolving these problems. I will also be talking to transport unions and authorities about solutions to the deficiencies in our land transport system generally. At this stage I envisage a meeting with my State colleagues in the Australian Transport Advisory Council in August to consider the results of these discussions.

I anticipate a positive approach from all parties to the reforms necessary for land transport to meet the great demands that will be placed upon it in the 1990s. The progress in recent years has established the framework in which the necessary reforms can be implemented. But I think we all agree that the pace of change now needs to be greatly increased.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to be able to respond to the Government's first major report this term addressing what is, after all, a fundamental area, namely, micro-economic reform. I thank the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) for his cooperation in allowing me to see the report prior to its being tabled although, judging by the reports appearing in the press in the last couple of weeks, it seems that I was not the first to get a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Inter-State Commission report that has been tabled this afternoon has had a long and tortured history. Indeed, it reflects the long and tortured history that the Government's micro-economic reform has had to date. It would be salient for me to run through the last seven years in the lead-up to the tabling of this report. In fact, this is the latest-and regrettably the last-effort from the Inter-State Commission.

During the February 1983 election the Australian Labor Party promised to conduct a national inquiry into the road freight industry in consultation with State and Territory governments and industry organisations. The May National Road Freight Industry Inquiry reported in September 1984. Following that, legislation was pledged in March 1985-another six months later-to establish Federal registration and licensing of vehicles and to set up the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC). That was more than two years after the first promise in February 1983. Through the Australian Transport Advisory Council, the Government said it would take up with the States the question of uniformity of driver licensing, uniformity of speed limits, uniformity of policies to improve rail cost recovery and uniformity of extension of consumer protection to trucking. All of that was promised some years ago. To date very little has happened.

In September 1985, the Interstate Road Transport Bill came into the Parliament but its effects were delayed until January 1987. We are now four years down the track. In the meantime, in April 1986 the Inter-State Commission brought in a report on cost recovery for registration charges. Following that report, four years ago, there was another report in October 1987, again looking at interstate road and registration charges. That second report was followed by the July 1988 truck blockade. Again, we had another deferral of the interstate charges until January this year.

The Minister has now tabled what is effectively the third report of the Inter-State Commission, which we are looking at today. In 1986 the first report was tabled; the third one has now been tabled. The point I make is that that is an awfully long time to keep tabling reports with very little action. The report suggests that it is not intended that anything be implemented until 1 July 1992. That would be almost 10 years since that first election promise in 1983 to conduct an inquiry and presumably to act. When we talk about speed of micro-economic reform, I think nearly 10 years is far from satisfactory and far from impressive.

The Minister's five-page speech this afternoon had some difficulty in scratching together what the real achievements of the Government have been over the last seven years, rather than the reports that have been produced. If we look at the actual achievements, it certainly has undertaken a comprehensive examination of the road transport industry. In fact, there has been several of these examinations. The Government talks about its new road funding arrangements. During the last election campaign it was pretty obvious from the reaction out amongst the public that the level of road funding has been far from adequate over the last few years, and there is a strong push amongst road users to see that level of funding increased.

The Minister mentioned improving the efficiency of Australian National Railways, and I certainly support that view. I think it is most commendable. The fact is that all the Government had to do, and in fact all the Government really did do, was to pick up a piece of lapsed legislation that the Fraser Government had introduced in 1982, resubmit it to the Parliament-the Minister is smirking; he knows it is true-and push it through. Of course, it was very good legislation because it was prepared before the Government even had to think about it. So after seven years one has to say that the Government's record of reform is really seven years of mostly lost opportunity. It is a real disappointment.

The Minister alluded in his speech, and we are all familiar with it, to the joint submission put forward by the Industry Commission and the Business Council of Australia, which mentioned that the transport industry could make very significant increases in national output.
