DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to utilise all the resources at its disposal to assist the recent victims of floods in Eastern Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I wish to thank the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for accepting this matter of public importance following the censure debate early this afternoon. I believe that it indicates the spirit that exists on both sides of the House in relation to the floods, and that is the spirit in which I have put forward this debate today on behalf of the Opposition parties. Uncommonly for matters of public importance, this matter of public importance does not criticise the Government, whether it is the Federal Government or one or all of the three State governments which are involved with the great flood problems we have in the three eastern States and which are continuing as the floods move down the Darling system.

SPEECH.PARA: These floods, that occurred in late April and, as I said, that are continuing in certain areas, have been very significant both in respect of the area covered and of the degree of devastation. One can argue whether they are the greatest floods this country has had, but whether they are or are not I do not think it matters. They are very significant. They cover an area of over one million square kilometres, or greater than the combined area of Britain, France and Germany. They have been particularly devastating in three widely separated geographic areas: central Queensland, north-western New South Wales and East Gippsland. Fortunately, very few people lost their lives. I extend the sympathy of everyone here to the families of those who are grieving. I also commend the expertise that meant that so few did lose their lives.

The economic loss from these floods is still mounting. According to my calculation, at the moment it could be approaching about $200m. At least half a million sheep have been lost, with more to be lost. My colleague the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) will go into that in more detail. About 20,000 head of cattle have been lost, as has about $50m of the very important cotton crop in New South Wales alone. But the greatest costs coming up are the infrastructure costs: the roads, the railways, the hospitals, the levy banks and so forth.

Once again on behalf of everyone here I congratulate the Defence Force personnel, the police, the State Emergency Service people in each of the three States and the hordes of volunteers of all types who so readily assisted and who still are assisting. For example, at present in Nyngan volunteers from the Bush Fire Brigade have just had a rotation as they assist with the hosing down and cleaning out of houses, et cetera. Then there are the other types of volunteers, those in the Dubbo area and other relief centre areas who have been looking after the displaced families.

I also commend the courage of those isolated farm families. Flying over some of those areas a couple of weeks ago with the honourable member for Parkes and Senator Brownhill from New South Wales I saw these homesteads with the levy banks surrounded by a massive inland sea. These people have had to show tremendous courage to maintain not only their livelihoods but also their sanity. I also commend the residents of those particularly hard-hit communities such as Charleville, Nyngan, Boisdale and of the other smaller communities which have been either partly or wholly evacuated.

When one considers the flood situation, immediately one is reminded of the short period in our recorded history of rainfall records and records of river heights and flood heights. Nyngan, in particular, is a stark reminder of this and of the perverse nature of our continent. At the same time we have drought areas still declared elsewhere in Australia. We have already had bushfires and earthquakes earlier this year.

Now, in the aftermath of the floods, with residents returning to those communities, questions need to be asked in a positive way to ensure that assistance is being maximised and that we learn for the future, whatever government is in power at the Federal or State levels. For example, how appropriate are the Federal-State arrangements? Are each of the three States involved maximising the different forms of assistance? Have they communicated to the affected people what those people are entitled to? I will return to this later.

How good are the State Emergency Service operations in each of the States? I know that is largely a matter for the States but it does have Federal ramifications because it is the Federal Government that decides whether or not to call in the defence forces. It has other ramifications with regard to the Federal-State financial cost sharing arrangements, depending on what decisions are made and the payment of Federal benefits, depending on what decisions are made.

Thirdly, how good is our early warning system for floods, our river gauging, our rain intensity arrangements? Are those gauging systems still adequate? Should they be modern, remote accessed radio controlled type gauges, so that if a river is in flood somebody can learn that it is, and that the Nyngans, the Charlevilles or whatever can be given better and more accurate warning as to what the level and intensity of the flood will be? That is both a Federal and a State responsibility.

How effective is the equipment for disaster relief assistance? One thinks at a Federal level in relation to aircraft. Once again I commend the Defence Force personnel who have been operating those aircraft now for some weeks and who still are, in the fodder drops as the floods move down the Darling. They have had the role, for example, of evacuating and assisting with two communities. We have the Caribou and the Hercules for fodder drops and for flying in supplies to isolated areas. How cost-effective are they? The reports coming through to me are that the Hercules has been a far more cost-effective type of aircraft than the Caribou, but obviously the Caribou can operate in some situations where the Hercules cannot. The comment that keeps coming back is that, as opposed to earlier situations when the Chinook heavy lift helicopter was available, it is sorely missed for short range evacuation purposes, for assistance with fighter drops or for assistance with livestock in short range situations. I was encouraged by the response of Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, in the Senate on Thursday to a question from Senator Bjelke-Petersen in relation to consideration by the Government of retaining some Chinook helicopters.

Some communities were completely devastated: Charleville, Nyngan and one or two smaller communities. Are there special needs for those communities, to make sure through, perhaps, additional forms of assistance that they have a viable future? They are facing a very grim situation, either of a personal business nature or just in regard to their future as a community generally. We recognise that they are smaller than Darwin or Newcastle but they should not be ignored, as they have to emerge again from that devastation.

A specific Federal issue put to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last week-as was indicated in the debate earlier this afternoon, we are still awaiting a reply-concerns the question of provisional tax, which is all-important for those farmers who have already paid their tax on the basis of what was going to be a considerably higher income than what is now the case. It is very important to enable a rebate of that provisional tax already paid in line with their projected income.

Under the Federal-State arrangements the States negotiate with the Commonwealth within overall parameters. When one looks, for example, at the personal assistance levels, there is quite a difference between the three States in how they are operating at the present time, in the level of that assistance, how much of it is means tested and how much is not means tested. This obviously is mainly a responsibility for the State to sort out. But if, for example, one were a Victorian in East Gippsland, and one's house was submerged or subjected to severe flooding, in theory at least one is entitled to receive up to about $11,000 of assistance in one way or another, without a means test. But a person similarly affected in New South Wales or Queensland is only allowed up to $3,000 before a means test. There is a dramatic difference there and I believe those things need to be highlighted. Also we need to ask whether or not those limits are adequate, taking into account the cost of building and so forth these days, and there are a number of other areas where there are quite significant differences between the States.

Honourable members have to acknowledge that with housing in flood-prone areas it is not easy to obtain flood insurance, in the sense that ordinary insurance does not cover floods. In other words, if the flood comes from above with heavy rain on one's place, one is covered, but if the water comes through the fence because of a flood from the river, one is not covered. People living in flood-prone areas have to pay very much heavier premiums for cover and it is therefore a difficult decision to make.

With businesses there is an $80,000 loan available at six per cent, although once again in two States it does appear possible to obtain more than the $80,000. Again one asks why the differences between the States? But the real problem about the loans for all these businesses-whether they are in the towns or in the farms-is that generally they are already heavily indebted and are paying 20 per cent interest. Just to offer them another loan on which more interest is payable is not necessarily going to be a great help to them, having in mind their ability to repay it, considering their circumstances, and particularly if that loan is available to them only as a last resort. It would seem to me that a loan at 6 per cent would allow someone at least to reduce part of his existing loan on which he is paying 20 per cent and that should be allowed because it would provide some assistance for a business that does not have very bright prospects in the immediate future.

The next point is payment of welfare. I do want to commend the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) for the action he took to assist people in the Charleville area. We have been advised that 700 people in that area are now receiving special benefit, which of course is the form of benefit when other forms of benefit do not really apply and this was the way to get some cash into the hands of affected ordinary people. But while 700 people at Charleville receive special benefit, only 200 at Nyngan have, and I think we have to ask why. While commending the honourable member for Bowman-and I do not back off from that at all because he did, as I understand it, initiate some quick action by the departmental people-I ask: Was there some breakdown within the Department either in the urgency of getting departmental people to the Nyngan area-meaning Dubbo where the people had moved to-or in the criteria for eligibility for that special benefit? That is another matter that has to be addressed.

The major cost eventually will be for infrastructure and that comes into the Federal-State arrangements. We are looking not just at roads, railways, hospitals and libraries but at levee banks. I am told that Nyngan alone will need about 10 kilometres of rebuilt levee banks. Probably 50 kilometres might be a reasonable guesstimate at the moment of rebuilding and strengthening levee banks all round. There has to be a clear statement that that rebuilding is included in the Federal-State arrangements, and as we are rapidly coming to 1 July and most of the bills for the floods will come in after that date, the financial year will commence again for the base amount of $33m for New South Wales, $24m for Victoria and $16m for Queensland. The Federal Government, under the present arrangements, may not be required to bear the fair burden that comes with these major natural disasters. Is that the most appropriate cost distribution, between the Federal and State governments with the financial year arrangements that we have at the moment?

I conclude with a couple of points concerning farming people. I have mentioned provisional tax and the need for an answer from the Treasurer, both on extending the time for those who have not paid and allowing a rebate to those who have. Another difference between the States is that one State allows up to $1,800 a mile to assist with the rebuilding of boundary fencing, but the other States do not. I think that has to be addressed. Another matter is household support, which does not come through the Department of Social Security but is the only way in which a farmer can get any sort of cash flow assistance when he has no income coming in. It is Federal money but it is done through the State rural adjustment arrangements. There needs to be a sympathetic consideration and implementation of household support, directed down from the Commonwealth, to ensure that those farmers do get some carry-on assistance. We should not forget the flood situation just because the floods have moved downstream. We need to continue to check in the aftermath the adequacy of those arrangements and if they prove not to be adequate we need to do something about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to take part in a debate in which, by and large, the sentiments on both side of the House are as one. It is a pleasure to join with the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) in conveying the sympathy, not just of members on his side of the House but of members on the Government side of the House as well, to those who have suffered distress in the tragic floods that have afflicted Queensland, New South Wales and areas of Victoria and also to echo the honourable member's admiration for the courage that people have displayed. This was displayed not just as they sought to fight the floods-I have in mind the pictures of people in Nyngan as they worked to build up the levees, only to be finally heartbreakingly defeated-but their courage as they have tried to rebuild in the wake of the floods.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an extraordinary country we live in-a country of great extremes. In my State-and I see the new honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) sitting opposite on the front bench-we face also the scourge of bushfires, another great natural disaster that we have to deal with in this country, particularly in South Australia and Victoria. I think we have come to expect from those men and women for whom I have particular responsibility in this Government-namely, the Australian Defence Force-that they respond quickly, efficiently and with a minimum of fuss, often in a way that is unsung. This is common ground. I particularly welcome the remarks that the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Lloyd) has made about the work that was done by the Australian Defence Force in this most recent set of disasters. This time has been no exception to their record.

I might say-perhaps in parenthesis-that they do attract occasionally some ill-informed minority criticism for their efforts and I will deal with that in a moment, but that is by and large very much a minority. Most people, I know, expect the armed forces to react in that way; they expect volunteers and emergency bodies to respond quickly and efficiently and it is only in a minor way that they are criticised.

I want to spend some time outlining what assistance is given by the Commonwealth in natural disasters of this kind. I am aware that the Deputy Leader spent some time on perhaps the deficiencies of responses either by State governments or in coordination arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth, and I will deal with that a little later after I have spoken about the assistance that the Commonwealth itself provides.

The first is perhaps the most visible form of assistance; namely, the physical assistance that is provided by the Australian Defence Force and I will get on in a moment to the financial assistance which is provided under the natural disaster relief arrangements or NDRA. Neither of those forms of assistance is new. They have been developed over a considerable period of time. They have been, I think, generally regarded as effective under this Government and previous governments. Under this Government, in the case of the most recent disasters, those arrangements were activated very rapidly. Assistance began on 13 April, quite soon after the scope of the disaster became clear, with airlifts of supplies and the dropping of fodder by Caribou and Hercules aircraft.

The disaster plan, Emperor, was, in fact, activated on 21 April with the deployment of armed forces, and that phase lasted until 1 May. That kind of disaster assistance, quite properly, is given only in response to direct requests from State governments which are in the best position, at that point, to assess the scope of the disaster.

In the course of Operation Emperor the Australian Defence Force (ADF) met all the requests which were made by State governments with one exception, and that was a request for additional manpower in Nyngan. That request was cancelled about an hour after it was made with the greatly changed circumstances which followed the breaching of the levy banks. The decision was made to evacuate Nyngan and that was done, basically, by ADF helicopters. At the height of the relief operation there were approximately 500 armed forces personnel and 39 aircraft being deployed, with additional manpower and equipment, which was not in fact needed, on standby.

I will run through the major tasks which were undertaken by the defence forces. Firstly, the evacuation of Charleville and Nyngan by helicopters. Secondly, the establishment of a tent city-temporary tent accommodation-for the 2,000 evacuees at Charleville. That tent city was supported by an infantry company of 135 personnel, plus catering and supply staff. Thirdly, medical facilities were provided at Charleville pending getting the hospital back into commission.

The fourth major task, was the transport of food, fuel, relief personnel and supplies to isolated towns and individual homesteads by aircraft, helicopters and trucks. Fifthly, aerial fodder dropping-particularly in the Narromine, Walgett and St George areas-was carried out by Caribou and Hercules aircraft. Sixthly-and this group is still there, as I will refer to in a moment-an army engineer group of 130 men, 60 trucks and various plant and equipment is engaged on reconstruction work in the Jericho Shire, Queensland. Fodder dropping in south Queensland is continuing as the floods gradually move south. Other activities include food supplies flights to Bourke, Cobar and Brewarrina and helicopter relief operations at Enngonia in New South Wales and Charleville in Queensland-taking people off roofs, and so forth. These mopping up tasks are expected to continue until 11 May.

Pretty well all those activities have now been wound up in Queensland and have been taken over by the civil power. The helicopters have been replaced by civil charter aircraft, the tent city is no longer there and various stores have been returned to Brisbane.

In New South Wales my understanding is that fodder dropping is expected to continue for at least another three or four days-as of Friday, a Caribou and a Hercules were still engaged on that activity. In Nyngan there is a family assistance centre which has been set up by the Australian Defence Force in conjunction with the New South Wales Government. That is being staffed by eight members of the armed forces and a further 10 members are distributing food supplies and bedding by truck. Rear Admiral Sinclair has requested some transport facilities which have been made available. The Army Malaria Research Unit is advising on mosquito control. That is the picture given by the ADF.
I was very pleased to see that Senator Newman moved a motion which was carried unanimously in the Senate the other day which stated:
That the Senate-
(a) recognises the enormous assistance which has been given to our flood stricken victims by Australian Defence Force personnel;

(b) recognises that whenever disaster strikes in our country in peacetime or in war, the Australian Defence Force is willing ready and able to swing into action regardless of personal inconvenience or danger; and
(c) expresses its gratitude to the men and women of the Australian Defence Force for their continuing selfless contribution to their fellow Australians.
I am sure that would command the same unanimous support in this House as it did in the other place.

Finally, on the ADF, man does not live by bread alone. Just last week I was pleased to authorise the use of another Caribou aircraft to fly around to various towns in Queensland including Alpha, Charleville and Blackall. In this plane was Col Joye and the Joye Boys. The Deputy Leader of the National Party and I are probably the only people in this House old enough to remember them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me check that.

—I am joking. Those of us who remember the work that Col Joye did in Vietnam in entertaining our troops will recognise that this is a similar operation. I was very pleased that he was able to do that, and I thank him and his group, including Julia Daniels, for the excellent work they are doing in Operation Cheer-up.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go on to other matters the emphasis now, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party has rightly pointed out, is on financial assistance provided under the NDRA. That form of relief is, constitutionally, primarily the responsibility of the States but the Commonwealth has always recognised that it will have a role when the States do not have the resources to deal with that kind of major disaster.

Before I speak further about those arrangements the Deputy Leader of the National Party drew attention to a number of possible deficiencies; State responses to the disasters; coordination arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States; and databases-for example, we have not been collecting flood river data for long enough, as Nyngan showed, to make that a reliable guide. Rainfall records are also deficient. He mentioned that we need to look again at the appropriateness of the equipment which was used, in particular, whether the Chinook helicopters would have been more useful. My impression and understanding is that the ADF met the tasks assigned to it very well with the existing equipment. The Black Hawke helicopters are a very adaptable aircraft. They did everything that was required of them.

As the Deputy Leader of the National Party mentioned, it is the case that the Government has agreed to look again at the possible refurbishment of a small number of Chinooks. In agreeing to that, of course, the Government has to bear in mind that the ADF is there basically for the defence of the country. While dual use of this kind is useful and without pre-empting the results of that review it has to be the case that that will always be the prime reason why an item of equipment is retained in the ADF inventory.
The question of differences between States is largely a matter which will have to be sorted out by the States, but if there is a lesson to be learnt, obviously it is a good thing.

Under the NDRA arrangements, the Commonwealth reimburses at least 50 per cent of State outlays on eligible measures for the relief of personal hardship and distress. In respect of other eligible relief and restoration measures, the Commonwealth provides financial assistance when a State's total outlays on those measures in any financial year exceeds its assessed financial capacity, as represented by an annual base amount. That base amount has been set at 0.225 per cent of State annual general government revenue and grants dating from two years earlier, which was the latest available data at the time. Commonwealth assistance is on a donor for donor basis in respect of outlays by a State above its base amount for amounts up to 75 per cent above the base amount and $3 Commonwealth to $1 State thereafter.

In Queensland the threshold is $15.78m, and it will be well above that largely because of earlier expenditure on Cyclone Ivu. Therefore, Queensland will get 3:1. In New South Wales the threshold is $32.75m. That State has spent $38.5m to date. In Victoria the threshold is $23.9m and my guess is that it will not, in fact, spend that.

The relief measures which have been funded under those guidelines have included grants for relief of personal hardship and distress, such as the provision of emergency food, clothing and accommodation; concessional loans to farmers and operators of small businesses and concessional loans to needy persons or voluntary non-profit bodies whose assets have been significantly damaged and have no reasonable access to commercial finance-the same applies to the previous category. There are also grants for the restoration of essential public assets owned by eligible public undertakings.

In relation to a number of other measures briefly referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the Government has taken steps to ensure that the tax and social security systems make proper allowance for the difficulties faced by individuals. Legislation is being enacted, for example, to double the initial payment of unemployment benefits to victims of disasters, and there are a number of other measures.

Finally, I want to echo briefly the remarks that were made about the representation in this place and in other parliaments of people in these stricken areas. The Deputy Leader referred to a number of those. I know personally that members of this House from both sides have done their damnedest to serve their constituents in their hour of need. I know that one of them, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), will be speaking later in this debate. I appreciate the spirit in which this matter has been raised. I hope that I have been able to enlighten the House with the Government's response to it.

—As the honourable member for Macquarie says, this will never be forgotten. Also, we will never forget the footage shown of the levee bank breaking and the youth of the town, who grew into adults, throwing themselves in front of the water trying in vain to stop it.

The level of loans in New South Wales has been lifted from $25,000, I think it was, up to $80,000, at 6 per cent, but I think more is needed. The State Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Gerry Peacocke, will be pressing for this. If the New South Wales State Government agrees to it, I hope the Commonwealth will come to the party under the Commonwealth-State agreements.

The situation with people's homes is horrific, and there are 1,100 or 1,200 homes in Nyngan. In one home two railway sleepers went straight through the front door with the water that came in. Sewage has been surcharging through the systems. Yesterday I went into a pensioner's home, and it was devastating. I was told that this pensioner had been into her house once since the flood. She threw up her hands and broke down. She walked out and has not been back since. I ask the Government to have compassion over what will happen to these pensioners' homes. There are 270 pensioners in Nyngan over 70 years of age and many of their houses will have to be demolished. If a recommendation is put forward by Rear-Admiral Peter Sinclair that, for example, a retirement village complex has to be set up, I hope that the Government will see its way clear to look at that favourably.

To mention just one item in that house: the family piano, an heirloom that had been there for generations, had floated across the room and was face downwards on the floor. It was stood up when I went there yesterday. I tried to depress one of the ivory keys with my finger, but it was jammed. The keys were turned up and the veneer had peeled off everywhere. I lifted up the back to look inside and it was rusted up. It would now not get 10c at auction. It is worthless. That is the type of thing that people have lost.

There is no such thing, of course, as flood insurance. I believe that we have to have another look at a natural disaster insurance scheme. Nyngan is a low income town, but for the average home one would need $10,000 to replace just the basics, like stoves, television sets and modern furniture. Water causes modern furniture to come apart, because it is only stuck together with glue and staples-unlike antique furniture. That figure of $10,000 does not include things like carpets, gyprock walls, curtains and floorboards. The owners of one of the houses I looked at yesterday had only just finished painting the interior of the house-so that was $6,000 totally down the drain. I would ask the Government-and I have written to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about this-to consider waiving the sales tax on the household items that Nyngan people will have to purchase to refurnish their homes. I am thinking of simple things like beds and mattresses. I believe that there is a 30 per cent sales tax on television sets-hardly a luxury item in an isolated town where there is not as much entertainment as there is in a city.

My colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party has mentioned the problems in relation to special benefits and household support. I would ask the Government to look at that, too. I would also ask the Government to look at the need for proper flood gauges, automatic telemark flood gauges which are accurate and quick. Some sort of investigation needs to be done as to why personal gauge reader warnings were not heeded more than they were.

We must look at spending more on levee banks. The 10-kilometre levee bank at Nyngan has to be raised by another two metres, I believe-just for peace of mind, to get people to go back and live there again. Roads and bridges have sustained devastating damage and a lot of funding will be needed. We must not forget the farming community, either. I spoke to a fellow from Wanaaring a couple of days ago, Doug Bambrick. Wanaaring is a couple of hundred kilometres west of Bourke. This fellow has a 110,000 acre property and 12,000 sheep. He has been marooned for a month. He has been without mail for all that time. We get six mail deliveries here a day but he has not had mail for a month. He can only get around to the parts of the property near his house.

He has seen 2,000 of his sheep. He does not know where the other 10,000 are or whether they are alive or dead, because he cannot get a helicopter in to find that out. I asked him when he expected to get out again and he said, `With a bit of luck, about September'. He has no income. He has wool shorn from sheep in February and March sitting in the shed. He will not be able to sell that wool until later this year, and he will have to pay at least another 12 per cent in wool tax.

I would ask the Government to consider when we are discussing wool legislation on Thursday waiving the wool tax on what would have normally been sold as this year's clip. Just that item alone runs into several thousand dollars. That is the sort of thing that isolated graziers-the people who have opened up this country and who contribute hundreds of thousands of dollars to our export income-are putting up with. Their children are not able to be educated. They cannot get out. There is no entertainment. All they have is a phone, a radio set and television. The more that we can do to help them the better.

The honourable member for Murray mentioned Chinook helicopters. I believe there is a need to have at least three or four such helicopters. We need to have some sort of vertical heavy lift capacity in this country. We cannot even take a 150 millimetre howitzer into the field these days. Chinook helicopters would have been very useful in the flood areas. If America is going to revamp 500 of these helicopters, surely we can afford to do the same with 11 of them in this country.

In conclusion, these floods have caused very serious problems. In many ways, some of the victims are the forgotten people of Australia. They live in isolated and harsh conditions to earn money for this country. They have pulled their weight in the past. I hope that in their hour of need, we will not forget them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the ongoing interest and real personal concern that has been expressed by members of the Opposition in the plight of the hundreds of Australian families who have been devastated because of the recent floods that have affected western Queensland and New South Wales. I concur with the general thrust of the proposition that has been put forward by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), when he says that there is a need for the Government to utilise all of the resources at its disposal to assist the recent victims of floods in eastern Australia. But as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) pointed out, that is exactly what the Federal Government-and I will add to that, the State governments in Queensland and New South Wales-have done in recent weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to place on record my admiration of and support for the actions of so many people, including representatives from this House of Parliament. The honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) was one of the first on the scene in Queensland. I would like to commend those political, administrative and defence officials who were also on the scene. I also commend the Premier of Queensland, Wayne Goss, for his personal intervention, the Department of Social Security representatives who moved to the flood areas in Queensland to ensure that special benefits were available and Army personnel. These people provided the immediate assistance that was necessary, the counselling service that was needed, the financial help that was urgently required and the physical support, be it getting people out of their homes and building tent cities. They all deserve commendation.

This support was highlighted during the visit by the Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he inspected areas of central and far western Queensland. I think everyone realises that everyone tried to do his bit. As I have said, assistance was provided not only at the Federal level but also at the State level. I again place on record my appreciation commendation of Terry Mackenroth, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services in Queensland, for the way he approached the issue. He did not just go out there but he stayed there. He camped with the people. He became involved with and suffered with the people. I think it is important that members of parliament do that.

I am pleased that the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) was able to tell the House of the experiences he has just had. All Australians need to know of the suffering that has taken place. At the same time we need to record our appreciation of the role played by the State emergency services, the local authorities, the police, the departmental officials, the ambulance and the other support groups such as the fire brigades. We also need to recognise the role played by the health department, the Department of Primary Industries, the education department, the Department of Social Security, the Commonwealth Employment Service, the Department of Family Services and so on. These are but some of the people who took action and did their bit. I would suggest that the action by these concerned people is beyond criticism. I am most pleased that the Opposition did not come forward with this matter of public importance today to try to criticise and have a crack at government. I am pleased with the thrust of the debate.

There was certainly a commitment and dedication to duty. I believe that this is matched only by the generosity of tens of thousands of Australians who were not directly affected but who put their hands into their pockets to ensure that money has been forthcoming. I cite a couple of quick examples. Today I received a cheque for $27,655 to the appeal that I am running in central Queensland from the miners at Blair Athol coal. The combined mining unions got together and raised $27,655. Their cheque, which arrived in my office at Rockhampton today, will be used to provide white goods-stoves and refrigerators and washing machines-for the people in Alpha, Jericho and other areas in central Queensland.

A concert held in Emerald last Friday week was assisted by Mickey Calvert and James Dean from 4HI in cooperation with Alan Douglas, Laurie Esmond, Ric McGuire and many other people as well as all the service clubs, the banks and Sunstate Airlines. All sorts of people and organisations, including commercial interests, contributed. The breweries came good with pallets of grog. An amount of over $30,000 was raised in four hours thanks to the presence of the Little River Band, the Roccatoos and Antix, a well known local group. But the people came there to support the cause. I think we need to place on record the Parliament's support for and appreciation of what these people have done.

The money is pouring in. Today I spoke to Clem Jones who heads the Queensland task force for the Premier. He tells me that already $4m has arrived in the Queensland voluntary coffers just to support Queensland victims and that this amount is expected to rise to $5m. We can add to that the $27.6m already spent by the Queensland Government. As a Commonwealth Government, we are directly spending $12m as we match the money above the 0.225 per cent of revenue that the States must first contribute. As the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has pointed out, we are now going to contribute $3 for every $1 contributed by the State of Queensland. This money will help those people in distress.

It is not just a matter of what is going to be provided. It is also a matter of the immediate financial assistance and the personal help that has been given. Thanks to the arrangement that we have with the States, food, clothing, shelter and emergency services have been provided. I believe that Australia can hold its head very high in the way in which this disaster has been handled. It is a unique disaster. The Deputy Leader of the National Party pointed out the magnitude of the problem. It was described to me that it was as big as a flood covering half of Europe and that its cost is something like a quarter of a billion dollars. We cannot conjure up in our minds the extent of the damage.

As Clem Jones said, it is unparalleled. Unlike the flood that took place in Brisbane, the people could not just shift out of their neighbourhood and stay with neighbours. These people had nowhere to go. Clem Jones said that when he walked into the towns there were no radios, telephones, railways, buses or taxis. There was nothing. The people had to live in tent cities, thanks to the Army and the support made available by this Government.

These incredible problems continue. Clem Jones has been trying to get underlay for 1,300 homes so that floor covering could be put down. He has already bought out all the vinyl in Mackay, Emerald and Rockhampton. He has been trying to buy floor coverings from other cities. The aim has been to try and buy things locally. Just last week he distributed $300,000 in vouchers-$100 per adult and $20 per child. This money has been made available by way of vouchers so that it can be spent locally. Another $300,000 to $400,000 is being spent today. By the end of the week $1.2m will have been made available by way of vouchers.
On top of this, $1,000 per household in Queensland will be given in voucher form so that householders can go along and buy the things that they need, be it beds, furniture or whatever.

The generosity is unprecedented. When I made a public appeal for beds, one of the hospitals rang up and said, `We have 16-they are on their way'. When I made an appeal for stoves, one of the mining companies said, `We have five stoves. We are delivering them personally'.

Today I spoke to Bob Mellis, the Shire Clerk in Alpha, and said, `Bob, what about the goods we were going to send in respect of furniture?' He said, `Three wagon loads have just arrived. I do not even know what is in them. Do not send any more before we have an inventory'. Peter Clark, the local police officer, is of the same attitude. People have been generous beyond all belief. It is unbelievable what they have done.

In the last few moments that I have in this debate I want to take up some points that have been raised by honourable members. I believe that the generosity should not stop there. A sympathetic approach must be taken by the Australian Taxation Office. Business and individuals have lost all of their documents. They have lost everything. It is not just a matter of their losing personal effects; they have lost everything in terms of being able to demonstrate their income over the last year.

There has been an unbelievable loss for business. That business loss shall flow not just to those in the affected area but to others in the non-affected areas. I have one businessman in Rockhampton who stands to lose $47,000 in debts owed to him by businessmen in those areas who simply cannot pay him. He could face bankruptcy. There is going to be a need for sympathy and compassion at every government level to ensure that we will accept delays in these returns. I would hope too that we can expand the system of assistance going to those business people and to the farmers, to repair the fences, to clean out the dams and to try to solve the problem of soil erosion that is so widespread across tens of thousands of acres.

I would make the appeal that the Australian people do not stop now with their compassion and care and generosity but that they remember that in the weeks to come the recreation fields, the school halls and the community facilities will have to be repaired. The money will still be needed. We will still have to deal with the psychological trauma of those families. I would suggest that there is a need to realise that this problem will go on and on for thousands of families for weeks and weeks to come. I would also make the suggestion that maybe, despite the argument against a national disaster fund and a national disaster insurance scheme, we need to have a look at the concept again.

Finally, I ask that this debate not be seen as a debate between the Opposition and Government but instead it be seen as some type of motion or statement that is congratulating the people of Australia for their dedication, commitment and compassion during this recent disaster.

DEBATE.TITLE: OAKLEIGH MULTI-USER ARMY RESERVE DEPOT, VICTORIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Oakleigh Multi-User Army Reserve Depot, Victoria.

This proposal is for the construction of a multi-user depot at Oakleigh, Victoria, for use by various Army Reserve units. The construction of the new depot is primarily the result of a request from the Victorian State Government that the site of an existing depot in Batman Avenue, East Melbourne, adjacent to the National Tennis Centre, be vacated for use as open space.

The Commonwealth agreed to make the land available to the Victorian State Government as part of a wider Commonwealth-State land transfer agreement involving various properties in Melbourne. In relation to the Batman Avenue depot, defence relocation costs were to be met and the Commonwealth was not to be financially disadvantaged overall. The construction of a new depot will also allow rationalisation and collocation of like Army Reserve functions which is consistent with this Government's policy of rationalising and upgrading defence facilities.

A suitable 3.17 hectare site for the construction of the new depot has been purchased at Oakleigh some 16 kilometres from the Melbourne central business district. When purchased the site, which was previously an abattoir, included disused and derelict buildings unsuitable to form part of the depot complex. Australian Construction Services, with approval from the Public Works Committee (PWC), let a contract for the demolition of these buildings in December 1989 and this demolition work is now complete.

The proposed work, in addition to the demolition work, includes construction of offices, administrative and storage facilities, training facilities, a vehicle compound, parade ground, recreational and some food preparation facilities, as well as car parking and security fencing. Landscaping and engineering services for the site will also be undertaken.

Once complete this depot will provide a home to Army Reserve headquarters and units of the Royal Australian Engineers, Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, and the Royal Australian Army Ordnance Corps in line with current defence policy of multi-user, or shared, accommodation for like Reserve Army functions.

Due to unavoidable delays expected from the recent dissolution of Parliament, and the need to refer this project to a new Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, agreement was sought from the previous Public Works Committee to progress the project to the stage of calling tenders. Australian Construction Services, on behalf of the Department of Defence, called tenders at the end of last month, to close late this month, pending completion of the current PWC process. The limit of cost estimate for the project, including demolition work, is $9m at November 1989 prices. As stated earlier, the demolition work is complete and construction of the new depot on the Oakleigh site is planned for commencement in mid-1990 with completion expected in late 1991.

The impact of the proposed work on the environment has been determined as minimal and the site at Oakleigh is appropriately zoned as general industrial. Construction of the new depot will provide in the order of 20 to 25 jobs on site, as well as opportunities for local contractors and suppliers of building materials and equipment.
I table selected drawings of the proposed work and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Puckapunyal Redevelopment Stage 1, Victoria.

The Puckapunyal military area is situated in Victoria, approximately 11 kilometres west of the town of Seymour and 100 kilometres north of Melbourne, and was originally established as an Army training centre for new recruits prior to, and during, World War II. Puckapunyal has been the main training centre for the armoured corps since 1942. The Puckapunyal military area is currently home to three major operational units, two of which are part of the operational deployment force, a newly formed logistic battalion, three major training establishments and various minor units. It is considered a significant defence base by the Australian Defence Force employing approximately 2,000 service men and women. The area consists of three distinct and special purpose zones. The range complex, covering 42,500 hectares, is used for training and is capable of brigade size exercises and live deployment of all major weapons deployed by the Army. The military cantonment, or soldier accommodation, is located in the south east corner of the range complex.

The third zone is the Puckapunyal village which includes married quarters for service personnel and dependants which, at present, total approximately 2,200. A study being conducted by the Australian Defence Families and Information Liaison Staff is aimed at identifying community needs through liaison with the Puckapunyal community. The redevelopment of Puckapunyal is directly in line with the Government's commitment to improving existing living-in accommodation and rationalising and modernising working accommodation and facilities as stated in the defence policy information paper titled The Defence of Australia 1987. Increases in occupational health and safety requirements and the services' scales and standards of accommodation have meant that deficiencies now exist in working accommodation at Puckapunyal. These deficiencies have had detrimental effects on the management of some functions at the base.

The proposed work currently before the House is the first part of a two-stage redevelopment program for the area and will basically involve replacing substandard living-in accommodation, upgrading engineering services and replacing and refurbishing working accommodation to house the newly formed Puckapunyal logistic battalion. Environmental effects of the planned development will be minimal and an environmental certificate of compliance has been issued.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING DEVELOPMENTS BY THE DEFENCE HOUSING AUTHORITY AT LAVERTON AND MACLEOD, VICTORIA AND BULLSBROOK, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF ARMY AVIATION CENTRE, OAKEY, QUEENSLAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of the Army Aviation Centre at Oakey, Queensland.
I hope that the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works acknowledges the great effort that we are putting in for it today.

The Oakey Army Aviation Centre, situated on 220 hectares of land near the township of Oakey on the Darling Downs-and it is very good country, too-160 kilometres west of Brisbane, was originally established in 1941 for use by the Royal Australian Air Force during World War II. In 1969 the Army took control of the airfield. Since then a number of developments have taken place including provision of temporary and permanent facilities for units currently housed on the base.

Today the airfield is home to the School of Army Aviation, 1st Aviation Regiment-with the exception of two squadrons located in Sydney and Townsville-1st Aviation Regiment workshop, 173 General Support Squadron and workshop, Oakey Workshop Battalion and the Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers Aircraft Maintenance School. All of these units are administratively coordinated and controlled by the headquarters Army aviation centre, which is also located at the base. Currently the base houses 55 aircraft and approximately 196 vehicles and trailers and employs 734 Army personnel and 51 civilian staff. This employment figure is expected to rise to a total of 863 by 1995.

The airfield at Oakey is a joint user aerodrome, the Department of Defence, Army, being the principal user with the Department of Transport and Communications as the tenant accounting for approximately 15 per cent of total aircraft movements.

In line with this Government's commitment to enhancing our defence capabilities, and as stressed in the defence policy information paper of 1987, there is a continued need for Army aviation assets and an extensive infrastructure of bases, airfields, training and other facilities to support the operations of the Australian Defence Force. The centre at Oakey is a major part of that infrastructure providing the core for both aviation training and support for the Army throughout Australia. Described as particularly suitable to aircraft operations, Oakey is the preferred possible site, over Fairbairn, for any triservice helicopter pilot training school.

The works currently before the House form stage one of a two-stage redevelopment aimed at rectifying significant occupational health and safety deficiencies and upgrading working conditions at the base. In particular, stage one will involve the construction of permanent facilities for 1st Aviation Regiment, who still occupy temporary facilities constructed in 1969 and 1973 General Support Squadron. Extension to the existing hangar and technical facilities used by 1st Aviation Regiment workshop and extension-refurbishment of aircraft maintenance facilities for Oakey Workshop Battalion. Also included are civil work and extensions to existing engineering services.

Once complete, these works will provide purpose designed working facilities for Army units located at the base and ensure the continued provision of services undertaken at the airfield and provide a centralised helicopter pilot training school once training facilities are complete in 1990. As part of the training school a number of Black Hawk helicopters will eventually be housed at Oakey.

The limit of cost for the stage one redevelopment is estimated at $14.6m at September 1989 prices. The proposed works are expected to go to tender in September 1990, subject to a favourable Public Works Committee report, with progressive completion through to 1994.

The proposed works are expected to provide employment for up to 80 personnel on site and substantial opportunities for local contractors and subcontractors as well as supplies of building materials, plant and equipment in the Oakey area. I table selected plans of the proposed stage one redevelopment at Oakey and I commend the motion to the House.
