SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990 was introduced last week into this House and is a complete change of direction. That change is embodied in the title in clause 3, which provides that it is the intention to replace bounty entitlements for yarn with capitalisation grants.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I must say that we do not oppose the thrust of this Bill if it does what it implies, and as is proposed in clause 21c. It is implied that there will be, firstly, reduced Commonwealth expenditure with which we obviously agree; secondly, accelerated restructuring of industry; and, thirdly, the potential for accelerating the reduction of reliance on assistance from government by industry, or, as the Bill says, reduce the dependence of those industries on assistance from the Commonwealth. That is totally consistent with coalition policy. As a consequence, it gives industry a chance to be more internationally competitive and potentially it gives industry a way of getting better value for bounty money by putting the onus for restructuring back on the companies in that industry.

We are not debating the merits of the existing entitlements scheme, which has some shortcomings, but that scheme will no doubt be looked at in the mid-term review. However, the industry would be entitled to continuing assistance under the current bounty legislation until 1995 even if this Bill had not appeared. We are considering a new method of delivering a lesser level of entitlements in net present value terms, but nevertheless entitlements received early and in advance of those that would have been delivered under the present annual bounty arrangements.

We have consulted with industry and industry associations and we understand that the provisions of this Bill arose from some suggestions to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority (TCFDA). No-one disputes the importance of restructuring. However, modifying tariff and bounty schemes is only part of what must be done to restructure the industry as a whole. For further restructuring to be successful, we certainly are going to need labour market reforms. We are going to need wages and conditions arrangements that do not build in inflation and we are going to need transport reforms, reduced regulations, and so on.

In regard to this Bill, we have satisfied ourselves to the best of our ability, in the limited time we have been given, on a number of points. First of all, as I said, industry is reasonably happy with the proposition and it has the choice of whether to take advantage of it or not. We have an assurance from the Department that this proposition does not interfere and is consistent with existing General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements. We have several reservations, however, which I will detail shortly. Before doing so, I have an in-principle amendment which I will put now. I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Bill should contain provision to ensure that;
(1) the making of a capitalisation grant to a textile yarn producer is limited to expected bounty receipts in respect of existing capacity; and

(2) where, in any case of Commonwealth funding being made and lost (for example, in the case of a textile yarn producer being declared bankrupt), any subsequent owner of the productive capacity is not eligible for payment of bounty-that is to prevent `double dipping' ''.

We understand that the Government now accepts some of those reservations and that some of the identified deficiencies may be remedied by Government amendments during the committee stage of this Bill. However, I would like to expand on the reservations which the in-principle amendment addresses.

The Bill is, in our view, not clear enough in providing that these capitalisation grants cannot be used for start-up capital. That is, the grants should not be able to be obtained for yarn production capacity that currently does not exist in the industry. Whilst making that point, we understand that under this scheme there can be a transfer of ownership of existing capacity and that the words `a person who is likely to become a producer of bountiable yarn during the bounty period' mean that there can be a transfer of ownership from one owner to another. I have been told by departmental officers that it is not the intention for it to be used as a source of new start-up capital for new ventures. We would like an assurance from the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) that that is the case under this Bill and that this scheme will not be used for such arrangements. Specifically, we would like an assurance that to receive a grant the applicant must be a producer of bountiable yarn and have lodged a claim for bounty, and that the making of a capitalisation grant to a textile yarn producer is limited to expected bounty receipts in respect of existing capacity.

In regard to the second point, that is, double dipping, we are satisfied that any debts arising out of the unfulfilled obligations by the recipient of the grant to the Commonwealth are reasonably well covered- that is under clause 21f with one exception, and that is in the case of bankruptcy or double dipping. I am advised that the Government now intends moving amendments to address this deficiency, and this shows the importance of allowing sufficient time for parliamentary scrutiny of legislation.

There are several other reservations about which we would like particular assurances from the Minister. We would like an assurance from the Minister of even-handed treatment of all applicants or applications. We would also like the TCFDA to publish guidelines on the type of proposal that would be acceptable for payment of grant, given that this legislation appears to have arisen from industry suggestions and our concerns about start-up capital. The House will have noticed that there have been comments in some places as to various commercial propositions that are or may be in the wind, so to speak. Thus the question arises, secondly, as to whether there are any arrangements or understandings that have already been made between the Government or its agencies and the industry, current or potential, in regard to this matter of capitalisation grants and that have not been announced to the public.
Finally, I ask the Minister in his response to the second reading debate to indicate whether there are any such arrangements or understandings and, if so, to provide some details as to their nature.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) on his Bill, the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990. I am very pleased to see a fellow Queenslander in the Ministry and certainly a Queenslander who has a full understanding of rural issues and rural areas, given that he represents a rural electorate. The proposed amendments to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 will provide persons currently eligible for bounty assistance under the Act with an alternative to assistance, that is, as has been mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), a one-off capitalisation grant in lieu of any future possible bounty receipts.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that, apart from anything else, such a scheme as this will provide the opportunity for accelerated restructuring of the industry while simultaneously granting net reductions in budgetary outlays to the Commonwealth. I do not believe that anyone has or will have any problems with that.

The main features of the proposed capitalisation grant are that current or likely producers of textile yarn may apply to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority and that applications submitted will have to include a comprehensive business plan that outlines the methods by which the applicant will achieve his objectives on a yearly basis against certain specified criteria. Included in the applicant's submission will be an estimate of the grant sought to enable the implementation of his business plan. In other words, it has to be well thought out and presented in a proper and fit manner.

After prompt consideration of all applications, the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority will report to the Minister with a recommendation stating whether the grant should be made and, if so, the amount of that grant, having given regard to certain factors. One of those factors is that the financial viability of the applicant's business plan has to be guaranteed. In other words, there is a thorough research on the plan that has been put forward by the applicant and consideration given to whether or not the making of the grant would result in an ultimate saving to the Commonwealth on the bounty. That ensures that both the producer and the Commonwealth benefit from some significant monetary saving. Under the current bounty textile yarn arrangements, Commonwealth outlays between 1 July 1990 and 30 June 1995 are likely to reach approximately $400m in present dollar values.

The extent of the potential outlay of reductions as a result of the new scheme will depend upon the number of applicants. It is not possible to foresee that at this stage. To me, the biggest benefit will be that it will make us more internationally competitive and will give to producers or prospective producers of yarn a choice as to the way they wish to go. It is important, if we are going to expand our export industries, that we be internationally competitive. Anything that helps add value to rural commodities is very welcome, given the fact that some 69 per cent of our gross domestic product is based on primary or resource industries.

We have to continually fight-I think the previous speaker mentioned the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-to make sure that we operate on a fair playing field. It is rather cynical that the most powerful nations on earth that can, at the press of a button, destroy the world hide behind high protection. When it comes to the really tough issue, free trade, they squib on it. Australia leads the way in fighting and pushing for free trade. In years to come we will stand tall because of that.

We have massive potential in regard to value-adding our rural commodities in two areas. One is Asia, as the standard of living improves and there is a bigger surplus of consumer spending. The other interesting scenario is eastern Europe. I think everyone is pleased to see what has happened there in the last six months. As those nations embrace democracy and start to restructure their industries there will be greater demands for products, possibly in the short term raw materials but, as their standard of living improves, most certainly value-added products. I believe that, providing we maintain top quality, we will get access to those markets. It matters little whether we sell our commodities in one form or another, providing we can get access to the markets. If at the same time they are value-added here, the jobs and the profit will be here and we will be much the better for it.

So on that basis I have great pleasure in supporting this Bill. Once again I compliment the Minister. He has a very good understanding of rural industries, the need to value-add and the need to get some competitiveness back into these sorts of industries. As I said, I am pleased to see bipartisan support for this Bill. As the honourable member for Barker has pointed out, the Opposition has no problems with this Bill. In regard to the need to restructure right across the board, I believe that we are showing the way. We are going to take on the tough issues within the shipping industry, as the majority of our commodities have to be exported. We have gone a long way down that track in a few years compared with the last 40.

The other area is the restructuring of the labour market, where we are doing a great job, given that we do not have industrial disputation and that real unit labour costs are much lower than they were prior to 1983. I have much pleasure in supporting the legislation before the House tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in speaking on the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990. The Bill proposes to amend the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 to provide those who are currently eligible for bounty assistance under the Act with the alternative assistance scheme which will take the form of a one-off capitalisation grant paid instead of possible future receipts of bounty over a period of five years.

SPEECH.PARA: The total bounties payable under the current scheme over the next five years are estimated to total approximately $400.94m on current dollar values. As my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has pointed out, the coalition supports the basic premise in the Bill, that is, to reduce government expenditure, to deregulate and restructure industry and to reduce dependence upon government assistance. The challenge to government as far as we are concerned is to remove the impediments which stand in the way of improved enterprise productivity and competitiveness, not just in industries such as textiles but right across the entire economy so we can have an industry base which is capable both of exporting and of import substitution. Regrettably, in so many areas of Australian secondary industry that is currently not the situation.

Improvements in productivity would stabilise and reduce inflationary pressures on the economy, improve our poor trade deficit, reduce our mounting foreign debt and ultimately improve the standard of living for all Australians which has deteriorated significantly under seven years of Labor.

Australian manufacturing needs to be matured and provided with the right environment to achieve a more productive outcome so that it will survive in an increasingly competitive world market. We believe that Australia must move at a much greater speed to achieve the changes necessary to facilitate a better position in world markets. Future generations, no doubt, will look back on the last seven years and see that much of that time has been wasted because, whilst numerous reports have been brought forward, there has been scarcely any significant fundamental change-above all, change in the attitude which people should have if this country is to be able to be got off its knees and back into a truly competitive situation internationally.

What my colleague the honourable member for Barker pointed out in his opening address was that, while we support the thrust of this legislation, nevertheless there are aspects of it which we are concerned about and to which we trust the Minister for Customs and Small Business (Mr Beddall), in his summing up at the end of the debate, will draw the attention of the House. For example, he identified the question of start-up capital or new start-up capital; he identified the question of the transfer of ownership and the question as to whether or not these benefits will be available to people who were previously producers, who sell their companies and their productive capacity to a third party and who then may have access to the same level of bounty support, whether through capitalisation or through the conventional means. In other words, to what extent will using existing capacity be seen as one of the sine qua non for access to these capitalisation grants?

The Labor Government has based its economic policy on a total reliance on tight monetary policy, with resultant high interest rates. This has produced an unsustainable situation for many industries, with incumbent volatility in the currency. A Liberal-National Party government will pursue more responsible fiscal and monetary policies to ensure a more stable macro-economic environment for industry. We see this as absolutely fundamental, as I said, if the Australian industrial base is going to be expanded and directed at those areas where we are capable of competing on world standards, on world terms. We believe that the complex system of industry assistance, of tariffs, of quotas and bounties, developed in Australia since Federation, has in fact worked against the nation's best interests and has created an inward looking manufacturing sector, insulated from the discipline of competition and often too heavily reliant on assistance from governments of all colours.

The Government received a review of textile yarn bounty administration in the form of a discussion paper from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority in September 1989. This was in response to a request from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in January of the same year. It is interesting that the terms of reference for the review excluded `examination of programmed levels of assistance accorded yarn production under the TC and F plan'. Furthermore, the report, which was meant to be presented to the Minister by 30 September last year, ended up as a mere discussion paper. It therefore contains no reference to the complete change of policy which is now contained in the Bill before the House.

Furthermore, in accordance with the terms of reference, the review did not cover `the merits of textile yarn bounties compared to some other possible forms of assistance or to consider varying the overall level of budgetary assistance accorded the yarn production sector as part of that policy'. Nevertheless, we are assured on page 7 of the review that after consultations on the discussion paper, a final report will be presented to the Minister. But there is no indication as to when this will take place and thus the question must be asked: What was the basis for this early legislation? Why was it that the Government proposed a fundamental change in the direction of bounty policy and in the substance of bounty policy, without in fact waiting for the final report to be brought forward?

The Opposition supports the objective of Government policy, which is to encourage the development of industries which are internationally competitive and capable of operating in the longer term with less taxpayer funded support. Clearly, we must move away from the protection of industry as a means of assistance and rather emphasise the improvement of industry efficiency and competitiveness as a clear objective of policy. Much has been said about this in recent years, but I come back to what I said initially: while much has been said, relatively little has been done either in fundamental change of policy or in evidence before us to indicate the success of that change of policy.

Tariffs for Australian manufacturing continue to be reduced to either 10 or 15 per cent, but among the exceptions are the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries, which are subject to sectoral plans. We can only hope that the sectoral plans for this industry are more successful than reports would suggest they have been in relation to the vehicle manufacturing sector. In the past, bounties have been provided as an alternative to tariff protection, as a means of avoiding loading the costs of industry assistance on to the taxpayer. The other advantage of bounty assistance is that the amount provided can be clearly identified, although in recent years with the reduction in industry assistance we have seen greater emphasis placed upon macro-economic management as the be-all and end-all of the Government's current problems.

In 1988-89 the total assistance to industry amounted to some $250m, of which textile yarn bounties accounted for 35 per cent or approximately $90m. The textiles, clothing and footwear plan has, as its fundamental objective, encouraging industries, which are efficient and inter-nationally competitive, to place greater emphasis on innovation and exports, while at the same time reducing dependence on taxation support. The main elements of the plan include industry development measures and changes to protection and labour adjustment assistance.

Although the plan came into operation on 1 March 1989 and is scheduled to run to mid-1995, the authority is required to complete a mid-term review by 1992. Again I therefore have to ask the question: Why has the Government made this fundamental change of policy in what can best be described as an atmosphere of some haste? Therefore, the Opposition is entitled to ask the question, in the context of this fundamental change of policy in relation to textile yarn bounties: what effect will this particular decision have on the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, and will the Government proceed to apply the same concept of capitalisation grants as an alternative to regular bounty payments to other industries receiving assistance?

If honourable members read carefully the explanatory memorandum attached to the Act and in fact the actual terminology of the Act itself they will see that it is perfectly clear that this is not necessarily going to be a one-off venture. I ask the Minister to explain clearly to the House whether he intends that the capitalisation grant concept will in fact be extended beyond the textiles, clothing and footwear area-certainly beyond the question of yarns-and, if so, will it be to other elements of the TCF bounty category as well?

In terms of textile bounties themselves, they accounted for some $86.9m of budgetary assistance to yarn producers in 1988-89. Under the plan we are told that they will be progressively reduced to some 30 per cent of factory value added by 1994, which in 1986 terms would represent a tariff of approximately 15 per cent. Since much is made in the plan of the need to provide a predictable and sustainable policy environment, my earlier question becomes particularly relevant, because annual expenditure on textile yarn bounties was $23m in 1981-82 but, as I have stated, it rose to $86.9m in 1988-89. In fact, over this period bounty assistance to the yarn sector has totalled $588m; not a mere bagatelle in anyone's language.

Recipients of the bounty show some interesting variations. There are approximately 27 companies or 30 per cent which receive less than $50,000, or approximately half a million dollars or less than one per cent of all bounties, while there are 15 companies or 17 per cent of the total which receive over $1m each or nearly $70m in total, or 81 per cent of all bounties paid.

The textile yarn industry in Australia, as elsewhere, is dominated of course by large producers, which tend to integrate on a vertical basis their downstream processing. For example, there are a number of corporate groups. These include JGL Investments Proprietary, otherwise known as Fibremakers Australia Pty Ltd, which has two major production units and has bounty worth $30.6m In terms of recipients, they get 36 per cent of the total bounty. There is Linter Groups Ltd, which has three major units. It gets $14.6m or 17 per cent of the total bounties. The other producers are significantly less than that. Nevertheless, the total of those five producers alone comes to $61.8m, or 72 per cent of the total.

The textiles industry also produces a range of fibres, the main one being man-made fibre which receives a bounty of over $31m. Cotton bounty receivers total $25.7m, while wool receives a mere $3.5m, worsteds $13m and carpet $4.3m. This group therefore makes up about 84 per cent of the total of all bounties paid under this category.

Clearly, the ultimate test in terms of the objectives of the Government's policy will be determined by whether it has succeeded over time in effectively increasing exports, directly or indirectly, or equally as important, reducing the flow of imports in this particular category. The picture here, regrettably, is somewhat confusing. According to the survey contained in the discussion paper, bounties paid on exports were worth $427,000 on total exports of $5m. Consequently, most of the production of these plants is used for Australian domestic production, much of which hopefully does find its way into the export market, but regrettably not sufficient to really justify at this time the level of those particular bounties.

While some 20 companies were engaged in yarn exports only one received in excess of $30,000 in bounty which, I think, emphasises the point I am making. In other words, the rest were insignificant in terms of their export potential. While many more companies-60-claimed they were exporting at a post-yarn stage of production which does not qualify them for the bounty, they believe that there were still further export opportunities. What we need to establish is precisely what are those opportunities.

Significantly, when asked if the current bounty system acted as a disincentive to exports, 22 companies-24 per cent of the total including, I might add, some of the main recipients-said yes, and 46 companies, 51 per cent, said no. Those who saw the bounty as a disincentive claimed that it penalised the efficient producer while subsidising the less efficient. They also claimed that it deterred capital investment and should be extended to exports as an incentive to local producers and to match what other countries provide. One of the problems here is international agreements which we have entered into, and whether it will be possible to do that. Nevertheless, there is a serious conceptual problem in that Australian manufacturing industries perceive that there is a range of ways, in international markets, by which their entry can be controlled or limited. Therefore, they believe they are facing a disincentive in terms of exports to various other markets.

Because the bounty is less on export sales, this also causes them to be marginal in comparison to domestic sales, which clearly has a built-in advantage. Significantly, it was also claimed that the policy discriminates against the export of wool rich carpets. The carding wool industry has particular problems, not the least of which is the significant competition it faces from New Zealand wools.

I think we are really facing a fundamental need for a value added base for as many of our domestic based industries as possible. Certainly, the yarn industry is one of those in which the value added component is of fundamental importance if we are going to be able to enter international markets and compete effectively when we get there.

On this evidence, and supported by industry submissions, it would appear that exports of yarn will not increase above the standing of marginal activity for producers unless the bias of incentives towards domestic production in relation to exports is corrected. I see that as one of the fundamental problems facing the Government in the application of this policy, and one upon which very little has been said by the Minister in his second reading speech. I trust he will direct his efforts to that in his concluding remarks.

Consequently, it is clear that the benefit of the yarn bounty is to those producers of fabrics who export only at the fabric stage because the exporter at the yarn stage receives a much lower bounty uplift. If the objective-and I assume that it is-of government policy is to achieve longer production runs and, thus, greater economies of scale, clearly, access to export markets for yarn should be at least on an equal footing with access to the domestic market.

Finally, I refer to an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 14 May. The headline was, `Govt attacked on textile bill'. Whether the word `attacked' is appropriate is a matter of some doubt. As my colleague the honourable member for Barker pointed out in his opening remarks there is concern in the industry, and it is exemplified in this article, as to whether the application of the capitalisation grants will be fair to all participants in the industry.

For example, the article refers to the question of one of the world's largest fibre manufacturers, E. I. Du Pont de Nemours. It is suggested that the Liberman family synthetic yarn producer, Fibremakers, is likely to be taken over by Du Pont. Of course, the question which arises in that particular context is what access would Du Pont have to the capitalisation grants which may be granted initially to Fibremakers, or which may be subject-if Fibremakers wish to continue with the conventional system-to the year by year arrangements.

What we are concerned about, and what the honourable member for Barker emphasised, is when we are talking about the transfer of ownership-and we are assuming that the transfer of ownership can only be, therefore, to an existing producer-surely the question arises whether Du Pont is an existing producer. Clearly, in the Australian environment the answer has to be no, although internationally quite clearly it is.

The other question which comes up concerns the start-up capital for new plant. In this case we assume we are not talking about new plant; we are talking about the transfer of ownership of existing plant. Therefore, a company has to be an existing producer to qualify under the Act for the capitalisation grant. To what extent will the capitalisation grant be built into the value of the total plant plus equipment, goodwill et cetera which is taken into account in the final figure which is negotiated by the owners of an existing plant and the foreign interests which may be coming in at the same time?

These are issues which are of concern to the industry. As I said, the industry says it supports this approach. It clearly does have built-in advantages to be able to say to people, `you may capitalise your expected grants over five years' of course, on the presumption that they will still be operating over that period of time. This is a matter which I think we have raised in our amendment, because it is one of the question marks in this legislation as it currently stands to which I trust the Minister will refer.

We see these changes as significant. We see the concept of capitalisation as an interesting additive to the debate on the capacity and benefits of tariffs, bounties and so forth, although as I said earlier, our objective is to phase them out as soon as possible, in terms of economic realities. Therefore, the issues which I put to the Minister, apart from those contained in our second reading amendment, are: to what extent is it the intention of the Government to extend the capitalisation concept to other industries which may be the recipients of tariffs or bounties, and is this to be limited exclusively to the bounty on textile yarn, or will it be extended further?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill is welcome as a measure which will facilitate restructuring in what continues to be one of the most heavily protected sections of Australian manufacturing. The Bill flows from the Government's review of the textile yarn bounty administration under the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan for the reduction of assistance to these industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The average effective rates of assistance enjoyed by the textile yarns industry currently range from 67 per cent to 104 per cent. This level of assistance is far higher than that available to most industries in the manufacturing sector and second only to the clothing and footwear industries as the most heavily protected Australian manufacturing industry. This is salutary when one remembers that manufacturing is the most heavily protected sector of our economy.

The bounties paid to the yarn industry under the textile, clothing and footwear industry plan are currently set at about 40 per cent of the value added. Projected expenditure for 1989-90 under the existing arrangement is $91m. This assistance, along with various TCF import restrictions, is responsible for the high costs faced by household and commercial users of textiles in Australia. These costs represent the inefficiency of an industry which has been living, like many others, at the expense of Australian consumers.

The textile yarns bounty must be seen in the context of the entire textile, clothing and footwear industries and the Government's TCF plan, the broad thrust of which the Opposition supports. Like the Government, the coalition is committed to sustained reductions in assistance to the TCF industries with a view to making them internationally competitive and an important contributor to value added production in Australia. We welcome any measure intended to relieve the taxpayer of bounty payments and relieve, in turn, consumers of the high prices for inefficiently produced goods.

The Opposition has had objection to the Government's administration of this plan. In particular, we oppose the unnecessary establishment of yet another statutory authority-the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority (TCFDA) to preside over the plan. We have objected to that authority's intrusive powers over management as indicative of the Government's corporate approach to industry policy. In the case of this Bill the TCFDA will be responsible for approving the business plan required of those enterprises seeking capitalisation grants. This plan will involve the firm seeking grants supplying detailed information to the authority about its proposed use of up-front payments of capital. This raises the important question of how a statutory authority can be expected to appraise accurately the financial position and market situation facing each firm.

This task is daunting enough for the entrepreneur with a financial stake in the matter let alone for a Canberra bureaucrat far removed from the day-to-day operations of the business. Yet any assessment of the financial viability of the proposed business plan under this legislation will depend on just such an appraisal.

Inevitably, approval for these capitalisation grants will entail the dubious exercise of picking winners on the part of the TCFDA bureaucracy. Whether or not this will be done effectively remains to be seen. Obviously a decision by some authority is required in the administration of these grants. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce could, if adequately resourced, provide the services currently being provided by the TCFDA without the need for the additional bureaucracy represented by the Authority. It was for reasons such as this that the coalition opposed the establishment of the TCFDA. It may even be the case that the Department is better qualified to perform this task, given its former institutional responsibilities.

The capitalisation agreements foreshadowed by this legislation will be subject to terms and conditions imposed by the Minister of the day in the case of each grant. Such terms and conditions will no doubt be designed to protect taxpayers' money from abuse. This requirement is clearly necessary, although it will do little to protect the revenue where firms which are the recipients of the capitalisation grant eventually go bankrupt. However, we need to be wary of attempts by government to use the necessary accountability to the taxpayer to interfere excessively in the decisions of management. A balance is required.

The TCFDA already has wide discretionary powers in allocating assistance on the basis of its own determination of labour management plans, production costs, productivity changes, and the like. These powers are backed up by considerable powers of investigation and review, and with associated penalties for non-compliance. The wide scope for government interference can be counterproductive if used overzealously. There is no chance that ever-changing market signals will remain in accord with the decrees of a statutory authority for any length of time. How the TCFDA will reconcile this conflict is an interesting question. The answer in due course will tell us much about the difficulties faced by these industries. It will remain the case that the market will continue to be the best regulator of business decision making. The Government will best facilitate restructuring in the domestic textile yarns industry by exposing it to greater international competition through the textiles, clothing and footwear plan.

Despite these reservations about the conduct of Government industry policy, the coalition recognises that consistency is an important principle in the reduction of industry assistance. Producers need to be able to proceed on the basis that current investment decisions will not be undermined by the actions of future governments. Accordingly, a future coalition government can be expected to continue with the substance of any devolution in assistance arrangements set in train by this Government. We would not seek to exceed those arrangements, except where economic circumstances were then judged to permit further reform and competition.

The TCF plan provides for significant reductions, after some initial increases, in the levels of assistance for textiles, clothing and footwear industries. These reductions should bring about the desired level of restructuring over the life of the plan. However, we should remain alert to the scope for introducing further competition where firms successfully grapple with the opportunities created by restructuring and rationalisation. Already, there is evidence that some firms are doing well under the plan and making good use of available opportunities. Of course, there are other firms that will not do as well. That is the nature of business generally.

It is not only the absolute level of TCF assistance that gives proper cause for reform. As the 1988-89 Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) annual report noted, it is the great differences in the levels of assistance within and between the textiles and other industries that leads to gross misallocations of resources, away from their most productive use. While there have been significant reductions in Government assistance to the manufacturing sector in recent years, there are still great variations in the levels of assistance provided to different industries, and these need to be evened out to encourage efficient resources use. That IAC annual report also noted that, were the agricultural and manufacturing assistance arrangements that are expected to be in place in the mid-1990s removed, Australia's gross domestic product could increase by nearly $4 billion per annum. Clearly, the scope for and potential benefits from further reform in industry policy are immense. It is to be hoped that many firms in the textiles industry will take up the opportunity of these up-front capitalisation grants to comprehensively restructure and rationalise their operations.

Such restructuring will complement the liberalised import arrangements under the TCF plan that will increasingly subject the textiles industries to international competition. It is this competition which will provide for the significant improvements in efficiency that are necessary to bring down TCF prices, for the benefit of consumers. It is competition that will ultimately deliver us an efficient textiles industry.

So-called positive assistance arrangements such as those provided for in this Bill should be seen in this light. The capitalisation grants provided for under this Bill should be used by the textile yarns industry not simply to adjust to the phased reduction of bounty rates provided for under the TCF plan but, more importantly, to lay the foundations for the abolition of these bounty arrangements after the expiry of the TCF plan in June 1995.

Micro-economic reform is firmly on the agenda-to use the buzz words of today-of both the Government and the Opposition. There is increasing international pressure for openness in trade policy through the current round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) talks. In the light of this agenda, those firms forgoing the textile yarn bounties in favour of capitalisation grants would be wise to use these grants to the greatest possible extent in anticipation of little or no assistance in years to come.

With those remarks, I now address the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the shadow Minister for industry and commerce. In concluding my remarks, I think it is important to state again that, through our second reading amendment, we seek to ensure that the making of a capitalisation grant to a textile yarn producer is limited to the expected bounty receipts in respect of existing capacity.

The honourable member for Barker made his intention and meaning quite clear. He said that the Government was prepared to amend, in committee or at a later stage, its own legislation to prevent double dipping. In the case of Commonwealth funding being made available and then lost-for example, in the case of a textile yarn producer being declared bankrupt-any subsequent owner of the productive capacity should not be eligible for payment of bounty. That, of course, is intended to prevent double dipping. It might suit the convenience of the House if I conclude my remarks there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their contribution to the second reading debate. Honourable members raised several points on the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990 on which they have sought some formal confirmation by the Government. Firstly, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) sought confirmation that this proposal for capitalisation does not contravene our General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) obligations. I confirm that. The bounty capitalisation scheme as proposed by the Bill is not a breach of Australia's GATT or closer economic relations obligations. There will be no impact on international trade obligations as this program is simply a refinement of the existing scheme which pays bounty on domestic production and domestic end use of textile yarns.

SPEECH.PARA: As a quantum of the capitalisation grant itself is dependent on, and must not be less than, a producer's current bounty entitlement under the Act-proposed new paragraph 21c (2) (a)-and as a producer's bounty entitlement is not measured in terms of export production, the capitalisation scheme itself has no direct implications for specific exports. As such, the grants are not in any way prescribed by the GATT or the GATT subsidies code.

The honourable member for Barker, together with the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), also sought confirmation that the proposed scheme cannot be used as start up capital or money which is calculated on possible bounty receipts or future expectations as opposed to current entitlement. I again confirm that this is so. Application for capitalisation grant is open to any person who is, or who is likely to become, a producer of bountiable yarn in Australia during the bounty period.

While it is acknowledged that eligibility to apply for a grant is not restricted to current producers of bountiable yarn, the proposed Bill, in the opinion of the Government's advisers and consistent with the Government's stated policy, expressly requires a grant to be made to a producer. The quantum with a capitalisation grant is dependent on, and must be less than, a producer's bounty entitlement under the Act, which is determined without the benefit of a capitalisation grant. Thus, a current producer cannot calculate the grant sought on the basis of what he might produce once he receives the money. While information concerning the purpose of the grant is indeed required both to cost and condition the grant, the ceiling on the quantum of a possible grant is dependent solely on one's bounty entitlement had the person continued to claim bounty without the benefits of a capitalisation grant-proposed paragraph 21c (2) (a).

Similarly, the new player, while he may apply for a grant-proposed new section 21a-cannot receive one until he becomes a producer and claims bounty under the Act. Again, the recommendation for a capitalisation grant is contingent, among other things, on there being a budgetary saving to the Commonwealth-that is, the grant sought must, in the opinion of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority (TCFDA), which has responsibility for the processing of grant applications, be likely to result in a lesser budgetary outlay by the Commonwealth, on a net present value basis, then the outlay required if the applicant had continued to claim a bounty in respect of bountiable yarn produced without the benefits of a capitalisation grant.

Where one has no entitlement under the Act, the Authority cannot satisfy itself as required in proposed new section 21c (2) (a) that, but for the grant, the applicant would have to continue to claim bounty and the bounty claims would have exceeded the amount proposed for the grant. In summary, therefore, the making of a capitalisation grant to a textile yarn producer is limited to expected bounty receipts in respect of existing capacity.

The honourable members asked whether guidelines are being prepared to assist applicants. I would point out that the legislation provides for expressed guidance for potential applicants in the type of information required to support an application. For example, proposed section 21b outlines what applications must contain with specific references to a business plan. I would expect the TCFDA would help firms develop their applications and, where necessary, develop literature to assist applicants. However, this must not be seen as additional to that which the legislation expressly requires.

The honourable member for Bradfield also asked generally whether the Government would apply bounty capitalisation to other bounty schemes. There have been no decisions to extend bounty capitalisation to other bounty schemes and I am not aware of any plans to do so. However, the option of capitalisation would undoubtedly be considered, especially if this scheme proves successful.

The honourable members for Barker and Bradfield also sought the Government's assurance that all applicants would be dealt with fairly and that there would be even-handed treatment for all applications. The basis for assessing a capitalisation grant is indicated in the legislation. All applications for capitalisation grants will be directed to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, an independent authority responsible for administering the TCF plan-proposed paragraph 21b (1) (b). Proposed subsection 21b of the legislation sets out the nature of the application that is required, including a business plan. The Authority, in considering the application, must have regard to proposed section 21c of the legislation. In assessing the application, the Authority may, if it considers it necessary, refer the business plan to a suitably qualified person for the assessment of the plan's financial viability-proposed new section 21d.

The TCFDA must consider each application as soon as practicable after receipt and must report to the Minister on all applications for capitalisation grants-proposed section 21c (1). The decision of the Minister on the grant must be conveyed to the applicant, including the recommendation of the TCFDA and its reasons-proposed section 21e (1) and (3)-and must be notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, proposed section 21g (1) and (2).

The assessment and recommendatory process will be highly transparent and provide applicants with an opportunity to consider the success or otherwise of their own and other applications for capitalisation grants. Further, given the facility for public scrutiny of this process, all applicants should be assured of timely and equitable treatment.

Finally, all Opposition members who spoke in the debate raised concerns about double dipping. The assurance sought concerning a control on double dipping, via sale perhaps, or bankruptcy, is in fact the subject of the Government's proposed amendment in the committee stage. Once a grant is taken, there will be no further entitlement to a bounty by the grant recipient, and any subsequent purchaser of the assets the subject of the grant will not be able to claim bounty on production generated by these assets.

The capitalisation proposal in this Bill gives persons the alternative of continuing under the present bounty assistance arrangements or opting for a one-off up-front grant. Recipients of capitalisation grants will be disqualified from future yarn bounty entitlements-proposed section 21h. In such cases, those persons will operate without tariff and bounty assistance.

Additionally, via the amendment which is to be moved in the committee stage, bounty entitlement is to be denied anyone on the production of particular textile yarns from assets which are identified as essential to achieving the nominated objectives of a grant recipient's business plan. As implementation of the plan is the purpose of the grant, the additional disentitlement will ensure that the benefits of capitalisation in terms of budgetary savings from bounty forgone are not lost to the Commonwealth simply because essential production capacity of one the subject of a grant is sold or otherwise transferred to another who is not-proposed new section 5 (5) (ba) contained in amendment No. 1 of the Government's proposed amendments.

I would like at this point to place on record my appreciation of the efforts of the honourable member for Barker who has taken the opportunity to have a number of briefings with officers of the Australian Customs Service. The Government's amendments arise out of those discussions. I think they have been fruitful discussions and I hope that this Bill now meets all people's requirements.
Amendment negatived.

Although this Bill was introduced into the Parliament only last week, in fact the proposed Bill was the subject of several briefings with the Opposition in the week prior to that, in particular, with the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the shadow Minister for industry and commerce. As a result of those briefings, the Government has accepted the concern expressed by the Opposition that the Bill does not completely protect the Commonwealth from the possibility of having to outlay money for a capitalisation grant, and then, subsequently, having to outlay additional money for a legitimate bounty claim in respect of bountiable production for that which the grant was meant to disentitle.

As I mentioned in the second reading speech on this Bill, the capitalisation grant scheme is predicated on the basis that capitalisation of bounty will exclude from bounty entitlement not only a person who capitalises a bounty entitlement, but also any subsequent purchaser of the capitalised business. The object of such a disentitlement is to clearly ensure that the benefits of capitalisation in terms of budgetary savings from bounty forgone are not lost to the Commonwealth simply because production by one person is taken over by another, or because production capacity of one the subject of a grant is merely sold to another who is not.

The Bill as introduced attempted to achieve the objective of protecting the Commonwealth's bounty saving by focusing on identified essential assets, that is, assets which are essential to achieving the nominated objectives of the business plan, the implementation of which was the purpose of the grant. The Bill in proposed section 21f forbids dealing with the identified assets without ministerial approval. Breach of that prohibition renders the capitalisation grant repayable in full.

The Government accepts the point which the Opposition has raised on this provision that if the original grant recipient gets into serious financial trouble and sells some or all of the identified essential assets, the Commonwealth's right of recovery of the capitalisation grant might, in fact, be worth very little. Accordingly, it is proposed by these amendments that the ministerial control over the identified essential assets be strengthened by an additional provision denying bounty entitlement to anyone who uses such an identified asset to produce textile yarn. For this purpose it is proposed that a public register of identified assets be created and maintained by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority as part of its administrative functions under the capitalisation grants scheme, to which proposed amendments (2) and (3) refer, and that the bounty eligibility provision in section 5 of the Act be amended to exclude a producer from entitlement to receive a payment of bounty in respect of bountiable yarn produced using such assets, to which amendment (1) refers. I commend the amend-ment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the outlays mentioned by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) in introducing Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1989-90 was an amount of $23.5m. This was set aside to assist in the recovery of the tourist industry. I believe that the allocation is a recognition by this Government of the harm done to the tourist industry by the air pilots dispute which, I would suggest, was an unwarranted dispute. It also stresses that this Government recognises the need to particularly assist the States to try to recover their tourist industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The expenditure is part of a national strategy to accelerate the recovery of the vital foreign currency earning tourist industry. Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1989-90 provides another $7.8m, and again this is mainly to assist tourism in the States. If those figures are added together, the total is $31.3m, which is a significant allocation to a particular industry across this nation, but it is warranted. It will be direct assistance in hard cash terms, and those people who have had a chance to talk to our entrepreneurs and State officials in the tourist industry would realise how important this expenditure will be. The allocation is understandable because of the broad and national economic importance of the tourist industry.

I took the time to extract some figures which highlight how important is this industry in dollar terms. In 1989 international tourism to Australia generated $6.1 billion-$6,000m-in foreign exchange earnings. It has become our nation's number one export earner, so its importance tends to rise up the scale in comparison. In 1988-89 tourism generated expenditure totalled $22.5 billion, and $15.3 billion of this amount can be attributed to domestic tourism.

It is estimated that last financial year the tourist industry contributed 5.6 per cent to gross domestic product. It is a major money earner for Australia, for regional Australia, and for every small locality in Australia that has something to sell in tourist terms. It is also a major employer. I point out that 5.8 per cent of the work force is found in the tourist industry, and that currently accounts for 442,000 jobs spread across Australia, not just in the capital cities or the major provincial cities but spread across Australia in every locality. It is an important generator of job positions. In 1988-89, 18,000 new jobs were created by tourism and, as honourable members would appreciate, particularly those who represent the provincial cities and country areas, it generates jobs in a very decentralised way. It is contributing to thousands of local economies across the nation.

I repeat that it does not matter where one lives in this country, some component of the local economy relates back to tourism. It is providing jobs for people from every working age group and from all the socioeconomic and educational levels. It creates jobs for those who are highly skilled and those who are under-skilled. It creates hundreds and thousands of associated jobs, not just in terms of the direct tourist industry, but also those that are ancillary to it, such as the service industries, parts and repairs industries, advertising, media, and food production. One could list item after item, category after category, where jobs have been created and are being created this very day. New jobs mean fewer unemployed Australians, greater productivity, and that, instead of drawing down on the welfare state of the nation, more people are contributing to the tax pool or tax revenue.

It is estimated that $2.7 billion came from the tourist industry in indirect taxes last financial year. In relation to the bricks and mortar investment, it has boosted the building and construction industry right across the nation. As at December 1989 the value of major tourist projects under construction or, one could add, the firmly committed projects, was worth $19.4 billion. It is interesting to note that this investment has increased by 0.5 per cent on the September 1989 figure. Perhaps 0.5 per cent does not sound much but, when one considers the impact of the pilots dispute and the sorts of things that were being said by the Opposition as to how the industry was being devastated because of the pilots dispute, 0.5 per cent is significant.

These are important statistics because they demonstrate the fact that tourism has an exciting future. As I said, it is an industry that was hurt severely by the pilots dispute, but it is quickly recovering. The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures show that in comparison with January 1989 the number of short-term visitor arrivals in January 1989 in fact increased by 4 per cent. I was surprised when I read those figures because, with all the hype that had been going on, I thought there had been a devastation in the industry but, when one compares January to January, there has been a 4 per cent increase in short term visitor arrivals, which was mainly brought about by a significant increase from Asian countries such as Taiwan, where the number of short term visitors has increased by 191 per cent; from China, 157 per cent; from Hong Kong, 144 per cent; and from Singapore, 96 per cent. It is pleasing to note that Qantas Airways Ltd is expanding its interests in the areas of South East Asia and Asia generally.

There is an encouraging story also from our traditional market of Japan where the increase was 29 per cent on January 1989. Again, I thought that the industry had been devastated but, again, when one looks at the figures comparing 1989 January date with 1990 January date, we have an increase, even from the traditional market of Japan, of almost 30 per cent. The pilots dispute caused a severe impact, but that impact is dissipating and I am confident that the decreases we experienced in visitors from the United Kingdom, Ireland, Europe, the United States of America (USA), Canada and New Zealand can be reversed. I am also confident that Australia will continue to grow in importance as an educational destination. Again comparing January 1989 to January 1990, there has been a 20 per cent increase in the use of Australia as an educational destination.

Another category that is worth looking at is business travel, which has also experienced an increase of 4 per cent, or a 4 per cent growth. The international fall that did take place from the areas I mentioned such as Europe and the USA I believe were offset by domestic tourist growth in many areas. Entrepreneurs in my own area were able to tell me how their numbers were up even during the pilots dispute. This came about mainly because people decided to drive rather than fly. They decided that they could travel within that eight hours or day's drive. That meant that they came to Central Queensland, the southern parts of the Great Barrier Reef, the Great Keppel Island regions, and the sapphire fields of central Queensland. I am told that the same thing occurred in many parts of Australia that were within eight hours of the capital and major provincial cities.

However, I think also that it is part of a new realisation among Australians that some great holidays are to be had in what we might term our own backyards. So, whilst we look at the negatives of the pilots dispute, we need to come back and weigh up the positives, which surely must first and foremost be that realisation that Australia is a magnificent, beautiful tourist destination which can be enjoyed just as much by Australians as by our overseas visitors, as welcome as they are. People have started to travel Australia and they are doing so more now, because, during that pilots dispute, they realised that it is worth going to those places.

In 1988-89 Australian residents aged 14 and over undertook 46 million trips of at least one night's duration. That is slightly down on the previous year but, when one considers the fact that we had such a huge drop in flights, that is understandable. During this period there were 214 million nights away from home, which again is big dollar terms in the tourist industry. Considering the length of the pilots dispute, I suggest that there has been a minute decrease in trips and night stays. When one looks at those figures, one sees that they are down 1.3 per cent which, as I stress, is a minute decrease.

I believe that the January figures signal a positive boost for the tourist industry. The growth is encouraging and it is proper that the Government, this Hawke Government, is acting to build on the good year's start that we had in January, February and March. I certainly welcome the investment of the $31.3m that this Government has appropriated, mainly through the States, to boost the state industries. We need to take advantage of the new interest in Australia among Australians.

In the few moments I have left I want to put forward five, I believe, basic recommendations that can assist. First and foremost we need to give greater emphasis to a regional approach to promotion. I argue that moneys need to be allocated for the Australian market and that this money be allocated on a regional promotional basis. We should experiment with regional super tourist destinations and, obviously, being a parochial person, I would argue that central Queensland, the land of Capricornia, is an ideal place to start. Those regions such as Capricornia need money to be given directly to their regionally based promotional groups.

At the moment we have a system whereby one must go through the States. I understand the issue of States rights and the importance of promoting an area on a State basis. Having been in the State Parliament, I also see the advantages of sometimes breaking expenditure down even on an more decentralised, parochial basis.

John Brown, a previous Minister for tourism, was prepared to pursue that concept following a conference he attended in Yeppoon in central Queensland. He was prepared to look at it for Tasmania and all places in central Queensland, but unfortunately nothing came of it at that time. Under previous governments in Queensland, the State approach meant that areas were left out. Regrettably, my area of Capricornia and central Queensland were certainly left out.

It was not so long ago, in 1988, that a brochure was produced in which it was claimed that Rockhampton was the gateway to Hamilton Island. Hamilton Island is a beautiful place and I recommend every person listening to this debate to go there, but I argue rather strongly that Rockhampton is not exactly the gateway to Hamilton Island. Mackay might be. Whilst we have Ansett Airlines flights going from Rockhampton to Hamilton Island, one still should not promote it as the gateway as such. In a similar vein, another brochure said that Brisbane was the gateway to the sapphire fields of central Queensland. Whoever prepared those promotions did not understand much about local geography.

There is a need to rely on the locals to work out the promotions. I argue that that can best be done if the promotional money-moneys needed for regional promotional material, for media advertising-is given to the local regional promotional organisations. I have advanced the idea, and I do it again tonight, that, if we were to give a quarter of a million dollar grant to central Queensland, this would readily be matched by the locals. It would be very good expenditure.

It could be matched by the regional bureaus, the chambers of commerce, the private entrepreneurs, the airlines, the carriers and the local governments-all of whom are interested in looking after their own. It could in fact double Federal government spending by taking a more regional approach. It would allow for local expertise in promotion. More importantly, it would assist the economies of regional Australia, and that is good for decentralisation and spreading out jobs.

My second recommendation is that we ensure that the national and international promotions that take place incorporate places other than Sydney, the Gold Coast and Ayers Rock. I know that Sydney is a wonderful place, that Ayers Rock is unique and that the Gold Coast is a great place to go for a holiday, but they are not the only parts of Australia. When one looks at some of the promotional material, that is all one sees. That is where the Japanese want to go and that is what the Americans hear about. We need to give greater emphasis to the magnificent tourist destinations that exist in regional Australia.

My third point is that, in terms of attracting tourists, we need to target Asia. There are 176 million Indonesians and 17 million Malaysians who, I am told, have a higher annual income than Australians. There are some 3.5 million Singaporeans, many of who are very wealthy. I am told that some 20 million Indians receive incomes equal to $A50,000 per year. There would be much value in targeting these countries. In the last 12 months we have started to see the great increases in the number of people coming from these countries. But they need to feel wanted. They need to be encouraged. There needs to be a national and coordinated State campaign into Asia and South East Asia.

My next point relates to the incentives for students to learn Asian languages. We need to have special Austudy allowances to encourage young people to undertake studies in other languages, particularly Indonesian, Japanese and other languages of Asia. We need to give assistance to teachers to undertake language studies and to upgrade their language skills. There ought to be courses. Having been an ex-teacher, I would argue that it ought to be compulsory for teachers to undertake a dual language course at teachers' college. We must have greater encouragement in the primary and secondary school fields.

Recently I was told that the Northern Territory has now introduced Indonesian into its primary schools. This is a wonderful thing. I know that many schools in Queensland are teaching Japanese at primary and secondary school levels. That is where we must start. We must get the young ones when they first enter school. It is important that we have this language objective, this language aim. Just as we are saying that we will have one billion trees planted in the next decade, we ought to have a target that a million Australians shall learn a second language by 1995 and three million by the turn of the twenty-first century. Again, I emphasise that those languages should centre on particularly Indonesian and Japanese.

My final point in the few moments I have left relates to the cost of travel in this country. Not so long ago a staff member told me that it was cheaper for her to go to Fiji for seven days than it was to travel from Rockhampton to Cairns and spend a long weekend there. I realise that the deregulation of the airlines will change a lot of this, but we need to do far more. The airlines have to be encouraged to start to compete domestically.

When I was in America last year I spoke to some of the Qantas Airways Ltd officials. They argued that the problem was that they could get the people to come to Australia because of our magnificent attractions but that when they got here the internal costs of travel were exorbitant. Again, we need to promote travel in Australia.

I wonder how many Australians realise that one can get an all-around-Australia ticket. The airlines do not seem to promote it very well. But one can get a ticket that allows one to go virtually all around Australia as long as one keeps going in the one direction. We need to argue for cheaper fares. I pulled out some figures tonight and found that the cost of a Sydney to Perth trip was $528 but that Sydney to Fiji was $542.

I spoke to a parliamentary staffer tonight and was told that she is going to Hawaii on a seven-day, six-night trip with all accommodation included for $1,100. I doubt that one could go to Cairns for very long on that amount of money. There is a need to target the cost of domestic travel in this country. The responsibility must be picked up by the domestic airlines. But we, as a government, and the States must give encouragement.

In closing, I congratulate the Government for the energy that its Ministers have demonstrated in promoting Australian tourism. I particularly cite J. J. Brown for the work that he did, for the foundation that he established. I also congratulate Senator Graham Richardson for his endeavours during some difficult times. He was the relevant Minister during the pilots dispute. I am confident that the new Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) will continue the standard. We must constantly tell ourselves that there are dollars to be earned, that there are jobs to be created and that there is an international reputation to be established. We need to give the money where it is needed and where it will be best used-and that is certainly tourism.
