TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 I wish to draw the House's attention to the appropriation of $90.5m to the Australian Federal Police (AFP). Such a significant expenditure recognises that, even though we are faced with financially tough times, we are also faced with a dramatically rising crime rate and our society demands and needs a well funded police force. Decisions are, however, now being made which will lead to a further increase in this crime rate and which will make the current allocation of moneys totally inadequate. I am referring to the proposed establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT).

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps lured by the prospect of easy money, many have forgotten the problems associated with such establishments and have concentrated on the pot of gold, which they mistakenly believe will be there for the taking. Mr Brian Bates, the Assistant Commissioner in charge of the ACT region of the Australian Federal Police, summed up the dangers of the proposed Canberra casino in the select committee on the casino inquiry held by the Legislative Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory in July 1989. Mr Bates said:

The AFP believes that the proposal to operate a casino in Canberra presents a potential for increase in criminal acts in this Territory. For example, it may be expected that there will be an increase in prostitution to cater for a certain element of the anticipated clientele. There may be an influx of professional gamblers, cheats and interstate criminals and their associates, and that premises are likely to be used as a money-laundering facility.

The AFP would also expect to be consulted on the developers' and licensees' suitability before approval is given as well as on the suitability of all persons under contract who are not directly involved in running the casino. In addition to sophisticated internal security which will no doubt be installed, adequate police contingency plans will be required to counter and react to large-scale armed holdup activity. There will be a continuing role for police in assisting the proper monitoring of employees and managerial appointments. All this will require the provision of additional AFP manpower. Accordingly, it is the AFP's view that if the community wants a casino, then that community needs to be aware of the potential for the further development of already existing problems such as prostitution, alcohol, drug abuse, general street offences, misbehaviour types of offences, assaults and robberies and thefts.

Mr Lloyd Worthy, the Commander of the Australian Capital Territory Crime Division, ACT region, in this same select committee estimated that it would cost approximately $5m per annum to police the casino development. That is an extra $5m of taxpayers' money that will need to be allocated to the AFP's appropriation should the proposed casino get off the ground. Regrettably, there was little done at that time to bring these and other AFP concerns about the proposed casino to the attention of the Canberra community.

The American study entitled `Casino Gambling as a Growth Pole Strategy and its Effect on Crime' published in the Journal of Regional Science in 1989, I believe, supports the AFP statements. The study highlights the fact that crimes in Atlantic City, New Jersey, were running at 100.6 per 1,000 people in 1977 when the casinos commenced operation. In 1984 the figure had increased to 353.7 per 1,000 people. It should be noted that for the same period the average rate in the State of New Jersey fell from 50.9 to 48.4 crimes per 1,000 people, providing a most disturbing contrast. Sadly, Atlantic City now has one of the highest crime rates in the United States.

The Cain Labor Government in my own State of Victoria has publicly stated that it will not allow casinos to open in that state. It has opted instead for a form of gambling called the tabaret. The first of what will be many such ventures is due to open later this year based in the hotel complex of the Menzies at Rialto. The gambling facilities will be controlled by the Victorian Totalisator Agency Board (TAB), with the food and drink provided by Federal Hotels which, of course, already has its Australian headquarters conveniently located at the hotel. The gambling will be via 220 computerised video gaming machines which will be operated by the customer inserting a pre-paid plastic card similar to the credit card into the device. This allows the player to win money on video games such as golf, football, basketball and racing. For instance, in the football game players can elect to kick a ball at the goal post. They bet on how close they will come to the goal once they have selected the distance and angle they will kick from. The video games will continue to operate for as long as the player's plastic card has a credit balance. The player can stop playing at any time, take his or her card to the cashier, and collect either winnings or the value of the unused portion of the card.

The Cain Labor Government has gone to great lengths to state that these machines are not poker machines, which Premier Cain will not permit in Victoria. The TAB's General Manager, Mr Bill Roffey, is quoted in the Sunday Age of 17 December 1989 as dismissing suggestions that the video machines are poker machines. Roffey claims that there are significant differences. Poker machines are developed around plums, cherries and spinning reels, whereas these machines are based upon a sequence in a game or sport. The only similarity is that in both games players have lost money. The only trouble with these statements is that they conflict with the findings of a 1983 State Government inquiry into poker machines. The inquiry, entitled `Board of Inquiry Into Poker Machines' and chaired by Mr Murray Wilcox, QC, arrived at a number of important conclusions. In section 2.21, entitled `The Future-Video Games', Mr Wilcox says in part:

It is clear from a technological point of view that microprocessor technology is readily available to design a multiplicity of slot machine games using video screens instead of spinning reels. Indeed there are already available `poker machines' which, instead of using spinning mechanical reels, display simulated spinning reels on a colour video machine . . . It is a short step from there to machines which play various other games upon the insertion of a coin either with or without the subsequent manipulation of a handle.
Wilcox suggests a statutory definition of a poker machine in section 2.36 of this report, which reads:
`Gaming machine' means any machine, device or contrivance, the operation of which determines the outcome of a game of chance or skill and chance played for money or money's worth.

The Wilcox definition seems to describe more than adequately the tabaret's video machines. The Cain Government has therefore quietly overturned the findings of this report in a very neat exercise of gross duplicity. All new legislation in Victoria impacting substantially on the community is required to have an environmental impact statement before it is passed. The Cain Government, when it decided that video machines were not really poker machines, found it could use the Racing Act of 1958-specifically division V, part V-to introduce tabarets. As it is existing legislation, the Cain Government will not be required to conduct an environmental impact statement or, for that matter, any other form of in-depth inquiry. Perhaps Mr Cain and his Ministers need to be reminded of the social impact Wilcox believed such gambling would have on the community. In his words, it is a:

. . . certainty that some Victorians will use the machines to gamble to an extent which is beyond their financial capacity and that many will gamble to an extent which causes them serious concern. Some of these persons may, in any event and by other means, gamble excessively but, for most, the critical factors would be the nature and availability of poker machines. The proportion of all Victorians who would gamble excessively upon poker machines would be extremely small, but the effect upon some of these individuals and their families would be catastrophic.
As the centres will be opened under the Racing Act of 1958 there will again be no environmental impact statement required. Mr Cain's duplicity is compounded even further.

As with all Cain Government forays into commerce, there seems to be little precision about the costs and expected returns of the project. Premier Cain announced on 8 December 1987 that the total cost of the Tabaret project will be $14m, including the cost of providing the high technology equipment and the alterations and refurbishment required to the premises. Mr Cain stated there would be no cost to the taxpayer. In 1990 the Victorian Auditor-General found that the Tabaret's capital costs were almost $20m and he expected the project to cost $25m by the time it opened-a sum vastly different from Mr Cain's $14m. Premier Cain announced in 1987 that he expected the revenue from the city Tabaret in the first year to be $60m. The then Chairman of the TAB, Mr Rob Nordlinger, estimated the Tabaret's turnover in the first year at $72m. The most interesting figure is, however, the one given by the man credited with the Tabaret idea, Mr Steve Crabb, at that stage the Labour Minister in the Cain Government. Mr Crabb is reported in the Melbourne Sun of 20 July 1987 as saying:
It is believed the new sports betting complex could bring in up to $150m a year, an optimistic figure quoted by Labour Minister Mr Crabb based on estimated gambling from a fully-fledged casino.

Mr Crabb's estimate, which differs enormously from that of Mr Cain and Mr Nordlinger, gives rise to several questions: Firstly, if the Tabaret is not a casino, why the decision to base potential revenue on that of a casino? Secondly, does this mean a study has been conducted into the potential for a casino in Victoria? Thirdly, if such a study exists, when was it done, who conducted it, who commissioned it, and where is it?

I refer now to an article in the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 7 May 1990, headed `Family Philanthropic to Tal Investors'. The article states that Tal Holdings, a company which is controlled by Mr Greg Farell, who is also the Chairman of Tal's subsidiary, Federal Hotels, has stated it will become the operator of at least two, and possibly three, additional casinos in the future. One of these two or three extra casinos would probably be the strange casino project approved by the Hawke Labor Government for Christmas Island. Where are the others to be? Is it possible that the Cain Government is considering converting the tabaret in the future to a fully fledged high technology casino and Federal Hotels perceive this as an addition to its stable in one form or another? Returning momentarily to the Canberra situation, does this also mean that Federal Hotels, which has tendered for the proposed casino, has already been given the nod even before tenders have been properly evaluated? It certainly is an interesting question as to where these additional casinos will ultimately eventuate.
In discussing the Victorian tabaret, it is important to note another of the findings of the Wilcox report, which stated:

[ . . . there is . . .] the certainty of increased criminal activity in Victoria as a direct result of the introduction of poker machines. The extent of the likely increase depends upon two factors: the number of premises in which the machines are permitted-
and of course the Victorian Government is planning on having a large number of tabarets-

and the stringency of the controls imposed. Depending on these factors crime will increase to a degree ranging from significant to serious. There is not merely a risk of increased crime. Under any scenarios crime will increase.

The tabarets are not yet open for business but the criminal element has already emerged in respect of poker machines in Victoria. I am advised that the firm Olympic Video Gaming Pty Ltd was given ministerial approval in late 1987 to manufacture video amusement and poker machines in Victoria. Olympic has lobbied for the introduction of its poker machines into AFL football clubs in Victoria and at one point had a similar interest in respect of the Tabaret. The firm is also now in the process of commencing operations in Queensland and yet the following facts should have caused Premier Cain to pause before the approval was granted and for the Goss Labor Government in Queensland to exercise caution about Olympic.

Mr Nick Balagiannis, managing director of Olympic Video Gaming Pty Ltd, has, among many other interesting things, convictions in the Melbourne magistrates court during 1986 for: smuggling, producing untrue documents and making false statements, with these convictions all relating to gaming machines.

In conclusion, it is my belief that the proposed introduction of the casino in Canberra and the opening of the tabaret in Melbourne will be at a great social cost to these respective communities. Premier Cain, by seeking to introduce the tabarets in Victoria without full and proper public consideration and in such an underhand manner, is doing a disservice to all Victorians and needs to be brought to task for his actions. He also has certain compelling questions to answer about the Tabaret, its intended future nature and the peculiar approval given to Olympic to manufacture in Victoria. I seek leave to table copies of various conviction orders recorded against Mr Balagiannis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset I ask you to convey my congratulations to the Speaker and his Deputy. I also congratulate you and the other Deputy Chairmen of Committees.
—The House recalls the distinction with which you held this position.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. You are too kind. I also congratulate all the new members on their election and the members who have been here before on their re-election. Having got that formality out of the way, I welcome the opportunity to speak in this Appropriation debate and, as usual, will exercise the opportunity, which most members take, to range widely over issues.

SPEECH.PARA: At the last election the Illawarra region once more returned four Labor members. This was not only a reflection on the very strong representation by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West), the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and-dare I say it-the honourable member for Throsby, who have given so much to the people of the region, but also it reflected the realisation by the people of the Illawarra that if our conservative opponents were elected to office the people of the Illawarra would receive an extra dose of what we in the Illawarra have come to call Greinerism.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be familiar with the Illawarra area, your electorate being quite close to it. No area in Australia has been singled out for more savage treatment by any government than the Illawarra has received at the hands of the New South Wales Government. There is a long list of closures of government services in the area. The Greiner Government selects an area, such as the Illawarra Welfare Rights Service of the Illawarra Legal Resource Centre, and decides without consultation or notification to close the Service in the expectation that the Federal Government will pick up the funding. The State Government has done this repeatedly with State services, services that are the responsibility of the States to fund and, indeed, services that the States in the past have always agreed to fund. There is a whole list of such services: child-care services, legal rights services, workers' health services and women's centres. The States have agreed to consultation with the Federal Government to pick up the funding for these services and now, often in the middle of a financial year, the State withdraws funding and expects or demands that the Federal Government pick up the tab.

The very latest example of this, which affects not only the Illawarra but the whole State of New South Wales, is the teachers' pay issue. The teachers have put in a very justifiable claim. The New South Wales Education Minister has offered a slight pay increase but the expectation is that the Federal Government will pick up the tab for the funding. This is out- rageous. No-one argues more strongly than I that the teachers have a justifiable claim but if the Federal Government funds the differential in teachers' pay what will stop all government employees demanding-and rightly-the same? The nurses, the police and the firemen, if the Federal Government steps in and makes up the difference between what the State Government has offered and what the teachers are demanding, will demand the same.

It is not only through this lack of funding that the Greiner Government is attempting to punish the people of the Illawarra. Over the past few years the Port Kembla Harbour Task Force has worked tirelessly to re-invigorate the Port of Kembla so it can take its place as an export development port. In this regard it has worked very closely with the farmers of the central west, especially in the Eugowra area. It is a project that has the full support of the Illawarra population. It was successful in getting the new grain terminal for Port Kembla. We hope that the New South Wales Government does not sell it off, as it has recently sold off the coal loader, which the Federal Government put $20m into. We also put $18.7m into the grain terminal. If the State Government attempts to sell off that grain terminal, I for one will be asking for that Federal money to be returned to the people of the Illawarra so that we can spend it on other areas.

The one thing stopping the port from reaching its full potential is the lack of adequate transport infrastructure. One of the first acts of vandalism of the Greiner Government when it came to power was to cease work on the Maldon-Dombarton rail link at the very time when, at long last, people were starting to realise the importance of rail.

As if this were not enough, the New South Wales Greiner Government refuses to nominate a replacement road for the notorious Macquarie pass for funding under the Federal Government's national arterial road program and even the recently announced rural and provincial cities program. If it nominated we could have a replacement road built there within 18 months which would contribute greatly to the development of the port of Kembla as an export port. I was delighted today, as I know the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) would have been delighted, with the announcement regarding funding for the Pacific Highway, for which the honourable member has long campaigned.

I am pleased that transport will take a high profile during this session. That was one of the reasons I was so anxious to get on to some of the transport committees with my good friend the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), who has done sterling work in this regard. I suspect that during this parliamentary session rail will come into its own, which is a long overdue step. It is a great pity that, as I said before, the Greiner Government, as one of its first acts of vandalism, cut the Maldon-Dombarton link.

Rail is the cheapest and most effective way of transporting freight on long deliveries. The Hume Highway runs through my electorate and, along with the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and other honourable members, I am horrified at the trucks trundling along it every day. These trucks go through places like Goulburn and Mittagong, trucks carrying freight that really should be and could be on rail. Sometimes when I see all these trucks going up and down the Hume Highway I have the nightmarish feeling that maybe they are loaded with exactly the same commodity, with one lot of the commodity going from Sydney to Melbourne and the other lot going from Melbourne to Sydney, trucks carrying exactly the same commodity and passing on the way.

It is my belief that governments of all political persuasions-from my side of the House or from the other side of the House-both State and Federal, have neglected rail for far too long. They are all guilty of letting the rail services in this country decline and now, as a result, all these trucks are on the roads, cutting them to pieces. The Government has been criticised very strongly by the honourable member for Cowper, and other members, of course, for not putting more money into roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite rightly.

—The honourable member says quite rightly, but I suggest, with the greatest respect, that if we could take some of those trucks of the road-I am not saying all trucks, because there will always be a place for trucks on the road-and put some of that freight on to rail, where it rightly belongs, the money that is being used mainly to repair the damage done to roads by trucks could be used to build new roads. Of course, there will always be a debate about whether the Government is spending enough money on the roads or whether more should be spent, and the point of view always depends on which side of the House one sits on.

SPEECH.PARA: The money that is being put into the roads today is mainly being used to repair the damage that the trucks are doing to our roads. What we need in this country is new roads and better roads. A truck does one thousand times more damage to the roads than the ordinary motorist does.

All motorists are subsidising the heavy freight industry in Australia. As I have said before, my brother is a truckie and my father had a truck transporting business for many years. If the road freight industry paid the real cost of transporting that freight by road, there would be absolutely no argument about which form of transport is the cheaper; of course, it would be rail. A rail network is in place all round Australia and governments should be putting a lot more money back into rail. Last year I served on a committee that was looking at the east-west freight corridor and the idea of transporting freight across Australia by rail. Another thing that governments must consider is a completely integrated transport network.

I cannot understand why at the moment Australia's major ports are stuck in the middle of the nation's largest cities. It seems to me absolutely ludicrous that we are taking container ships into Glebe, an inner suburb of Sydney, and the container terminal at Port Botany. The result is that freight such as wool and hides is trundled from Yennora across the city to Botany. It is ridiculous to do that. We should be doing what has been done in some European countries, where they have established completely new ports.

One place where this has been done is Port Kembla, although it is not a new port. If we could develop Port Kembla as a roll-on roll-off container port, with adequate road and rail networks to that port, we could forget the business of taking containers to Sydney. At present a lot of freight from Port Kembla is taken by road to Sydney and then exported by sea and incoming freight comes by sea to Sydney and is then trucked down the highway to Port Kembla. In my view, that is absolute stupidity .

We should have an adequate transport infrastructure, which would involve rail taking its rightful place as the premier way of transporting heavy freight over long distances. That is what I am talking about. I am not talking about short haul deliveries. I am not saying that there is no place for road haulage. Of course, there will always be a place for trucks on our roads. But I think all governments have allowed rail to decline far too much and I am pleased to perceive ever so slightly a realisation in this Parliament that rail must come back into its own. It is my hope that rail will have its rightful place as the premier way of transporting heavy freight over long distances in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I agree with a fair amount of what the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has been saying; in particular, I agree with him when he says that there will be an increasing emphasis on transport in this Parliament. I believe he is absolutely right. I, of course, as you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker and other honourable members know, have been for five years or more advocating the upgrading of the Pacific Highway to a four-lane dual carriageway divided highway. So far as I am concerned, today is an historic day, because there has been a bipartisan agreement between the Federal Minister for Land Transport, (Mr Robert Brown), and the New South Wales Minister for Transport, the Hon. Bruce Baird. It is a very significant day indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: What I have been campaigning for for more than five years is to have the concept accepted that the Pacific Highway between Hexham and the Queensland border must be a four-lane dual carriageway divided highway for the benefit of all Australians-not just for the people of northern New South Wales. It is the premier link on the east coast of Australia. It is significant that only last week I presented petitions to this Parliament with 45,454 signatures, asking this Parliament and the Government to provide more funding.

Of course, I am absolutely delighted that we have reached this historic occasion today. It is historic because, if you look at what the Opposition-the coalition parties-tried to do and the policies we advocated in the last and the most recent election campaign, we said that we would be prepared in conjunction with New South Wales to provide $1.2 billion over the next 10 years to upgrade the Pacific Highway. By the announcement put out today by the State and Federal Ministers, an amount of $1 billion has been promised over the next 10 years.

So you might understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is with a great deal of joy that I stand here, seeing that not only my efforts, but also those of many people on the north coast of New South Wales, my parliamentary colleagues from the region, the former members for Richmond and Page and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) all working with me, have achieved this result. It is a great result that has come out of those efforts and I pay tribute to all the people on the north coast of New South Wales who have supported me in this campaign. Tonight we are discussing the Appropriation and Supply Bills. Listening to the debate I find there has not been a great deal of detail spoken about the Bills before the House. I refer to the Department of Finance Information Paper and Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (No. 1) and (No. 2) of 1989-90. For instance, there was a total budget for legal aid initially of $3,550,000, but there will be a saving of $300,000 of that, which, I suppose, is a good thing when looked at in isolation. I think one of the great shortcomings we have in this country is the affordability of recourse to the law for ordinary citizens. It seems to me that people have either to be very rich or very poor or they cannot go to the law about anything. If people are very rich and have the resources to pay for their own legal advice and go to court, that is fine. I move on to education. I want to close by talking very briefly about education. I shall refer to one particular facet. I would like to read just briefly from the notes of that meeting which portray the concern of these workers and the conditions under which they had been employed for up to 18 months in the zone. This was an agreement which had been negotiated and which came into force in September 1989, an agreement in which the Trade Development Zone Authority, in other words the Northern Territory Government, was to act as the agent for the companies wishing to make use of the scheme. TALK.START.PARA: —May I begin by congratulating you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your appointment to the position you now hold. I will be grateful if you could pass my congratulations on also to the Speaker on his election to that position, a closely fought contest.

—I want to talk about these Bills that are before the House, in particular, two aspects of Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation Bill (No. 3). In one case they are an indictment in general of the policies of intervention. SPEECH.PARA: In Appropriation Bill (No. 4) there is an item which asks for $15.6m to be paid for outstanding debts to what was incurred by the International Tin Council. These are debts that have been acquired by each of the 22 tin producing member countries of the International Tin Council as a result of the ITC's failed attempt to manipulate the tin market and hold floor prices up until 1985. The interesting thing about this particular exercise, which in this legislation is costing the Australian taxpayer alone $15.6m and taxpayers from other countries similar amounts, is that it underlines and emphasises the problems of trying to hold floor prices in a depressed market. It is a lesson that should be learnt in a whole range of other industries which operate on that basis.

These sorts of schemes, as members of the House would be aware, are as old as history. In this particular case the International Tin Council used to have a fund which it established, as I understand it, from the member countries and companies of that particular tin council. In the early 1980s the international price of tin started to decline. It was forced down because one non-member of the International Tin Council, Brazil, became a very major tin producer. Brazilians saw that the tin price was pretty good; it was a high price. Brazil found that it could produce tin and sell it very efficiently and profitably at that price. Inevitably it increased its output. Over a period its exports increased from 4,000 tonnes to 20,000 tonnes. Interestingly, the International Tin Council had a floor price. While Brazilian production increased very substantially from 4,000 tonnes to 20,000 tonnes the 22 members of the International Tin Council decided that they would have to prop up their floor price. The International Tin Council went into the marketplace to buy up tin in order to maintain the floor price. Consequently, it accumulated a gigantic stockpile. I think I am right in saying that the statutory limit that the Tin Council was supposed to accumulate was something like 63,000 tonnes but its stockpile went above that limit up to 80,000 tonnes.

While all this was happening the Brazilians were thinking to themselves that this tin mining and marketing was becoming so increasingly profitable that they had to keep on producing, which they did. The inevitable consequence of all that was that the Tin Council could no longer afford to maintain its artificial floor price. The floor price finally collapsed because the Tin Council collapsed under a mountain of debt.

Eventually a Government such as ours and our people, the taxpayers, had to pay the bill for the collapse of the Tin Council. It has to be remembered that that policy also put tin consumers at a very substantial disadvantage because, until the collapse of the scheme, those tin consumers ended up by having to buy tin at an artificially high price. So, broadly speaking, consumers ended up being the losers because they paid more for tin than would have been normal under the international price arrangements. So, indeed, the consumers were losers as taxpayers when they had to bail out this failed economically nonsensical scheme. The International Tin Council's attempt reaped a very bitter harvest. The number of companies trading in tin that have been hurt is simply enormous. Some estimates are that around 40 per cent of Malaysian tin companies eventually went broke as a result of this particular scheme.

Since 1985, when the collapse of the International Tin Council occurred, the industry has begun to recover, with prices again beginning to approach what was the old floor level, but what is interesting is that there is a cartel known as the Association of Tin Producers Council, which once more is in the marketplace, not on this occasion by setting floor prices and intervening directly in the market, but by trying to control production and exercising limits on the amounts of production. Some of the major tin producers of the world are not members of the Association of Tin Producers Council and it is only as a result of the goodwill of those non members, in particular China and Brazil, that production has not been increased beyond the levels that are set by the council and consequently prices have remained moderately firm. But the fact is that, if those two major tin producers, China and Brazil, decide to abandon that voluntary arrangement-and it is quite possible they could, because those countries are in desperate need of foreign exchange-then, once more, the tin industry will enter a period of some disruption.

The real point I want to emphasise by drawing the House's attention to the $15.6m that Australian taxpayers are being asked to fork out on this occasion through this legislation is that schemes such as the International Tin Council's cartel are doomed to fail. We all know what happened to the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), yet when Milton Friedman predicted many years ago-I think in 1974 or 1975-that OPEC would eventually collapse, people laughed at him. Of course, like all cartels and like all price fixing arrangements that do not take any notice of market signals and messages, they are doomed to fail. I believe that the lesson of the Tin Council is something that, in the current context of the crisis of the Australian wool industry, all Australians ought to give some attention to.

The second aspect of this package of legislation to which I want to refer is an item in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which asks for $6m of taxpayers money to be paid to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd as a bounty on sensitised film production. This issue of the Kodak bounty was dealt with at some length last year when it was first raised, but it is important that I again draw the attention of the House to the fact that in this legislation ordinary taxpayers are being told that they have to stump up the first $6m. This $6m is part of the Government's three year $36m production bounty to keep Kodak from apparently moving its Coburg operation overseas.

It is interesting to recall that that decision was announced by Senator Button and at the time of that announcement it was described colourfully by the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers as mindbending. This deal amounts to little more, if I may say so, than corporate extortion. A company has gone along to a Government, threatened the Government, and sadly, the Government has simply caved in. It is an example of an Australian Government, yet again, propping up an industry which is inefficient and, as a result of its inefficiency, is forced into a state of decline. Because of the ascendancy of electronic photography or video stills which will replace this sort of technology, the Coburg plant technology will almost certainly be obsolete by the time this deal eventually expires in five years.

I think that all honourable members should try to concentrate on the point that the only manufacturing industries worth having in this country are those which can compete successfully on export markets, or with imports, and they are the industries we should try to encourage, not sunset industries, and not industries which go along to the Government and threaten the Government in a lead-up to an election. Indeed, what is even worse than Kodak's threatening the Government is that the Government actually caved in to that particular threat. I think that brings home the meaning of the expression that Senator Walsh used the other day about the Prime Minister being spineless, because it is noteworthy that at the time this plant was in the Prime Minister's electorate.

Without wishing to appear to be xenophobic, another point that I think is worth emphasising is that the Kodak plant to which we are referring is not an Australian-owned plant but a foreign owned and controlled plant. Whilst I do not favour the Government giving money away by this sort of method to companies of any kind, it is particularly reprehensible that the Government has made the decision to give the money to a foreign company. If it were going to start handing cheques around at the expense of Australian taxpayers, I suppose it would be fairer if that money, since it was financed by Australian taxpayers, were given to an Australian company.

I think that this decision to award this bounty to Kodak demonstrates several important points. First, it vindicates the sort of criticism that Senator Walsh has been making of the Government being pragmatic and spineless. It is no coincidence that this deal was sewn up, as I said already, in the lead-up to the Federal election when the Government apparently was at its most nervous and, in particular, the Prime Minister was at his most nervous, bearing in mind that this plant was in his electorate.

Secondly, this particular financing at the expense of ordinary taxpayers underlies the failure of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and therefore the strategy of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce for a manufacturing export led economic recovery. When one looks at the last month's balance of payments figures and distils all the rhetoric one hears in the community about what is legitimately a catastrophic figure looking at it in absolute terms, one sees that one of the things that were particularly sad about those balance of payments figures was the failure of Australian manufacturing industry to improve its export capacity. I forget the precise figures, but in the last quarter of our balance of payments figures there was a decline of something like 20 per cent in manufacturing exports. If that trend continues, the future of this country is very dim indeed. If the Government thinks that the solution to our balance of payments crisis is to take money from taxpayers, to take away incentive from people by increasing those taxes and by increasing company taxes, and by farming it out to not just American companies but any company which is threatening to leave Australia if it does not get the grant from the Government, the Government is wrong.

Thirdly, Senator Button lacks confidence in his own policies. If ever there was an admission of that, it was this particular initiative by Senator Button and by the Government. It really begs the question: Now that Senator Button's plan for the car industry can be seen to be failing, will similar deals such as this be offered to the Ford Motor Company of Australia Ltd, Nissan Motor Company (Australia) Pty Ltd and General Motors-Holden's Ltd? If one looks at the quote today from the Treasurer's press conference, one wonders all the more. I just remind the House what the Treasurer said outside the entrance to Parliament House today:
Now, in cars, Senator Button wanted to do a private deal with the car companies.

Was that the sort of private deal he wanted to do, and did do, with Kodak? I do not know the answer but, according to the Treasurer, he wanted to do a private deal with car companies through his department, that is, one which was not recommended or examined by the Industry Commission. The Treasurer, and this is one of the rare occasions when I will use this expression, to his credit said, `I told him that was unacceptable'.
The Treasurer also made the point that in 1985 it took 33 weeks to buy an Australian car. That was two years into the Hawke Government. It now takes more than 40 weeks. He went onto say:
We've now got long waiting lists for Australian cars and we have to import them which is a disgrace.

The Treasurer went on to underline how Australia was failing-as I have been saying in this debate today-as a manufacturing nation. In saying that, he was conceding that the Government's and Senator Button's industry policy had been a failure.

In a sense, Senator Button, who is a man given to frankness, admitted this in relation to the Kodak deal. He was so embarrassed by the whole affair that he described it as `an aberration from government policy' and claimed that it would not happen again. The only thing that worried me about that claim that it would not happen again and the admission that this was the wrong thing to do was that Senator Button-it has been revealed by the Treasurer-was in any case very recently trying to negotiate some private deal with car companies.

In setting this precedent of the Kodak case, Senator Button has really opened up some sort of Pandora's box. What criteria could the Government implore when other companies approach it with threats of closure unless bribes are made to keep them here? What will he say when a company which may in fact be quite profitable-and Kodak was making profits-comes along to the Government and says, `Give us $36m over five years and we promise we won't close down'. Maybe it is not thinking of closing down, but the prospect of all this taxpayers' money to be extorted makes it enthusiastic to try to get a share of it. A government should never do that sort of thing. If it does give in to that sort of bribery and that sort of threat, then simply more threats and more bribery of that kind will follow.

What does Senator Button now say to all those Australian companies who have had to close down or relocate overseas because operating costs in this country are prohibitive and because the Government has failed to undertake micro-economic reform? They have closed down; people have lost their jobs; and they did not get $36m.

A textile plant in my electorate is in the process of closing down for economic reasons. It is very hard on the people who work in that factory. But they were not offered $36m or some pro rata amount by the Federal Government because they did not threaten the Government and try to bribe it in the way that Kodak did.

How consistent is this particular initiative with the Government's grant strategy in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations where it is saying, quite rightly, that we have to reduce protection levels, that there has to be a 30 per cent reduction in tariffs and that there has to be the elimination of non-tariff barriers and the like, when the Australian Government is going around giving $36m of taxpayers' money to prop up Kodak? What countries will take Australia seriously if we go on behaving in that sort of way?

To add insult to the very real injury that has been done, in recent days the Bureau of Industry Economics has informed us of what is happening with this particular Kodak factory which has just been propped up with taxpayers' money. It has done a study of Kodak factories in four countries-the United Kingdom, Canada, Brazil and Australia. It is interesting to study labour productivity in the Kodak plant in Australia. I should say `our plant' because it is you, Mr Deputy Speaker, me, everyone in this House, the people in the gallery and the great public of Australia who are paying for this factory to stay in place. Productivity was 83 per cent higher, not in Brazil, Japan or some mega-growth country like Taiwan, but in the British factory. And capital productivity in the British factory was 67 per cent better. Goodness me, Mrs Thatcher has turned that country around. But, heavens, it is a terrible indictment of this Government.

The Bureau suggests that the best way to boost productivity in Australia is, amongst other things, through more flexible working hours and shift arrangements, by giving people on the shop floor more authority and responsibility, and by cutting the inflation rate. Interestingly enough, that is the coalition's policy. The two particular issues that come through in this package of legislation are issues that the Australian public really needs to think about.

The Tin Council underlines the danger of concocting phoney cartel arrangements and trying to rig markets. It always fails. The Kodak deal is the worst sort of action a government can take-to try to prop up inefficient companies and to encourage them to remain inefficient. From the bottom of my heart I really do condemn the Kodak deal and I know my constituents would agree with me.
