SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Appropriation and Supply Bills, which comes to the Parliament at this time each year, tidies up the Government's expenditure program for 1989-90 and provides Supply until 30 November 1990, by which time most new Budget Bills should be in place. Nevertheless, it gives me the opportunity to look at the broad Budget picture and at the economic history of this Government. It is an interesting situation. For instance, we find that in the Budget brought down for the current financial year the people of Australia, as individuals are paying more tax-$51,320m, to be exact-than the total collections of taxation from all sources in the last Fraser Budget. In fact, they are paying some $7 billion more.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers in the current Budget are paying almost as much tax as the total collections of the last year of the Fraser Government. In that year the Fraser Government raised about $44 billion, of which $41 billion was tax. This year PAYE taxpayers are paying some $41 billion in tax themselves. It gives honourable members some idea of the massive growth of tax under the Keating administration as Treasurer.

There are some other interesting points worth noting. One is the growth of tax on superannuation from $7m in the previous year to $885m in the current year. We see that the Government will require some $10,689m for its general purposes in that three months of the new financial year. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) tells us that this is an increase of 7.5 per cent on the comparable period for last year. The tip is, therefore, that both growth and inflation will be of that order. That is the other great problem confronting Australia. Whilst the rest of the world seems to have been able to come to grips with inflation, Australia has not. The situation seems to be getting worse. This of course is a major problem.

We should quickly look at economics under the present Treasurer (Mr Keating). We have had some quite amazing situations. We had that amazing $9 billion deficit-the inherited deficit. I have always wondered why anybody would want to inherit a debt. I always wondered why, having taken over the shop, someone then wanted to blame the previous owner for his borrowing strategy.

Of course, those of us who were present at the time know that of the eventual $8 billion-it was not $9 billion; the Treasurer uses that figure-of overspending in Treasurer Keating's first ever Budget of his own making, there were new spending initiatives of $7 billion, one significant amount being Medicare, which certainly was not promised by the Fraser Government in that particular election. We know that that is costing thousands of millions of taxpayers' dollars today. The Treasurer introduced this myth to meet a different aim. But just taking a bit of insurance, he blamed it on the previous Government. When we look at the Labor policies of the 1983 election, we see that its total economic policy was contained on one fools-cap typewritten page.

The Treasurer did not have too many promises to keep. That may have been to his advantage, but the simple fact is that he was under no obligation to continue any level of deficit that he believed a previous government might have contemplated. He is the one who lectures us about tough decisions. He is the one who could have taken his first tough decision and balanced his first Budget. It would only have taken political will. The economy would not have disappeared because the economy was just growing out of the drought and the international recession that had affected it so badly in that period from 1980 to 1982. Of course, Malcolm Fraser was blamed in that case for bad economic management. The poor fellow did not know how to make it rain-a disgraceful situation.

The reality is that the Treasurer did that deliberately because he was of the belief that he could kick-start the Australian economy by overspending. It was a deliberate mechanism and unfortunately it worked. We are reaping the whirlwind of that overheating of the Australian economy that occurred in the first Keating Budget. He went on in that way, continually into the fourth Budget year, blaming the Opposition, stoking up the economy, but he wanted to add a few extra measures. One day he had a flash of inspiration, not to be found in his one foolscap page of economic policy: he might deregulate the Australian financial system. There had been a lot written about that. A lot of people had said it was a good idea. It is a bit like some other economic theories on taxation we read. He just did it one day. He floated the dollar. He did not know what effect that might have, and I do not know that he cared. It sounded a good idea at the time. Away again went the Australian economy-not on productivity, hard work or savings, but on borrowed money.

It is a funny thing about a national economy. There is only one difference between a Federal Budget and a household budget: the noughts on the end of the figures. All the other rules apply. One borrows money, spends it, accelerates spending and looks rich. People can be employed, even in a household sense. Then comes the fateful day when the lender says, `I would like my money back'. On that fateful day when he discovers he cannot get it, he says, `Well, I have another solution. I will just charge you double for it because you are now a very bad risk'. We all experience that personally, but the same thing has happened to our country. We have borrowed $100,000m to create 1.6 million jobs, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer boast. The total cost of the wages of that job growth is in that $100,000-$60,000 a job, or four years wages, if you like. It is not very smart because it has had the wrong effect.

The Treasurer, as a reaction, constantly presents himself as a person who has this grand plan for Australia. He is a fix-it merchant, a patch-up merchant. He floated the Australian dollar because the money market dealers of the world were playing games with the currency. They push it up 10 per cent and push it down 10 per cent and make a lot of money both ways. the Treasurer threw them the ball and said, `You go and play with it.' But he did not know, did not understand and did not explain to Australia what might happen. He did not warn the banks that it looked like there was a fortune to be made. They now find that 24 per cent interest is barely enough to cover their bad debts. Who is paying the 24 per cent? It is those hardworking Australians who are still in business, the very people we want to survive.

This is what the Treasurer achieved; this is where the Australian economy stands today. We have this massive economic growth of 3 or 4 per cent, equal to that of the Japanese. We just happen to have one simple difference from the Japanese, through. They have 3 3/4 per cent labour productivity growth whereas we have minus 0.2 per cent labour productivity growth. Our growth is debt funded and it will go on being debt funded, except that it is not now a case of buying less from the rest of the world. We have to find close to $1,000m a month to pay the interest bill. That will not go away, even if we stop buying anything. Who do we blame for that? The Treasurer, in his typical style, will always find someone to blame-never himself.

We have a new problem; some of his colleagues are getting cold feet. There was a debate here today in which some of my front bench colleagues quite properly raised the formal aspects of this matter in terms of the breach of Cabinet solidarity. That is a matter for debate in this Parliament. The fact, though, is that senior members of the Government are starting to fight with one another. They are trying to make sure they do not get the blame.

Senator Walsh, one of the most astute Ministers, decided it was no longer a good time to remain around as Minister for Finance because public anger was eventually going to be directed at this Government. He wanted to be somewhere else so he declined the offer of a further stint as a frontbencher and now sits on the back bench telling everyone how he would have done it all those years ago, when in fact he was booming up the Treasurer for the wonderful steps he was taking. Senator Walsh believes he would have done it all differently if it had not been for his spineless Prime Minister.

Senator Button wants a few bob each way. He thinks that it might not be such a good idea to be too closely supportive of the Treasurer because Senator Button goes out and talks to business people, not antique clock merchants. In his portfolio he is obliged to talk to real business people. I know what they are telling him because they are telling us: they are going broke. Their order books are getting thinner by the day; everybody has closed up shop. People in business can no longer afford to increase their business with interest rates at 24 per cent. It is as simple as that. My own children, who are involved in the business of computers, one of the leading technology areas today, are finding it very hard with no business. Companies are falling over day by day. The good strong ones are going to survive and they are picking up some staff. But people are going broke, and so it becomes a chain reaction.

The Treasurer is still lecturing us and saying that it is going to be a soft landing. If it is a hard landing, Senator Walsh and Senator Button do not want to be around for the bump. They are starting to dispute the Treasurer. In other words, the wheels are starting to fall off Labor's economic cart. The senior blokes know it. They are getting worried, and they want out. They are pretty smart to be in that position. It is just a pity that they could not have been more honest with the electorate quite some time ago so that the electorate had the opportunity to cover its losses and get itself some decent conservative economic managers.

It has never been surprising to me that our Treasurer has a little difficulty in managing this economy. After all, as I have informed the Parliament on previous occasions, he left school at 15 and had a brief flirtation with the private sector. I understand he actually took a job. Then he got himself a job with a trade union-a wonderful place to be-educated in hard free enterprise economics, which is fundamental to Australia. Then at the age of 24, having learned to work at least some numbers, he got himself elected as the member for Blaxland and he has been here ever since. It is a wonderful training ground, I might add, for practical economics.

There is a simple economic theory available to the Treasurer-it is a pity he never learned it-and that is that 2 plus 2 equals four. The Treasurer likes to make it any number that suits his daily argument. He has got this country into a terrible state of affairs. What is more, and no doubt this is well recognised by Senator Walsh and Button and a few others that are probably mumbling away on the sideline but do not know how to get the same level of publicity, we have only survived because these have been very propitious economic times in this period when we have continued to borrow. Our trade deficit this year is only going to be about $20,000m for one year. They have been good times. The rest of the world has been booming. All our commodities have been achieving extremely high prices. There was a time, not that long ago, when we were borrowing thousands of millions of dollars a month and yet we completely sold a $1m-plus wool stockpile. Every fibre of wool that could be grown and shorn in the country was sold.

But what is the situation confronting us today? We have to discuss legislation this week to confront a situation which the Wool Council of Australia in its own table says will probably result in a six-million bale stockpile of wool, one of Australia's leading export commodities, by 1992-93 at which stage the Wool Corporation will apparently owe overseas interests $4,000m. That is about $4,000m that has already been spent in Australia and possibly returned to the source whence it came as our rural industries, having received the money, have gone and bought overseas-manufactured rural equipment because that is the only place they can get it today.

The home of the harvester, the home of the stump jump plough, the home of bearings in plough discs, the home of cane harvesters, you name it-every worthwhile invention in broad acre agriculture has been developed here in Australia-and we buy that technology back from the rest of the world. The main reason for that is that in terms of labour productivity we were never able to sustain a competitive industry to support the brilliance of our inventors and our technology.

These are the issues. This is where this Government has failed. It just gave us the classic Keynesian kickstart. It did it in its first Budget and it did it deliberately. It has all flowed on to the situation confronting us today, and the Treasurer's only solution is high interest rates. `Hit them with high interest rates' he says. `It is a tough decision'. What has it achieved? It has not achieved any substantial reduction in our overseas deficit. That is what it was supposed to do. Everything was going to be hunky-dory at home and people were going to stop borrowing from overseas. Why would that happen? An interest rate of 26 per cent on Bankcard is fairly close to the 18 and 20 per cent that people have been paying for years. The consumers in Australia, with their $700 video cassette recorders, et cetera, are not very discouraged by that 2 or 3 per cent increase.

But the bloke in my electorate who looked out the window last April, saw the rain falling and was aware that wheat as a commodity was something that could be sold easily around the world and at reasonable prices, went back to the breakfast table and said to his wife, `Mum, I think we will plant 5,000 acres of wheat this year', and Mum said, `Hang on a minute. We have only got enough money in the bank for 3,000 acres.' And he said, `Well, it is going to be a good year. I will check with the stock firm and ask them how much they will charge me to carry the rest'. Of course, the stock firm said, `Our current rate, Mr Smith, is 24 per cent', and Mum said, `We will plant 3,000 acres'. That is 2,000 acres of productivity lost to our export effort because the interest was too high to make it viable for that person to take the risk.

Then there are the people with small factories and other people looking to expand. Who was going out looking to export at a 24 per cent interest rate with a labour market which nobody has been able to fix? Ralph Sarich, a Western Australian whom everyone knows, is getting huge publicity as he commences manufacturing his technology in Michigan, the United States. He told me personally years ago that he would never manufacture his engine in Australia for one simple reason. With high automation he could make an engine competitive with engines made in other parts of the world but he just did not know when he could get it out of the country. He could not guarantee supply to where the customers were. The cost of building up inventories in those importer countries to guarantee supply totally destroyed the viability of his product. There has been a total failure to fix up the waterfront so that our inventors and manufacturers can actually write a contract and deliver on time. They were Sarich's own words, and I am talking three or four years ago, maybe five, when I sat next to him on a TAA flight.

This is what our problem is. It is not understood. The Government gets its instructions from the wrong place. Maybe if at the time it had floated the Australian dollar it had deregulated the Australian labour market it might have got somewhere, but it did not do that because it was not able to. It would have messed up too many people's endorsements.

The solution to our wool problem and to our export problems is to look very closely at the value of a totally floating market and the influences there and either, through a continuation of our current dirty float or by recognising the problem, substantially devalue the Australian dollar. People can laugh about that but it is there already in reality. Any business that owed this amount of money would have its share price written down to nearly nothing. The Australian dollar is our share price. We will not get out of our problems without doing it. That is the sort of pain we will have to wear. But it can all be laid at the feet of a very arrogant Treasurer. It is a pity that he is not as good in his thinking as he is in his talking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be grateful, Mr Deputy Speaker, if you accepted my congratulations to the Speaker on his re-election to the high office. I would like to start my contribution tonight by referring in passing to a few comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who I am pleased to see is remaining in the chamber. He said that he believed that drawing up the Budget for the Australian nation is very similar to drawing up and administering a budget for a typical Australian family and that the only difference is that a lot more zeros are associated with the Australian Budget. I suppose that there is a great deal of truth in that. If the Treasurer of this country runs a very tight ship and is very careful about where money is spent that is good for our country and means that certainly there is less risk that the Government is building up debt.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine what has happened in the years under the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in regard to Commonwealth debt and outlays. If the honourable member for O'Connor digs out Budget Paper No. 1, on page 6.9 he will see a table which shows public sector outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product. It shows that in the last Budget which was drawn up by a government of which he was a member Commonwealth outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product were 29.8 per cent. Commonwealth outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product in the last Budget of the Hawke-Keating Government were 26.2 per cent. The honourable member says that the Federal Budget is the same as a family budget, but using his own comparisons it is very clear that, under Treasurer Keating, spending has been much more tightly contained than spending under the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the person who was Treasurer when the member for O'Connor, was a backbencher, had his opportunity to participate in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was probably under Menzies, too.
—I was not able to hear the interjection from the honourable member for Lowe but I am sure that it was as constructive as his previous contributions in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor went on to say that this terrible debt has existed because of the terrible policies of the Government. We are not responsible for the economic policies of State governments such as those run by Mr Greiner and others. We are responsible for the debt of the Federal Government. And what is the debt of the Federal Government at the moment? It is zero, because under this Government we have had massive surpluses built up in the last two Budgets which have meant that we have paid up massive amounts of debt incurred by previous governments such as that in which the honourable member participated.

So what did the honourable member do during the days of Sir Philip Lynch and John Howard when they were running massive deficits at the Federal level? He did nothing. The honourable member should think about the contributions he makes in this chamber. He comes in here and explains to us all the things that are wrong but he does not seem to think that perhaps he could have done more in the years when he was in government. He perhaps could have done something in the years that he had control of the levers that determine what happens in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could have taxed them out of sight like you do.

—The honourable member opposite says that he believes that this Government taxes too much. I invite him to have a conversation with the Premier of New South Wales, the Premier of the Party that he supports, who has increased taxes and charges in New South Wales by record amounts. How much does one pay to register one's car in New South Wales these days? One pays more than $550 to register a car under Mr Greiner-$200 more than in any other State. Why? Because Mr Greiner cannot run an efficient economy. That is the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Greiner, of course, is only interested in raising taxes and charges, every chance he gets. Whether one looks at rail fares for commuters, at electricity charges for consumers or the way he is treating teachers in NSW, his is a record of financial irresponsibility. So the honourable member for O'Connor should not give the House the suggestion that the Liberal Party is the party of small government and low taxes. Mr Greiner's record demonstrates that that certainly is not the case. I will return to Mr Greiner in a few minutes, but I just want to refer to one issue that has come to my attention in case I run out of time later on.

I wish to make some comments concerning the activities of a company associated with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP). I would like to quote from an article that was published in the Sydney Morning Herald last year under the headline, `Mine dumping risks catastrophe'. The article reads:

Papua New Guinea's decision to continue dumping wastes into the Fly River could have catastrophic consequences for 40,000 people living in the river catchment, according to a leading anthropologist. Dr David Hyndman, of the University of Queensland, said the dumping could lead to ``another Bougainville'' as villagers reacted angrily to the destruction of their food sources and lifestyle. Concern is mounting over the PNG Government's decision earlier this month to allow the huge Ok Tedi copper mine to continue dumping heavy metal wastes and silt into the river.

The article goes on to state that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has arranged for scientists to carry out investigations into this issue. It is something that I am concerned about and of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, with your own deep commitment to protecting the Australian environment, I know that you are also concerned about the potential mercury pollution of the Gulf of Carpentaria and waters to the north of Australia.

I understand that the ore is taken out of the mine in Ok Tedi and crushed and some basic manufacturing process is carried out on site. In similar mines around the world they provide for a tailings dam for the wastes of this manufacturing process to be stored. Unfortunately, a temporary tailings dam at the Ok Tedi site was washed away several years ago, and the company that is associated with the Ok Tedi mine has said that it cannot afford to build a new tailings dam to stop these wastes going into the Fly River. I am very concerned that the result of this activity is increasing concentrations of mercury washing into not only the Fly River but also waters to the north of Australia. There is a danger that that might affect the Great Barrier Reef and also some of the beautiful barramundi fillets that people in Australia are known to consume on the odd occasion.

With BHP seeking to have a reputation as a company that does not pollute the environment, I suggest to that company and its board that they should be doing something about reconstructing a tailings dam at the Ok Tedi site. Since BHP will be negotiating with the Government about the future of the Coronation Hill mine, I hope that the company will be prepared to make sure that while it might be a good corporate citizen in this country it will not seek to become a bad corporate citizen in a near neighbour such as Papua New Guinea.

I turn now to the performance of the New South Wales Government, the State Government with which I have had the most to do. I am very concerned about some matters in the administration of that Government. You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in the last Budget the Federal Government provided for $13.2 billion to be made available in general revenue assistance grants to the States, an increase of $247m on the previous year. In the State election campaign in 1988 Nick Greiner promised that he would become the Manager of the Board of New South Wales Incorporated and he would make sure that the Government was run in an efficient manner and that taxpayers would benefit.

After two years, what have we seen? Taxes and charges are up. I have already mentioned the fact that to register a car in New South Wales it will now cost a minimum of $550-$200 more than in other States. Electricity charges and train fares are up. Rail services are down, as people can no longer book sleepers on country trains. Rail services are being shut down and replaced with bus services. Grants to charities, neighbourhood centres and welfare groups have been frozen, so that they no longer receive consumer price index increases. We have the Greiner Government running round the State, selling off State assets. In my own electorate the primary school at The Entrance North has been closed down; not because the student numbers are too low and not because a decline is projected in future years-in fact, the reverse-and not because the school is run down as it is quite a modern building. I think it was opened in 1981-82. For none of those reasons was there any need for that school to be closed and that land to be sold off.

The only reason that Dr Metherell and the Greiner Government have decided to close that primary school in my electorate is that the land has an ocean frontage at the North Entrance. For that simple reason the children are being made to travel all the way to The Entrance primary school. We have people associated with the State Government seeking to say that it is more efficient to sell off a school simply because it has an ocean frontage. I do not think that is sufficient government. I certainly suspect the motives of Mr Wal Murray, the Deputy Premier of New South Wales, the Minister in charge of ensuring that every vacant lot of land along the east coast of Australia is sold off to developers. I have great doubts as to the plans which Mr Murray has for that site at North Entrance.

We might also remember that in the 1988 State election campaign Mr Greiner promised that government funded advertising would no longer be used for political purposes. Do you remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, Nick Greiner promising that he would never use government advertising to score political points? In fact, Mr Greiner said that he was going to send Barrie Unsworth a bill for the government advertising in the last days of the Unsworth Government. What has been the record of Mr Greiner compared to his promises during the last election campaign? Every time one sees an advertisement which has been placed by any New South Wales Government department or government authority, one get this message at the bottom of the advertisement, `Putting people first by managing better'. It is frightening; it is almost like subliminal advertising. Every time one picks up a newspaper one sees this political slogan paid for by the taxpayers-forcing down our throats the message, which Mr Greiner would have us believe-that he is helping the people of New South Wales by managing better.

I wonder what the performance of Mr Greiner has been in trying to manage the State of New South Wales better. I quote to the House some comments made by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) who was the chairman of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee in the last Parliament. The following comments were made about the use of consultants in the Federal Public Service:
Mr Smith said that he believed the $70 million estimated expenditure-
that is, by the Federal Government-
on consultants was probably a conservative estimate because there had been ``a very rapid trend'' for ministers and departments to engage consultants for a wide range of tasks.
``There is little or no scrutiny'', he said. Mr Smith said that the key question to be pursued by the Waste Watch Committee-
that is, the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee-
would be whether the Government and departments were getting value for money by retaining consultants.

What has been the performance of the New South Wales Government in the use of consultants since the Liberal Party and the Opposition are so keen to make sure that the $70m spent at the Federal level on consultants is money well spent and that value is obtained for that $70m? The headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 22 September last year is: `Auditor damns use and control of government consultants'. The article says:
The State Government has employed 4,000 different consultants since it came to office, costing taxpayers $150 million in just 12 months.
An Auditor-General's review of consultant services has revealed that more than 1,400 of these contracts, or 37 per cent, were awarded without tender.
In his annual report, tabled in State Parliament yesterday, the Auditor-General, Mr Ken Robson, criticised the number employed and the lack of formal guidelines covering their use.

It goes on to deal with the problems in engaging consultants in New South Wales. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) suggested that his friends who run the State Government in Macquarie Street are, of course, top economic managers who make sure that money is never wasted. His friend, the honourable member for Bass, criticises the Government when $70m is spent throughout the whole Public Service on consultants. What is his friend Mr Greiner doing in New South Wales? There has been $150m spent on consultants in 12 months, and here we have the Auditor-General saying that 37 per cent of these consultants have been engaged without even going to tender. So how can one say that we are getting good value for money out of that in New South Wales? The way money is being thrown around New South Wales is frightening.

It does not stop at the use of consultants. In last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald the headline of an article was: `$29m lent without guarantees'. The subheading was: ` ``May not be repaid'', Auditor-General on motor race deal'. The articles states:

The NSW Auditor-General has reported that a total of $29 million in Government loan facilities and guarantees were advanced to the backers of Sydney's international motor racing project without their personal guarantees of repayment.

In a review of the Government's fast-track plan to build the circuit at Eastern Creek, the Auditor, Mr Ken Robson, said that the directors of the building consortium had refused to provide any additional surety for a $20 million cut-rate loan provided by the Government.

Because Mr Greiner is unable to win the Olympic Games for Sydney and unable to win the frigates contract for New South Wales, Mr Greiner goes all out to win the Grand Prix for Sydney. He does not worry if he spends the taxpayers' money-up to $29m of it-to win the Grand Prix for Sydney. It does not matter because Mr Greiner has to get that motorcycle race for Sydney no matter how much it will cost the taxpayers of New South Wales. I do not think that is helping the people of New South Wales and I certainly do not think it is managing better.

Nevertheless Mr Greiner came in as the white knight in 1988 who was going to stop corruption, make sure that government advertising was not used for political purpose and ensure that there was no misuse of the Public Service for political purposes. Let us have a look at what has happened to his standards on that issue. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be aware that a former member of Mr Greiner's staff, Mr Gary Sturgess, was appointed Director-General of the NSW Cabinet office. All of us would sincerely believe that Mr Greiner would have searched the country high and low to find the most qualified person to fill that very important office. Unfortunately, there was no one better than someone from Mr Greiner's personal staff, Mr Gary Sturgess, to fill that job. I am sure that Mr Greiner honestly believed that Mr Sturgess was the man most qualified for this particular job.

Let us have a look at Mr Sturgess's performance. What has he been up to since then? I forgot to mention Mr Ian Kortlang, the other member of Mr Greiner's personal staff, who ended up head of the development department in the State of New South Wales. I am sure that Mr Greiner also searched very hard to find the person most qualified to fill that job.

What has Mr Sturgess done since he has been appointed Director-General of the New South Wales Cabinet Office in his role as a non-political public servant? We know that Mr Kortlang and Mr Sturgess did an investigation for Mr Greiner of development proposals on the New South Wales coast. Do honourable members recall when the issue first blew up over developments in the Tweed Shire? Mr Greiner sent his two fix-it men-Mr Sturgess and Mr Kortlang-to sort that out. They prepared a secret report for the Premier which was meant to investigate all the important issues surrounding these development proposals.

Unfortunately, that report has never been made public. The Opposition leader in New South Wales, Bob Carr, has been trying for months to have that report released. Mr Greiner made lots of promises about freedom of information legislation when he was in Opposition, but for some reason this report by Mr Sturgess and Mr Kortlang has been declared a top secret document and Mr Greiner will not release it to the Opposition because, for some reason, this does not fit within the guidelines of freedom of information. I wonder what does.

If one reads last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald one learns that Mr Gary Sturgess, this non-political public servant, employee of the taxpayers of New South Wales, was down here in Canberra last week having lunches and briefings with journalists in the Federal Parliamentary Press Gallery. What business is it for a State public servant employed by the taxpayers of New South Wales to be down here mixing amount the gallery in Parliament House giving briefings on the way Mr Greiner has run the State of New South Wales?

The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) yawns. He does not think this is an important issue. I suggest to the honourable member that the electors of Lowe would think it grossly improper for their taxes to be paying for the Director-General of the New South Wales Cabinet Office to be down here running the political errands of Mr Greiner. If the honourable member for Lowe does not think it is important and if he does not think it is an abuse of the Public Service and the separation of powers, then I think there is something wrong with the honourable member for Lowe and his standards.

Mr Greiner was quite happy to attack people like Tony Adams, the former head of a unit in the New South Wales Public Service because he was prepared to do an advertisement during the days of the Unsworth Government-an advertisement that told people in my electorate that if their specialist tells them there is a long queue to have cataracts taken out of their eyes or to have a hip replacement done, they could ring a hot line number and go to a hospital which was a bit further from home but they would not have to wait. I thought that was a great public service.

When Mr Greiner was elected, Mr Adams was axed because it was thought that he had done something political. The Director-General of the Cabinet Office in New South Wales is down here at the Federal Parliament doing Mr Greiner's political errands. Those opposite think that there is nothing wrong with that. The honourable member for Lowe yawns and says that that is no problem. I think it is a problem. I think it is grossly improper for a non-political public servant to be down here on Mr Greiner's errands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sitting here this evening listening to the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), I appreciate a saying that we often have from the Chair when questions are asked, that these are very wide-ranging debates. From what I have heard of the speech made by the honourable member for Dobell I think he has spoken principally about New South Wales and what is occurring there. I say to him that people in glass houses should not throw stones, because they are likely to break something.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to those who are listening-the record will be in Hansard-that when Mr Greiner and Mr Murray came into government in New South Wales a couple of years ago they faced a State debt of $46 billion and a daily loss of $3m on the railways. One would expect them to do something about that. The people of New South Wales put them in. They obliterated the Labor New South Wales Government because it caused this. The people of New South Wales wanted a change, and they have got that change. Mr Greiner and Mr Murray have certainly been forced to give some very bad medicine economically to the State to try to get it back onto the track. The State of New South Wales is like a business that was not paying. If that is the case, one has to make it pay and has to make very great changes indeed. Those changes are being made.

I do not like to see a passenger train or freight train pass major local railway stations. I think it is a great shame. Nevertheless, we accept the fact that something had to be done to remedy the situation, and the New South Wales Government has tackled that. As I will mention later, the Government has more or less started this State off again on a plain basis from taws.

I refer to the development along the north coast. I have seen judgment of the media in New South Wales. I am sure it can happen to all of us. While I do not pinpoint it anywhere, it is a shame when it happens because the public can get the wrong impression. I ask the honourable member for Dobell and any member of the Government: Can they tonight, or at any other time, point out any developments that Mr Murray or his Government have approved along the New South Wales coastline either on Crown land or anywhere else where they are directly concerned? I challenge the honourable member for Dobell and the rest of the Government to point out to this House and to the people of New South Wales and the rest of Australia where Mr Murray has approved of any developments. They are under consideration. There is always something under consideration. Basically the matters that are under consideration are those that were being dealt with by the previous administration and are still being dealt with by the Government in power now.

Before we get up in this place under the protection of this House, we must be very careful when we say that these things are occurring. If they are, I would like to know where they are occurring. I am sure that many people along the New South Wales coast would like to know. We have not seen them. I hope that sensible developments do occur. Mr Greiner and Mr Murray have very fine environmental rules in that State and they are tightening up on them. That is essential. We want to see that being done more often.

We cannot blame Mr Greiner for losing the frigate contract for New South Wales. I remind the honourable member for Dobell that he, his Labor colleagues and myself all worked darned hard in the Sydney area, particularly the Newcastle area, to try to get the frigate contract placed with Newcastle, where we would have loved to see it.

So let us not say that Mr Greiner is actually responsible for the matter. If any blame is to attach, let us all share it and say that it is just a pity that the contract did not go to Newcastle, where we would certainly have liked to see the frigates constructed.

The most recent Federal election was a funny election. The people in my electorate, I think, were very undecided about how to vote. They were so uncertain and so worried about Australia that they were looking for change. I am quite sure that they did not want to vote for the Hawke Government, although one must be fair and say that, at the same time, they were doubtful about voting for the Liberal and National parties. Many people, therefore, supported the Democrats and the independents. To me, that is a straightforward sign that the people of this country are very concerned about the economy, and about other issues as well.

Australia is a lucky land, when one comes to think about it. We have a Celtic background, and our nation is just over 200 years of age. We must ask ourselves whether we are pulling our weight sufficiently for our own good. Can we afford to keep saying, `Righto, everything's quite okay, mate, let's just go ahead'? I believe that, if the direction of this country is not changed around, before very long we will face very hard times. We will face hard economic times which will affect the standard of education and health in Australia. Home ownership will be affected, as will ownership of land. The hard economic times will affect many other things also.

Today in Australia we need hard work. I would like to see support in this country for going back to a 40-hour week. The Government would oppose this, as would many members on this side of the House. People would contend that we are used to a high standard of living in Australia-and so we are. But I believe that times have been too good. We have been careless. We are all guilty of this, in particular we the administrators. We must tackle this problem very soon. As Senator Walsh, a prominent ex-Federal Minister, has said, it is time to have a look at ourselves and put ourselves in the direction of where we want to go.

We are a social security country. We believe in looking after those people who are disadvantaged, those people in the community who may not be treated fairly, such as deserted wives. We believe in providing refuges for children and all these sorts of things, but we will have to tighten up on those sorts of things. We will lose some of those things, even for those people who deserve support, unless we reduce our balance of payments and unless we can get interest rates and the national debt down.

The inflationary trend is 8.5 per cent. When I first came to this Parliament I learnt from the Treasurer and Prime Minister, as well as from other members from either side of the House, that the way to run into trouble is to keep inflation high. At present inflation is high, at 8.6 per cent, and it will grow higher and will be followed by greater unemployment.

We must realise that we have a responsibility to look at the economy and try to adopt the policies and the administration that are necessary to get us back on the right track. That was the issue at the last election. There was no other issue in Australia on 24 March last more pressing than that of the future direction of this country-to become solvent again, to continue our prosperity, and to place confidence in our young Australians and in our people.

We must get away from the business of criticising Asians or any other people who want to come to our land. Those people who want to come to our land. Those people come here and work. They come here and settle down and work. With the freedoms that they have got under the Constitution they know that they come here and, if they are lucky to be accepted for citizenship, start a business or just hop in and work. I suppose the nation is certainly taking advantage of their doing that.

The Appropriation Bills before the House tonight contain certain savings and extra expenditures in a number of administrations. It is the policy, of course, of any Government to bring these Bills before the House whenever they are required. I just want to speak about a few matters which I think are interesting.

The first is defence. We are very dependent upon defence. I have no great criticism about the hardware that Australia is purchasing today, including the frigates and the submarines. I suppose the way these things should be used is another matter. We have to keep our sea lanes clear and keep ourselves safe. We have to be prepared to go throughout the globe to any theatre of war which may lead to a danger for us.

But I believe that we must give more attention to the wastage that is occurring within our defence forces. It hurts me greatly to know of the number of service men and women who are today leaving the forces. I believe that they are leaving them basically because of pay and conditions. We must keep the hardware side going but not to the detriment of the pay and conditions of our service personnel. I do not believe that services salaries are keeping abreast of increases in the salaries of those in the Public Service and in industry within Australia. We must recognise this, and I trust that the Government will attend to this matter.

I have the Williamtown Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base within my electorate. I want to say something about that base, because it is important. Over 2,000 personnel are employed on the base, which is virtually the home of the new FA18 fighter plane, and there are facilities there to accommodate and train personnel for a long time into the future.

But we have found certain problems there. Today my electorate office received a couple of calls from people who complained about the noise factor. The base was set up during the last war as a defence establishment. Today it has developed into a most important civil aviation airport. We talk about, of course, wanting to see it expanded and eventually an international airport established within the Newcastle region. Over the years a number of subdivisions have been approved around both the base and the weapons range, which is only a few kilometres away.

I was a member of the Public Works Committee that did the hearing on the base before the building of the facilities to accommodate the new aircraft. At that time there was evidence before the Committee concerning the noise factor at the base. Unfortunately, as I say, both the Council and the State had agreed to these subdivisions taking place, at the time not appreciating the potential growth of that area generally and the actual importance of the base to the economy of the Hunter River district generally.

I submitted a minority report suggesting, first of all, that the Government should acquire homes within a certain radius of the weapons range. If that was not done I thought there should be a move made to relocate the weapons range to an area where it would not interfere with the residential areas around it. I am very concerned that the RAAF base generally is under pressure. I believe it has cooperated very closely indeed over recent years with the people living in the surrounding area. It advises people of manoeuvres to be carried out, and there has been general cooperation. Naturally new people are moving into the area, which is a fast growing part of our coastal belt.

I have raised this matter before with the Minister on behalf of my constituents. I do not want to see the base affected. The actual work carried out by the base is terribly important to the defence of Australia. However, I do not want the people on the base to have to worry. I ask the Government to take a long term view and look at relocating the weapons range to an area where it will not affect the local people or place the airmen and people working on the base under a lot of strain. I will certainly continue to pursue this angle because we want to see harmony between the local people and the base. If it is possible, a suitable site should be obtained elsewhere for the weapons range.

This evening I listened to the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) speak about the tourist industry. I agree with everything that he said. The Appropriation Bills contain provision for additional funding for certain aspects of the tourist industry. They contain an amount of $22.5m in respect of the recent pilots strike. Tourism is the growing industry in Australia. It is a great employer of the labour force and a great overseas money earner so far as Australia is concerned. We must do everything possible to support it and encourage it in every way.

My daughter and I were up in Queensland recently and it hurt me to see that some of the entrepreneurs who have established themselves in very big ventures up there and elsewhere in Australia are finding it very difficult to survive. This is a shame because these are the people who are providing the facilities. These people are having a job to survive simply because of the structure of our industrial relations system and our rising costs. We are now becoming uncompetitive so far as our manufacturing industries are concerned-in many cases, this applies to primary industries-and we are grossly uncompetitive with respect to the tourist industry.

We want to see more people from overseas coming to Australia. We want to be able to compete with other countries and attract people here. Queensland has three international airports. If Customs facilities were provided at Coolangatta Airport, the number would be four. That is very good planning. I do not want to say much about Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Maybe I will have the opportunity to do so before the end of the week. But it is scandalous that planes cannot land there without experiencing certain delays. I am sure this is the reason that the overseas tourist promoters are passing Sydney by.

We have to support our local modes of travel. We have to support train travel. We have to do everything we possibly can in this respect. We have to look at how our penalty rates are affecting the tourist industry. In this respect I refer to the five-day working week and overtime. We have to look at these very vital areas. Mr John Brown spoke about this matter a lot when he was a member of this place and the Minister for tourism. I am sure that none of us would disagree with the fact that it is necessary to do something about this industry.

I would like to have talked about community affairs but my time has almost run out. Our community affairs programs are important in looking after the disadvantaged and people who have problems. Let us not overlook the fact that the best people to support people in need are those who work for voluntary organisations. I speak of such voluntary organisations as the Smith Family, the Salvation Army, the St Vincent de Paul Society, the churches and other groups that have played a magnificent role such as service clubs, Rotary, Lions and Quota which have supported people in need within their local areas.

I am worried that much government funding, both Commonwealth and State, goes towards paying for people who are taking the place of many voluntary workers who are capable of doing and are knowledgeable in this kind of work. Tonight I speak only about the principle involved in this issue. I hope that in future we can all be realistic and charitable enough to appreciate the work that these people are doing voluntarily in the community, looking after those who need care and the meals on wheels service. We have district nurses. The object is to keep people in their own homes for as long as we can to save us building nursing homes, hostels and units. That is a direction that I know the Government intends to take. I hope that it does not depart from that direction because in my view it is a very important one.
